header.postText: My Twitter, for smaller thoughts: https://twitter.com/TheeNerdwriter. As I said in the video, this is the kind of thing I love to do with The Nerdwriter: think about moral issues, try to clarify them and understand the intersection of the issue and my own (or our own) presumptions. If you want to discuss more, ask me anything on Tumblr. Also, as always, I'M IN COMMENTS! WORKS CITED TO COME (stand by)

Dude...

In all of history and today still men were always superiror to women in every way other than nurturing children. We know now from decades of research that men and women are about equal in intelligence, and hence the majority of positions of influence, like politics, corporations, government or publications, just to name a few, can be performed equally well by either gender. Personality and temperament varies greatly from person to person regardless of gender. And yet men are still superior. In our civilization it is not acceptable to promote that view, but that view is part of the mentality, conscious or not, of millions of Americans and Europeans. In less advanced and democratic parts of the world a woman is explicitly inferior to a man, her worth ranging fr om nothing to the value of her virginity and family honor. And what's more that is completely natural to deny women equal standing and allow for them to be abused. But here in America try as we may to demonstrate our commitment to gender equality, the reality is much different from what we want to believe. Men still call the shots in business, government, technology, positions of power. The women who make it into the ranks of the magnates are indeed admired, for the ironic reason that they are women who have won the privilege to matter as much as the greatest men. By recognizing successful women we empower women and pay due respect to the established social order of male superiority. The women's sucess is not so much in whatever they have achieved but the fact that their achievements were great enough to prove their equal value to successful men. Why? Why are men assumed naturally superior, more capable, more intelligent, more fit to make decisions, to lead, than women. This is the unspoken truth shared by everybody, even those who fight against it. We all accept that as the norm, even if we want to change it, our mind somehow assumes it the natural assumption a bout gender, wrong though it may be... I have an idea. Men are clearly superior to women in a specific way. And I mean, not an opinon, but a concrete, undisputable superiority over women. Men are faster, stronger, more physically able than women. Sure there are women who can take down a man three times their size or who can outrun 95% of men. But the fa stest woman will always be much slower than the fastest man, the str ongest woman will never match up to the strongest men. The most skilled woman fighter will lose when up against an equally skilled man. Because no matter how hard or how much she wo rks, the woman will never close the gap of physical ability between herself and the man who has done an equal amount of work. This is fact. and we all accept it as fact. And deep down inside, despite all our enlightenment, we value physical superiority like all animals. because in the beginning of our history, it was the only thing that mattered. The strongest person was the most valuable person, in all ways that mattered. And that is thousands of years worth of foundation of the value we ascribe to a human. By this value women are inherently worse than men. Though they may be strong, capable, intelligent, or whatever admirable quality they may have, it's really insignificant when compared to their male counterparts. The barrier was so impermeable that all character traits were subject to it including intellect. Men are superior, because they have always been superior, that is the normal state of the human race. This is the fou ndation of sexism. It may sound ridiculous, but it is very deeply ingrained in our understanding of the world, reinforced millions of times in every culture everywhere at every stage of human civilization. The fact that it is no longer relevant given our great intellectual achievements, our technology, our weaponry, and the advancement of our logic, is not enough to overcome the instinct to give all respect to the strongest person among us, and that will never be a woman. In fact I see no way of c hanging this sexism so long as the physical superiority remains true. So it is interesting to watch the devel opment of the transgender movement, and the complete confusion it causes. Apart from the bathroom issues, what does this mean for women sports? From a purely biological standpoint, the definition of woman is becoming hard to figure out. If anybody regardless of their physical compo sition can be a woman - or a man - then what is the need for genders? add to that the mo vement to reject gender altogether, those who identif y as an >dr ogy>nous, gender queer etc, and I think this is the point of human evolution, the very early stages anyway, of the rejection of gender as no longer needed for social order. Obviously it's a small rather unpopular movement right now, and in many places so offensive that those individuals are in danger of being killed, yet it it is a movement nonetheless, and growing. And if it persists that is what will end sexis m - the uselessness of gender when it is no longer clear and defined and seen as natural. Feminists are wasting their time. That's why I'm not one. Someday I see a much more advanced society of beings who are not divided because of ridiculous physical differences and who see the mind as the only relevant expression of a person. Or maybe I'm just imagining the society ai's who outlive our extinction or self destruction

From what I know one of the biggest correlations known to sociological research (a heavily liberal/leftist-dominated field, by the way) is the one between how egalitarian a country/culture is and how much men and women tend to differ in interests and career choices (it's 0.7 I think). The more feminist the culture the more male-dominated the male-dominated fields and the more female-dominated the female-dominated fields. Like in Norway, Sweden and such. If more women are needed in STEM fields, for reasons of diversity, why isn't there the same emphasis on getting more men into psychology or veterinary medicine? Or to put it this way: If formerly male-dominated fields like these two became female-dominated after the second wave of feminism, why didn't STEM fields? Or...I don't know...plumbing... Also, the dominance hierarchy of "call-out culture" (gaining prestige b y exposing sexism, racism, etc...) on the internet is associated with growing up with social media. And what it is people are in danger of losing are their jobs. Or careers. Like Lindsay Sheperd for example. Because it's a prestige system that has external costs. Other people, who are not part of this call-out culture, and don't want to be (i.e. anyone born before 1995 :D), pay the price. Also more and more ex-SJWs are coming out with stories and accounts describing an environment of anxiety and depression. So, not even SJWs are actually enjoying being SJWs. They're just conditioned that way. Just like only 3 percent of all teenagers on Instagram & co. are actually liking it, while the vast majority feels anxious during, yet still participates. To me it's not a question about whether or not to let them be, but about how to help them.

I'm always conflicted with that assumption that it's JUST cultural norms that divide male/female social roles. Some of it is nature. Human male are more prone to evolutionary mutations than human female, so there is more extremes on male Gaussan distribution than on the female one. That reflects in human species behaviour as well: males tend to take more and bigger risks, while females tend to play it safer. STEM field is a high-risk one: one can work hard for decades, and not get any ground-breaking results. I understand that there is gender bias inside the hard sciences communities, and it's something that should be fought, but putting the blame for disproportional number of females in hard sciences SOLELY on mysoginism is criminally stupid.

In egalitarian societies - such as the Nordic countries - where male and female equality is championed and encouraged through culture and education, studies found that women were MORE likely to choose fields/careers that are generally female-dominated: nursing, social work, education, just to name a few. The idea that the lack of women joining STEM fields is predicated on discouragement rather than disinterest is simply false.

commentThread.commentText: Absolutely terrible take, and here's why 1) Listing statistics is all well and good, but unless you can connect them to your point of contention, they're worthless. I completely fail to see the connection between 'Guy wears a shirt' and 'fewer women go into STEM careers'. You can't really lean on 'boys club' mentality either, as studies have shown that fewer women (as a percentage) go into STEM careers in very liberal countries than they do in countries with stronger gender roles 2) As clearly demonstrated in the beginning of your video, plenty of women are not offended by the shirt, and plenty of men are. Therefore, acting like this is both completely and solely affecting women is both disingenuous and an insult to the women who are sensible enough to not let something this petty bother them 3) Characterising sexism as a power trip is essentially a strawman that allows you to tar anyone that disagrees with you. You offer no evidence that anyone actually thinks this way, only rhetoric. This point is so lacking in substance that i'm amazed you even mentioned it, nevermind trying to spin it as a life lesson to close out the video To answer your question, i'm both annoyed that one of the greatest achievements in human history was blighted by a ridiculous overreaction to something barely out of the norm, and threatened that completely innocent behaviour with absolutely no ill intent behind it (no, not even subconscious ill intent) can be spun so dramatically as to stir up a mob of hate against someone who di d nothing wrong PS: the shirt was designed and made by a woman, so all the criticism of the shirt is having an exponentially worse effect on women in creative industries than the shirt itself is having on women in STEM. If I made something for my friend that got such a bad reaction from the public that he had to make a tearstained apology over it, I'm not sure I'd ever want to make anything again.
The comment section is quite informative.. I think I like it more than the video. Thats a first.
I feel threatened. I feel like I'm in danger of losing my freedom of expression.

I'm not mad at the guy wearing the shirt, I'm mad at pile of managers, HR, PR people, that saw that shirt and let him wear it on national television. This is why we have dress codes, so that a single person's need to "express themselves" doesn't overshadow the company's message. Now, nobody can remember what the Rosetta's accomplishment was but everyone remembers the dumb stuff on that guy's shirt. It isn't even a feminist issue - if there were a female engineer on tv wearing a "I drink boy tears" shirt, and she was talking about a breakthrough in technology... guess what we'd be talking about. Her stupid shirt. The problem with society is that as a female engineer, I'd be hesitant to ask someone to talk to him about his shirt. Because I don't want to look like I'm being "hypersensitive" or "too emotional for the workplace". And that's why women don't go into STEM, so they don't have to deal with that brand of BS.
Billions of people live normally without such "pleasure". How come some of us need extra pleasure to feel good about themselves an that is found at the expense of others?

I am in a stem field of study. I love mathematics and i love doing makeup. For some reason this irks alot of my professors. And this moment i will share is only 1 of a handful i have been through, all along the lines of comments on my look. Currently i am the only women of 3 in a class of 50. This is actually a common theme since i have left basic algebra. Not many woman in higher fields of math. The sexists jokes get thrown around which i could be apathetic about. Sadly im ised to it. Recently i have asked my professor a question regarding differential equations and he stopped me mid sentence and said 'please, just stop, i cannot focus on your question when your wearing SOOOO much makeup.' I was rather speachless. So i just kept my head down the whole class. When i spoke to him about it after class as to why he felt the need to say something like that in an entire room of men he simply said ' you do not potray the image that the STEM division of this college. Tone down the look and maybe well talk. Then he jokingly said 'or grow a penis' i just laughed because i didnt know what else to do. This is a man who ran the STEM department at my college and could have a very big impact on my future. All i do now is keep my head down and kill it on exam days. Im working harder than i ever have to prove him wrong. Sadly i shouldnt have to do that, but i will never let a man in the stem field bring me down.

Sexy is not inherently sexist. The sexism piece comes in when one gender is far more often portrayed as being sexy, and that their worth is, in part, derived, from their physicality and sexuality. So, women are far more likely to not only be portrayed a s sexual, almost ubiquitously, but also more likely have their sexuality emphasized as important over other important features (one example is how rare leading roles in media are for non-physically attractive women, when the reverse is not true of men). Another example, it is rare to see a camera linger and move over a man's body as if that body was being viewed through the eyes of someone sexually attracted to the man's body. There may be reasons this happens, but those reasons do not change that this contributes to a cultural understanding of women's bodies and who i s "sexual." This actually is unfair to both men and women . Men often complain about having a LACK of sexual presence, never being complimented, never being pursued, as opposed to always being the pursuer. All of this, in part, relates to how men and women are portrayed sexually, and disadvantages that come from being either reduced to one's sexuality, or conversely, having one's sexuality ignored entirely. The sexism at work piece comes in when employers, co-workers, interviewees, also start looking at women through this len s, as sexual beings first instead of fully human, and w e know sexism does show up in this wa y, from sexual harassment onward.

I'm seeing a lot of horrendously illogical takes that try to reverse things and call this video sexist for saying that women are oh so fragile and need to be protected from a shirt. "It's just a shirt" shows a lack of understanding of the power of symbolic meaning. That shirt presents women as sexual objects, and sexual objectification of women is immensely more prevalent than that of men. There' s nothing wrong with sexiness by itself, but over time our culture has started to focus so heavily on the sexiness of women and so little on anything else women have to offer (case in point the existence of the Bechdel Test) that women start to feel like the message they're getting is that only their sexiness matters. This is the root of self-esteem issues, because culture is telling them that if their appearance isn't up to pa r, nothing else is going to redeem them or make them worthy of love. This shirt is another of those thousands of images that reinforce this same theme. This is something that only women have to put up with. It's not a situation where women are being coddled for something that any person should have the grit to put up with; it's a situation where men don't have any issue like this at all, and it's a disadvantage that only women face. That's where the sexism is, in the fact that men aren't made to obsess over their appearances to nearly the same degree. It's not that we're trying to protect women from things that men deal with on a daily basis without breaking a sweat; it's that there's a real aspect of this that alienates women and just women. Not all women, sure. But I do think the women who speak out like "this is fine, I don't know what everyone's getting so worked up about" aren't sensitive to the fact that there really are women that are upset and turned off certain sub-cultures and communities by things like this. Having the grit to work through a less-than-ideal workplace environment because it's the career you feel passionate about is admirable, bu t no woman should have to work through issues like that in the first place. Trying to remove barriers like that is still fig hting sexism.

People (including some further down this feed) try to end discussions by declaring that women today are experiencing greater equality than in the past or by demanding to be shown an example of a right that men have that women don't. It's not productive to stop the discussion once we reach the end of easily quantifiable things like "can women vote." The discussion is more nuanced now than it was 100 years ago, because the problems that face today's women can't necessarily be fixed by introducing legislation. That doesn't mean they don't exist. It's also more difficult to quantify today's inequalities because not all women respond to the same issues in the same way, and not all men perpetuate these problems (and men are, obviously, not the sole perpetuators of harm or stereotype against women). Asks like "Let us vote" has been replaced with asks like "Don't objectify us," which are harder to explain and don't change as visibly, since they're not binary. Something as innocuous as this shirt presents a problems for not all, but a good number of women who are treated poorly in the workplace by not all, but SOME men, and wearing such a thing in an academic or professional setting makes those women remember the current state of things: that they are generally less well-regarded in STEM (I was a software engineer at Google when the Damore manifesto leaked; that didn't feel awesome), and that their gender faces a greater likelihood of experiencing sexual violence at the hand of SOME, NOT ALL men who are influenced IN PART by media that portrays women as status symbols valued for their aesthetics to be "worn" by men.

"What is it am in danger of losing?"

That's just the problem though: he was crucified. Like everyone who does anything in the view of the internet is. Small minded people with nothing better to do than shit on other people make mountains out of molehills and ruin other people's lives. You didn't used to meet these people: they are the brother of your friend that no one has seen in five years, and the sister of the guy who fixes your drainpipe that he thinks might be selling crack. /ignore, and move on with your life. Getting worked up over their opinion is not worth your time and effort. The problem is that girls are told from Kindergarten, if not earlier by their parents, that math and science are not for them. They are steered away from these subjects early on. Math and science teachers, often the first male teachers they encounter, do little to make the subjects interesting to them. Vapid books written to appeal to girls whose idea of a good read is Seventeen Magazine do even more to push potential female scientists away. Those aren't the girls who are going to become scientists anyway, it's the ones who find the magazines ridiculous. When a girl shows a talent for languages she isn't directed towards programming, but instead towards French lessons. Not that I am saying my French classes were a waste of time, but it would have been nice to know that programming languages were an option when I was nine instead of finding out about them in my 20s. To make matters worse, College usually sours women (and this is definitely true for me as well) on the idea of a career in Academia. The petty bickering, the harassment, the long hours and low salaries, the near-impossibility of landing a tenured position: most women just don't want to deal with it. There are plenty of jobs for a woman with a scientific degree outside of academia, and the barriers for entry there are lower. As biology, chemistry, physics and computer science become ever larger parts of the regular economy: Academia will need to change or struggle to attract anyone. It's primarily this which causes the statistics that you cited. Women may not be working in the field that they studied in college: that doesn't mean they got a shit job. Since they work outside of universities, they also don't publish as frequently or at all. Finally: the usual definition of STEM fields is inherently biased. While they include the traditionally male-dominated field of video game development-despite the fact obvious to any gamer that at least half of video game devs are artists, not engineers-they do not include the traditionally female dominated fields of nursing and social work. These fields are equally quantitative, requiring a strong background in science. If you want to say that you are advocating for female scientists, you cannot just conveniently forget to count scientists when they happen to be mostly female.

Academia is very competitive. If a woman gives up on her dream of becoming a scientist because she saw an offensive shirt on the internet, she never had the determination required to succeed in academia in the first place. So nothing's lost here really.

In response to the suggestion that the underrepresentation of women in STEM reflects the fact that women are less interest in science, you say "maybe [these] assumptions are following from cultural norms so invisible they seem like insights about gender." This isn't an argument. The suggestion that what seems self-evident might actually be a reflection of pervasive bias applies with equal force to your view that the underrepresentation of women in STEM reflects institutionalized sex discrimination. In other words—you didn't SHOW that women like science less; you side-stepped the argument entirely. Since you like science, you know that valid hypotheses must be falsifiable. But if you're going to deny the existence of meaningfu l sex difference and assume, instead, that a ny gender disparities are the result of sexism in the ether--is your hypothesis falsifiable? What would it take to prove to you that this I SN'T sexism?

What about the pleasure "victims" feel when they condemn the source of their "oppression," or when they inflate the severity of the "offense," or when they see others rally to their cause and their "oppressor" publicly shamed and chastened? Should we not guard against that? Should we allow lives to be ruined merely to validate the feelings of the overly sensitive?

I'm not even saying that you are incorrect in pointing out that there is a boys club in stem. However imagine you were a smart, if impressionable, young girl interested in science. However, every time you bring it up every one makes sure to tell you that stem is a toxic, hyper masculine boys club and you'll have you work cut out for you if you make that your career, fighting an uphill battle against a prejudiced and patriarchal system. Perhaps discouraged enough that you might much rather get a degree in literature or philosophy, which you also very much enjoy and which are apparently less of a pain in the ass for women to make a mark in? Now what if you are a girl who is not discouraged by the notion of an uphill battle against tall odds, the kind of battle that multiple cultural figures like the nerd writer here have convinced you that you will most certainly encounter, will you likely be discouraged by a scientists goofy shirt because it has sexy women on it? The point of what I am staying is that, even assuming that science is a patriarchal boys club, if you are concerned about who might be discouraging girls from pursuing science you should look into the mirror. Frankly, I think that if a girl is young enough to be discouraged by this man's shirt she will only be so after someone like you has explained to her that it is something that she should find discouraging. This is a perfect example of the ecological fallacy and the single-cause fallacy. Engineering is dominated by men, but that doesn't mean that there is an inherent misogyny or gender bias in that field. The medical field is dominated by women, but I don't hear anyone talking about getting more men in medicine. There are psychological differences between men and women on average (key words: "on average"). Left to make their own choices (i.e. given equality of opportunity), men and women, on average, choose different professions and careers. And there' s nothing wrong with that. What I have a problem with is "equality of outcome:" creating these quotas to hire people based on gender or other arbitrary physical characteristics. You can't just look at the data and assume intent; you have to look at what is CAUSING that outcome. If it's prejudice, then take steps to change that. But most of the time, these statistics are used to conflate unrelated phenomena in order to promote an agenda. I notice that people also use the fallacy of composition with this topic as wel l: "sexism still exists, therefore the gender disparity in industry X is d ue to sexism." I don't deny tha t some misog yny and gender bias still exists. But to argue t hat that sexism is systemic is a different claim altogether. When these arguments that vict imize one gender are made and propagated (especially without sufficient evidence), they perpetuate an "us vs. them" mentality throughout our society. This has the opposite effect that's desired. The same stereotypes that hurt women, also hurt men. The same stereotypes that hurt men, also h urt women. Gender issues on both fronts are very different, but arguably equal. You cannot solve one without solving the other. I'd be willing to go into this further, but this comment is long enough. This same issue can also be applied to race and racism, but that's a discussion for another day.

replies.commentText: Your argument is a classic strawman, and intellectually dishonest. This video cites the shirt, not as a primary cause for STEM's inaccessibility to women, but as a symptom of a larger problem of passive misogyny. No one is suggesting that he actively pawed through his wardrobe, looking for the best way to demean women via shirt pattern. Rather, the argument is that he is part of a culture that cares so little about the input of women that he did not need to actively consider the implication of a shirt covered in semi-nude women. Taken as a single instance, sure- it doesn't matter. But have you ever heard of the phrase 'the straw that broke the camel's back'? It's not just a shirt that causes women to reconsider science. It's the constant wear, even from small things like an inappropriate shirt, that grinds women in science down and causes others to seek professions which aren't as destructive to one's self worth. Source: am woman in science

I appreciate the fact that the narrator avoids definitive approval or disapproval of the shirt-- it is, after all, just a shirt, and entirely within a mans rights to wear or not wear-- but also would like to say this annoyance is not necessarily the pervasive pull of the insidious sexism(although it might also be): sociology is simply too complex a field to so easily categorize a particular reaction or emotion. I do not believe, moreover, that traditions and existing culture should be abandoned out of hand; they provide a truly vital degree of identity to men and women alike and thus have to weighed carefully against potential cultural upheaval which can bring both increased equality and increased intolerance

commentThread.commentText: If bigotry is about the pleasure of exerting one's dominance, would it serve to reason that a more effective method of ending bigotry may be to celebrate deliberate non-bigoted actions in context, rather then condemn the bigoted ones? Are we entrenching people with bigoted beliefs when we condemn them, when instead we should be offering accolades or even tangible rewards for being purposefully inclusive, or, let's say, helping end a particularly contentious conflict? Are we doing ourselves a disservice by calling bigotry "hate" in the first place? Perhaps a better phrase would be "alpha speech" (rather than "hate speech"), or "superiority crime" (rather than "hate crime")? I wonder if there is a suitable reward that can match or exceed the pleasure of exerting one's dominance, and if that may be a more effective tool for combating bigotry than merely hating it back? What can someone do in the context of a situation like shirt-gate to be praiseworthy, and what would the appropriate accolade or response be? Not for nothing but maybe Mel Brooks was right - that the best tool for handling hatred is to turn that hatred into the butt of a joke. I suppose that's always an option too. Thanks for the perspective, @TheNerdWriter

Sexual attraction is a natural human condition. So I'm going to play Devil's Advocate here and ask, does appreciating or admiring an image of sexual expression automatically constitute oppression and/or perpetuate exploitation by default? Case study: I see a seductive photo shoot or advertisement with a model, done completely of her free will, who I think is stunningly gorgeous in a sexual way. Now, I'm not about to go out and rape the next girl I see. I under no circumstances believe she should be paid less than a male counterpart doing the same job. I don't believe her opportunities should be restricted due to he r gender or that she should be pigeon-holed solely to similar lines of work. I don't believe that it would be fair if she was presented with no opportunity to make a living, other than by appearing in sexy photo shoots. I absolutely don't view her as an object, I see her as an attracti ve woman expressing her sexuality. I understand that there are many other facets that complete t hat woman as a person, be it intellectually, emotionally, spiritually, altruistically, etc, but at this point I can only appreciate her physical beauty/sexuality that I naturally find attractive. What does that make me? Another question I have is, what counts more? A person's freedom to be able to express themselves sexually or how offended some people might get by that sexual expression? Someone offend ed by sexual images can easily turn away, but would it be morally right to stop individuals creating such consented content? We know sexuality comes in many different forms and not everyone shares the same tastes, but as long as it's not harming anyone then it should be respected. Are we on course to creating a society so sterile, sensitively fragile, and devoid of emotion that we'll no longer be able to revel in openly expressed sexuality? That would be a travesty as the sexual diversity and expression found within people (everyone) is one of the most beautiful things about humanity. What if the sexuality itself is not the issue, but how it's being interpreted and used by certain sections of society? Is eradication and hyper-sensitivity really the solution then or would that create a paradox of reverse oppression? Call me crazy, but I'm of the belief that educating people on how to deal with all forms of sexuality would go further than a campaign of censorship driven by the minority who i nterpret sexual expression as an avenue for social dominance.

We lose focus, the ability to distinguish what real dangers are, as ever the more benign become seemingly malignant.

Actually, the choice of shirt says a lot about the man who chose it. It says that he wants to reduce women to cartoons, that he finds women inherently aggressive and punishing and that they make him feel small and a victim. It is what is behind most misogynist behaviors, a fear that women are going to beat them, that they are inherently superior. We ain't. I have been living with this for sixty plus years and am so disappointed to see it still coming up, still being relevant. Pubescent girls are told to wear golf shirts and baggy khakis to class because anything else distracts the boys (hate to tell ya, but the abaya results in as much sexual harassment of women in public as do short-shorts. An Abaya is a black burqa without the eye screen.) Girls and science - we LOVE science. We tend to be very good at science. Heck, chemistry is cooking you can't eat. Quantum mechanics is right up our alleys - we are not naturally linear thinkers and qm is a balancing act of plates on poles. In four or five dimensions. Heck, bring it on! But the erosion starts with breast buds and our first periods, with teachers and parents directing us to make it easier on the boys. With teachers who are still more likely to wait for a boy to raise his hand before allowing a girl to answer. With publications that won't take our work without a man's name over ours. (This even happens in fiction publishing - Nora Roberts publishes her science fiction mysteries under a pseudonym that is gender ambiguous. Rowling was told to not use her first name because no one would buy that kind of fiction fro m a woman.) It wasn't until 1957 that women could sign for a loan, be the name on a mortgage or car title. I see signs everywhere of politicians and other groups trying to push women back that way. It is what is behind the anti-immigration sentiment - a fear of having to compete.

As a female, though, I feel part of that lack of emotional response is a cultural conditioning around that sort of issue. I feel as though I'm used to seeing images like that all over. I believe there are legitimate gender inequality issues present in STEM but not so severe such that wearing the wrong shirt is considered important, especially in first-world countries where often girls are being motivated wherever they can to pursue a STEM major. As a female studying and working in CS/Engineering in a first-world country, I cannot stand this constant babying of girls here--often certain opportunities are given (especially in tech) exclusively to women and under-represented minorities (i.e. non-Asians and non-Caucasians) while we are in university. All they've done for me is distance myself further from my male peers who feel slighted at the idea that they have a smaller shot at certain internships and opportunities just because I was born the right sex, despite having a weaker resume. There may definitely be some biases at the graduate and post-graduate level that I'm not aware of so I can only acknowledge that they may exist; I don't know enough to comment further. But my perspective is that if you can be so easily deterred from studying STEM because of someone's choice of clothing, then maybe you shouldn't study STEM in the first place. Sexism in STEM is complicated and goes beyond "STEM hates women". I'm sick of discussions about this issue being focused around shirts and toys. You speak so eloquently, your speech alone is enough to make me want to binge watch all of your videos. (This comment is long and does not at all mention the t-shirt incident mentioned in the video above) This is a really really late comment but personally, I feel that, to some degree, young women are not exactly encouraged to pursue STEM careers. Take it from a 17-year old in a public science high school from a third-world country trying to pursue a career in physics, which is arguably one of the most male-dominated fields in research. In my year, the ratio of boys to girls is two is to one. Overall, there are more males than females in my school. This can mean that when there are issues affecting the student body, such as, let's say, overpopulation (because our country had just adjusted to a K-12 curriculum and they were not able to build additional dorms because of budget constraints), the males would be given a higher priority than females. In our campus, there are 2 dorms each for males and females. For the past four years the females only occupied one, so the following school year, when the student population was expected to increase by 25%, they decided that to give the unused dormitory to the boys. Somewhat reasonable based on the logistics, however, the girls were either forced to cram their already full dormitory to accommodate the new tenants. Some of the girls were forced to vacate the dorm, while the others, like myself, were forced into smaller, more crowded rooms. Unfortunately, the stress accumulated due to the taxing requirements accompanied by the new, less-conducive-to-studying atmosphere of the room. My mental health degraded and I started have panic attacks. I was not able to attend classes for a long period of time--long enough for the higher-ups to consider my dismissal from school. Take into account that I had been performing exceedingly well before I developed severe anxiety. I was one of the very few in our year who was consistently in the honor roll. In the end, the school gave me an ultimatum: either catch up on everything that I missed (which was half a year of work) within two weeks, repeat a year, or withdraw. I chose the last option for the sake of m y mental stability. Mine was not an isolated case. At least 20 of my batchmates also developed some form of (clinically-diagnose d) mental illness. Most of us were girls. Our already-dwindling female population in the science high school decreased all the more. Even a close (male) friend of mine would tell me that (non-verbatim) ours is a male-dominated field and always will be because men are really better at math than women. He would tell me this when I ask about his math competitions abroad and inquire on the percentage of females competing and winning the event. Not to worry, though. I still plan on pursuing a career in physics and I don't think I would consider any other path than that.

Generally speaking, women just aren't that into science. Not that they can't be, and not that there's a problem when they are. Marie Curie, for example, was one of the most important scientists in history. But, neurologically speaking, women operate differently than men. Men's brains tend to navigate structural problems better, while women's tend to navigate interpersonal problems better. Not that this matters, but it does help to explain the lack of women in STEM fields. Assuming oppression without evidence does not. It's okay for women to be scientists, and it's okay for them to not. It's okay for men to be nurses, counselors, and elementary school teachers, and it's okay for them to not. But obsessively demanding a 50/50 gender split in all occupational fields will do nothing more than drive people into fields they don't really want to be in . Nobody demands a 50/50 split in sewage workers, for example. Everyone should aspire to the job that they want, and statisticians should get over the "representation gap." To assert th at sexism is the cause of this gap is to assume your conclusion. And also, people need to get over "objectification." It's not misogyny, it's advertising, and it happens to men as well. I think one important premise to establish is whether or not the belief that the objectification of women is deleterious to the standing of women in society is true. Feminists seem to argue that when women in a culture are continually sexualised in a certain manner (objectification) their perceived non-sexual values are diminished. If this is correct it stands to reason that if all women in a culture are not as valued as men for attributes such as intelligence, decisiveness, etc. that women would not enjoy equal opportunities in many areas. So, it seems that responses to this controversy are predicated on the belief or disbelief that the kind of sexualisation apparent on Matt Taylor's shirt would precipitate such an effect. In order for that to be answered one would have to have a great depth of knowledge of the psychology of sexualization and its consequences socially, something which I, the authors of "think pieces" and other laymen lack.
To answer your last question; I'm in danger of losing my freedom of speech. And that, good sir.. I will not take.

There's no confusion about what we were afraid of losing. When a hard working, intelligent, dedicated, and apparently nice guy like Matt Taylor can be brought to tears by self-anointed moral crusaders because of a shirt, we have ventured into dangerous territory. You talk about how racists and sexists and the like derive pleasure from their sense of superiority and power over others, and you are absolutely correct, but this is the same thing happening with people who go around saying that everything under the sun is somehow prejudiced and harmful. They are taking pleasure in asserting their dominance over others by shaming them, turning them into a pariah, over barely perceptible slights. This culture of hyper-sensitivity pushes society further from the ideal that its adherents, as well as many of its victims, desire. In hindsight, we can see that this is exactly what happened with the Clinton campaign and why it was such a failure. More than any candidate in the last two decades, Clinton spent much of her time campaigning attempting to shame the opposition, and the results have clearly been disastrous, having the exact opposite effect to what was intended. This is what we were afraid of losing; the once liberally minded, socially conscious, free-speech advocating left has been corrupted by this authoritarian and hateful ideology that is no more self-aware of its own hypocrisy and the harm it does than it claims Taylor was of his shirt and its supposed detrimental effect on girls' ambitions. Regarding differences in male and female career choices, and gender norms in general: there is a plethora of evidence from multiple lines of scientific inquiry that supports the hypothesis that there is a biological basis for the observed differences in male and female preferences. Obviously, this doesn't say anything about whether or not there is sexual discrimination in STEM fields, but it should at least make one pause and think critically when presented with some sex-based statistics so as to avoid committing a base-rate fallacy error.

As a feminist, I have to disagree. Yeah, I think the shirt is a part of negative images of women, and yeah, I do think it has an effect on how people think (and before anyone says that it infantilizes women to say that they're influenced by things like that, everyone is influenced by their environment; there's no such thing as a personality or choice that isn't). People don't realize the influence because they take it for granted, but I do think it matters. But this was just one instance; the guy wore the wrong shirt, and it wasn't great, but he probably just didn't think about it. He absolutely did get skewered, if not here, then plenty of other places. And that's ridiculous; everyone makes gaffes from time to time. The thing to do is talk to the person; usually, they'll apologize, be more careful in the future, and everyone moves on with their lives. And honestly, one shirt choice is the least of reasons why women might feel unwelcome in STEM fields. Why was everyone suddenly attacking him? I'll tell you why: bandwagon mentality. It became something to talk about and have an opinion on. And people felt self-righteous about those opinions, on both sides. But I think THAT is the main reason people don't want to hear it: it's less about talking about attitudes toward women, and more about trying to make yourself look more enlightened than everyone else. It's true that people don't want to give things up, but when you bring things up in a more down-to-earth context, they might disagree, but they're a lot less likely to get hostile.I actually think one of the biggest problems facing modern Feminism is its own sanctimonious attitude; nothing makes people shut down faster than acting like you're better and/or smarter than them. Fortunately, I do think there's a movement against that trend, with people saying things more like, hey, I'm not trying to say you're bad or stupid; this just bothers me, and here's why. I don't even think you have to give up everything that has some sexism in it... but that's a different subject.

I've been ruminating on a term that has become ubiquitous on youtube in as diverse discourses as politics, sports, gaming, and flaming. That term is being someone's "bitch." Although it is used to describe the dominance of one allegedly straight man (Putin) over another allegedly straight man (Trump), it originates from, and correct me if I get this wrong, the disempowered position of a female dog beneath the male dog that is humping her. The use of this term even by what I believe are enlightened, progressive people perpetuates, I believe, the rampant verbal sexualization of all competition. I believe the term, being someone's bitch, has extended into the gay >community as well so that in those relationships, too, instead of venturing into new, egalitarian modes of communion simply parrot all inside traditional heterosexual relations that keeps the politics of power alive. Women use this terminology as much as men, and never before have I heard articulated a reason for its popularity until I watched this video: the pleasure of domination. So long as we slice up domination and focus on all the "isms" lik e racis m, sexism, etc. We keep the lens focused on the victims instead of what inspires a perpetrator to act out aggression. I think it is indeed this pleasure of domination, which is reinforced in myriad ways throughout our culture, so much so that we don't blink when we hear of someone being another's "bitch." It's a sort of pathology of competition, the threads of which are so woven into the fabric of our society as to appear, as you say, invisible. To this day, for example, few people know who Lynn Margulis is or the era of symbiogenesis she introduced to evolutionary theory, effectively bringing to an end the view that survival meant solely competition. Our vocabulary egregiously lags, ever tapping into medieval concepts of brute dominance when in fact at every turn, cooperation has been shown to be as much a key to success as any other. Some people might see a shirt like that as a bunch of admittedly over-sexualized "kick-ass bitches" and admire those images of women as somehow empowering to the female. Some people might see a shirt like that as objectifying women, belittling the significance of their intellect, and blaming the lack of women in important STEM fields on the biases that are obviously alive and well. Then there are others who might question why it is seen as admirable for women to enter the traditionally male arena of competition, e ven sexual competition, testosterone hype, and the politics of dominance. Do claiming those things add one iota of freedom and empowerment to the state of women? How can it when we still have in our language terminology like "being one's bitch," which immediately connotes that the traditional position of the female is that of disempowerment? Do we then somehow empower that position? Or do we summarily divorce it from its origin? I don't know. But it seems to me an important question.

I still don't dislike the shirt. I do feel threatened: I feel like these people threaten my freedom of expression. I'm sure sexism exists, but I'm not sure we're dealing with it appropriately by focussing on something so benign.

I suppose the point I raise has already been raised ad nauseam sempiternam, but... just on the off chance that someone may not have heard it, or may want to engage... the question to me is the correlation. When you claim that Matt's t-shirt is 'part of a culture' that 'influences women away from STEM' (Mike's apt comparison with the colors of poisonous frogs sort of summarizes it rather well), what I miss is the evidence other than the fact that there are fewer women than men in STEM fields. As the saying goes, correlation does not imply causation, and one should always be distrustful of easy "just-so" stories. The truth to me is that we still don't have a good science of "social engineering" that can really answer the question, 'what is the expected impact of this or that element (be it a work of art, an idea, a tendency, a meme, an ideology, a scientific fact...) on society as a whole?' To pretend that we do -- that there is a simple causal relation between "sexualized images of women (or men) in the media" and sexism, for instance, because "it's obvious" -- begs the question. There is research supporting this idea, and there is research supporting the opposite idea -- at best this is far from being a settled question. But, as you said... the dirty secret of sexism -- and of ant i-sexism -- is that it's a pleasurable way of asserting dominance. If a group can dominate the narrative -- "sexualized images" > "sexism" -- and silence other narratives, or at least make them avoidable for thinking people... then what have we escaped from, really? Certainly not oppression, as it is now understood . "Patriarchy" is not in itself a bad concept; like, say, "primitive society", it is simply trying to capture some sort of anthropological intuition about society. It's the use that is made of it that can be, and often is, cringeworthy. "Primitive society", which could have been simply a technical term, became offensive because of its use to justify evolutionist views of human groups, thus placing higher importance and higher worth on our own group -- the danger of bad ethnocentrism (there is a good ethnocentrism, but that's a topic for a different post) is quite obvio us. "Patriarchy" as a justification for anything that is seen as (as opposed to being proven to be) bad for women (or men as a gender, lately) similarly begs the question. Boogeymen never really explain anything, because they don't exist. A number of things that are bad for wome n as a gender (or for men, for that matter) probably have much deeper (and surprising) roots than the i dea of "patriarchy" gives them credit for. Here, as was the case for 'primitive society", the danger of (over)simplification and reification -- of assumi ng that "patriarchy" is something material, like a bunch of sexist pigs hiding somewhere and controlling everything, rather than a complex and basically still unexplored system of relations -- may end up with t his word, "patriarchy", becoming similarly dangerous and ultimately counterproductive. As I watch would-be SJWs consistently misrepresent problems and their solutions in the internet, the end result -- 'patriarchy' been reduced to just a word used to silence certain people, e.g. white men, which is what MRA's are trying to do to it -- seems woefully unavoidable.

I'm a science major, I work with women in my classes and research everyday. They are PhDs, grad students, and undergrads. Those who are passionate about the sciences, just are. I've never experienced this "boy's club" mentality. To pay the bills I work in a small, locally-owned company and I definitely experience it there, so I don't feel like it's something I'm blind to. And, as a science major, I can tell you for a fact, no researcher cares about the gender of the author in a potential citation. None. Most of the time you can't even tell who they were, as most published names have an initial for first letters, and there is no way, no way tha t gender would somehow quell the hunger we all feel when we're making an argument in an abstract to our own research paper or grant proposal. Maybe that doesn't make sense to someone who's not in the sciences, but there is a desperate, desperate hunger to build substantial arguments, and I can't even imagine a proclaim ed misogynist googling each author for a citation, just to make sure there weren't any women in there... Some publications have upwards of 20 authors! Can you imagine the time requirement necessary to be that petty? Not to sound self-important, but those of us in the sciences have way more pressing matters absorbing our time t han gender exclusion. With that in mind, the citative(made up word) disparity is entirely fascinating if it really exists. Given there's no easy way to tell gender, this is an issue that should be studied at length. I'd have to see if I thought the stats held up on the citation disparity, but if they do and I decide to do a lit analysis to pad my CV I'll post back with a link to my findings. For now I should probably stop wasting time on youtube and get back to my Linear Algebra homework. Though I think you probably missed the boat here, or at least temporarily squandered an opportunity to seriously explore a valid issue, I do love your work. Please, keep it up my friend.

While this video makes some very valid points (though certainly appears to examine them through a pretty one sided lens), it closes with a pretty awful strawman. It strongly implies that those people that are annoyed by SWJ's are actually threatened rather than annoyed. Not only does it couch this as a neutral ("ask yourself which you feel) while making a thinly veiled accusation ("you're probably threatened"), it also means that your fallback position ("I'm not threatened") is one of a trivial emotion ("annoyance"). It's a classic debate strategy cleverly (or, hopefully, unintentionally?) used as a closing argument to the video. People can defend a scientist who they feel is wrongfully maligned for reasons other than annoyance at his accuser. The lack of civil debate that occurred (yes, on both sides of the issue) is the real argument that most people have against SJWs right now. Frequently, those people on the side of SJWs (and I realize I'm painting with a broad brush stroke here... my goal is not to equate all SJWs... it's convenient short hand here) want to create binary situations (he's either for us or against us) out of grey situations. They want to stifle commentary. They do this either by shouting louder or, in Mike's case (and I say this as an avid subscriber to Idea Channel), use lengthy sentences and big words to sound objective and academic while displaying a veneer of elucidation when persuasion is their actual intent. I like intelligent discussion. I like coming at these things with an open mind. It's been 2 years since this event (debacle?) and I think we can all agree that the number of women harmed by this man's shirt was probably small. The amount of change that has been made in a predominantly masculine industry has been minute at best. And the amount of reasonable discourse that has actually been made here has been slim to none. Getting outraged (triggered?) at these things doesn't advance the cause. It sets it back. Over and over and over again. There are people that want these things to change but they don't want to do it by torching the whole system or by demonizing those individuals who succeeded within the system they grew up in. Lastly, PLEASE, read some broadly sourced academic literature on pay disparity. There is sooooo much more going on then I think you realize. Pay disparity has many, many factors and some of them deserve a very different discussion. Currently, recent female graduates actually out earn men. Given the historical bias in favor of men, this is pretty surprising. How much pay disparity is due to job steering? How much due to education steering? How much due to different priorities and what portion of those priorities are biological vs. sociological? How much should society work to subsidize the biological end of those equations given the (in this at least) competing goals of fairness and procreation? These are all difficult questions that do not have clean moral answers. The involve competing interests with valid arguments on both sides. Demonizing the other side and just saying that they're wrong and should go "fuck off" does no good when the goal is to find a solution that everyone can live with. I know this video is two years old. I know this was a lot of writing. Hopefully you still read these and glean something from this.

replies.commentText: I think Evan is circling a valid point but I agree more with this. Yes, sexism is very real and I think normalized mysoginist archetypes can often do harm to women who wish to pursue historically non-traditional careers. But if a shirt displays imagery that supports stereotypical or sexualized portrayals of women, is that shirt actually part of the reason for the wage gap and gender bias in STEM? I think Evan went really soft on the people engaging in character assassinations. You might consider a guy's fashion sense to be in bad taste because of that, but it's a whole other leap to say the images conveyed on it confirm sexist intent or that "even if it's unintentional it still does harm". Does it? Really? That thing specifically is doing the harm? Just because something is associated with the greater harm by implication, that doesn't mean the thing is directly contributing to it. Whether it is should depend on portrayal and context. It would be one thing if he actually expressed sexist ideas verbally to support such conclusions but he didn't. I feel like a lot of progressives (and I generally consider myself one) tend to unfairly prioritize breadth over depth of harm. In this case it's all women versus one man. An unintentional slight should not excuse rabid personal attacks, even if that slight may contribute to a larger problem. Implicit association with a greater harm does not make something more harmful than the character assassination of one man. Shirts like that may be a symptom of sexist society, but they are not the cause o f sexism. Attacking someone for it do es nothing but make people feel victimized. Not because of the fact that "oh no I like this shirt, that's annoying" but because the social policing is so strict and unforgiving, that it puts them in that position by default. Going about it so aggressively gi ves zero room for a person to learn/change and makes it far less likely for people to take the overall issu e of sexism seriously. That feeling of digging into someone and ripping them apart while self-righteously waving the banner of social justice is far more pleasurable than whatever that guy got out of wearing a shirt.

commentThread.commentText: As a practicing anthropologist and a female, I don't feel that your point about sexism being a sort of unquestioned cultural norm in STEM fields is entirely accurate. Let's be honest, the reason MOST people don't enter STEM fields is because they are extremely difficult and require a lot of hard work and dedication. That is a big reason why these jobs pay so much money. Aside from those with a truly undying passion for their job, a large incentive for having a STEM job is the financial security. In my perspective, it seems that males in our culture have far greater expectations to provide financial security than females. This makes it so that females don't feel as pressured to choose jobs in these more difficult fields. Now, one could argue that the expectation of women to depend and men to provide is "sexist", but that's an entirely different arguemnt than "men prevent women from getting engineering degrees because they hate when women have more power than them". It seems your point in and of itself is also a cultural assumption.

replies.commentText: he's not making the argument that men actively prevent women from going into stem at all (though I guess that could be happened somewhere? either way it's irrelevant) He's saying that one reason there are less women in stem is that because of cultural messaging towards young women and that women *themselves* choose not to go into stem because either they feel inadequate or that stem careers are not for people like them because of the lack of support for women in stem (maybe from early childhood teachers who dont recommend stem as careers for them or are not able to recognize their talent in stem), not seeing other women in the field and the sort of boys club type feel that can permeate some departments. alex What is the reality of your experience?

I have a job I love now but when I first started working there was a lot of resentment directed at myself and the other woman who started out on the same level as me. It was hard to put my finger on at first but a lot of the guys going into the sciences don't have much experience working with women and have an anxiety that if women are getting good positions or moving up in the field then there is less success or opportunities available to them. There is also the issue that some men tend to see all women as potential sexual partners instead of just colleagues and are angry when they have to keep relationships professional. And then there are some that are just plai n old misogynistic and think women should stay out of the workplace. That last one is the most uncommon- most guys seem to just feel a general dislike to having to work with women. Also, there tends to be this idea that older men are more hostile to women in STEM than millennial men but it's actually the opposite. Younger guys are a lot less likely to work on a project with a female colleague, whether it's doing research or just writing a paper. I remember one man that even turned down a grant because the team would have included a woman we both worked with. To sum it up- I've never been sexually harassed (although I know it does happen) but for a lot of women, I think it's hard for them to feel excluded in a workplace that otherwise works as a team and to deal with the passive-aggressive resentment that is common with young men these days.

People (including some further down this feed) try to end discussions by declaring that women today are experiencing greater equality than in the past or by demanding to be shown an example of a right that men have that women don't. It's not productive to stop the discussion once we reach the end of easily quantifiable things like "can women vote." The discussion is more nuanced now than it was 100 years ago, because the problems that face today's women can't necessarily be fixed by introducing legislation. That doesn't mean they don't exist. It's also more difficult to quantify today's inequalities because not all women respond to the same issues in the same way, and not all men perpetuate these problems (and men are, obviously, not the sole perpetuators of harm or stereotype against women). Asks like "Let us vote" has been replaced with asks like "Don't objectify us," which are harder to explain and don't change as visibly, since they're not binary. Something as innocuous as this shirt presents a problems for not all, but a good number of women who are treated poorly in the workplace by not all, but SOME men, and wearing such a thing in an academic or professional setting makes those women remember the current state of things: that they are generally less well-regarded in STEM (I was a software engineer at Google when the Damore manifesto leaked; that didn't feel awesome), and that their gender faces a greater likelihood of experiencing sexual violence at the hand of SOME, NOT ALL men who are influenced IN PART by media that portrays women as status symbols valued for their aesthetics to be "worn" by men.

This video completely flies in the face of one of the insights from the more recent video about Louis CK: effects matter, yes, but intent also matters. He did not wear the shirt to assert sexual dominance. He didn't even pick the shirt himself. The shirt was a gift by a woman. You can argue whether it was appropriate to wear the shirt in such a public context and you can try to find out whether the colleagues (and potential colleagues) generally find this appropriate for their workplace when it's not on TV -- but you can't blame him personally for being "sexist". You point out that being sexist/racist/whatever is pleasurable, but so is being morally outraged. And outrage culture is exactly that: a hedonistic outlet that allows us to righteously harass and denigrate people in a way that would be wholly unacceptable if they hadn't been declared as valid targets for violating social norms. The people "calling him out" were harassing him in a way that's socially acceptable -- this is where the slur "crybullies" comes from: harassment being justified by either portraying yourself as the victim ("so how dare you question my behaviour") or speaking on behalf of the supposed victims (whether they actually exist or not). The employment gaps are interesting, yes, and they may be the result of social norms that make certain people feel unwelcome in certain fields, but mob justice is never acceptable and psychological violence is still a form of violence (and can be far more traumatising than mere physical violence). This poor human was harassed to tears over a shirt that would have been perfectly acceptable in other contexts. It was never about him or the shirt, they only served as a proxy for the "patriarchy" or "misogynists" or whatever -- a confused mess of actual network effects negatively affecting women and the various individual abuses by men throughout society. They saw a guy who fit their bill for a sexist scapegoat and they tore him to shreds with complete disregard for his actual person.

The answer to the Question at the end: Annoyed. I believe women should get equal pay and absolutely think there should be more women in the stem fields; however, I'm not pleased with the way the feminist movement is going about trying to make that change happen. Constant complaining and less action. If you want a change in legislation, devote your life to it and become a politician so you can effect that change, I know some women have done that already but not enough, when you're best option for a president is Hillary Clinton you know you don't have a lot of options (not trying to get into a political debate about the election, but I think most people if they had their first pick of who would represent women as a president would probably have someone else in mind). My point is there's a lot of talking, a lot of being offended, a lot of complaining, but not a lot of action. Secondly, I feel that the feminist movement has actually deepened the rift between genders (in recent years) more than actually helping. When people are constantly comparing the two genders instead of accepting their differences, saying that equal has to mean the same, it just forces us farther apart. I don't like the idea that women and men are the same, I think we're different and I think that's beautiful. For instance, I think women are better stay-at-home parents then men, not that the women are incapable of going in to various carriers but that statistically men make worse stay-at-home parents. Men (usually) as good as nurturing and comforting, I'm not arguing whether that is is because of conditioning or biology; regardless the fact remains that they aren't as good at it. I definitely don't want a future where children are sent to nurseries and raised by hired babysitters, I find this selfish on the parents side and think this is detrimental to future generations. Although that is besides the point, it's meant to be an example of what I'm trying to say which is that equal doesn't have to mean the same, this is perhaps my biggest problem with the feminist movement. Lastly, the "man-haters". I know quite a few feminists who try to be social justice warriors but the more I hear them talk the more I realize they never have anything good to say about any man. I know this one girl who I heard complaining (rightly so) about a man being sexist and misogynistic, then just the next week heard her complaining about a man who was trying to defend feminist ideals saying "he couldn't understand our problems so he has no right to talk about them, he's never been in our shoes". So we can't be misogynistic and we can't be feminists, what are we supposed to do? I realize that not all feminists are like this but there is definitely a good sized group of feminists that hold this disposition. I suppose I'd like to draw a line between what feminism and what I'm going to call hyper-feminism. If you define feminism as wanting equal rights, pay, and respect towards women then count me in, I'm absolutely a feminist, but if you take it a step farther to what I believe it has become, then count me out. And in addition to counting me out please leave me alone, stop twisting my words to things they were not intended to say with your extreme political correctness, let me speak my mind in my own way - I promise I don't have any hatred or superiority in my heart towards women and I don't see gender as a competition. If you're offended by everybody then maybe you should tone down what offends you, maybe I'm not the problem, maybe you're just easily offended. So to recap: not threatened, just annoyed, please leave me alone!

commentThread.commentText: 1. Cultural norms are hardly invisible. I can see perfectly the norms you are following when you argue in this video and the way it helps you to think/feel about yourself. Now why, instead of just denying sexual dimorphism, don't you think about ways to prove or disprove what hypothesis better maps reality. Is it that women are not that much into hard sciences or that there's a bias or discrimination against them? You mention one idea you don't like, and pass judgement on it as (maybe) people just following an invisible bias. But what if it was true that women statistically don't like that much the STEM field, what would that imply? Should we close the sciences to women? Well of course not. It speaks about what's generally the case. But there's where the individuals come in. You can have an incredible female physicist or mathematician that stands out among everyone else in their field, and there should be room for her too. But trying to unnaturally balance the score is wrong and painful for both sexes, and as with your video on dragons, it has a negative impact on the results and overall progress of our civilization. 2. Then you state that it's pleasurable to assert your dominance, there are contexts for that too. I mean, if I'm playing chess, I like to win, and I get pleasure from winning, yeah. But there are other situations where I would despise myself if I was trying to assert dominance. With my family for instance, I try to please my wife and I try to get my kids to learn skills that will make them (hopefully) better than I am, you can see that I'm hardly trying to dominate them. Or at work, I team up with some other people to get things done, and since the goal is to get things done, it's really easy to work as a team. And it's unnecesary to say that with my family or my team at work I also get pleasure. If asserting your dominance is such a driving force, then the ultimate achievement would be to dominate yourself, and we would all arrive to that conclusion. Whereas mocking someone's physical characteristics, preferences or ideas is not asserting dominance. Despising is not subdoing. Rejecting is not controlling. So no. In my case the annoyance has nothing to do with fear or loss of pleasure, but with detecting bias and willful ignorance: you don't say here are the two (or more) explanations for the numbers given by the statistics, you dismiss the explanation you don't like and keep on the one you do as if it was the truth. Yep, my annoyance is about the lack of rigour on feminist/sjw arguments, and how they try to dress them as the truth.

I don't think it's the shirt that is the issue. The shirt is representational and invites the topic that women feel discouraged from entering STEM fields because of objectification/sexualization. From a young age women are heavily criticized in regards to appearance (this statement is oversimplified, I can explain if anyone wants me to) but this criticizing heavily impacts self-esteem. These issues with self esteem and the pressures of looking a very specific way effect the confidence (and interest) of women joining STEM fields. In regards to the interest of joining STEM fields, If you look at commercials for children's shows (for ex.) you'll notice specific marketing for "boy" and "girl" toys (girls have makeup, baking, beauty related toys while boys have super heros, guns, robotics and remote controlled cars). Even in womens fashion you'll notice it's fast paced and complicated compared to mens fashion. That may even relate to how markets prefer having a target group of customers who want the same thing rather than a bunch of individuals with varied interests. I guess in saying this I'm trying to illustrate how sexism is not as simple as a tee-shirt. The tee-shirt reminds us of an underlying societal issue. People want to speak out because it makes them uncomfortable. Please don't take my word as solid fact, I'm no statistical genius but this issue personally effects me (and many others) as a woman in STEM.

commentThread.commentText: the movement doesn't even seem to have a single position on this. half of them hate the porn industry for objectifying women, the other half are like "Fuck off, women should do what they want with their bodies, including sell them." half are like "you go girl, sleep with as many guys as you want. Yay sex workers, yay all female body types." the others are like, "Damn those dirty men for feasting their piggy little eyes on naked women! Think of the children and the stereotypes!!" as an outsider i'm at a loss. how do you get to a society where women are sexually autonomous, while also keeping their sexuality under wraps where it cant be exploited by media and consumers? i dont think it's possible. we are sexual beings, programmed to objectify each others' bodies, and evidently those urges are much stronger in men than women. i dont see how we'll ever get away from that short of 1984-lik e sexual reprogramming. i guess the conclusion i'm reaching is not that the guy's shirt was a problem. the shirt in itself hurts no one except those prone to victimizing themselves. the problem is not male consumption of female sexuality. that has always happened and will always happen so long as society remains free, as will the reverse. so what are we worried about? women being driven away from STEM by the perception that it is an old boys club? it certainly doesn't affect women in school, who perform as well as if not better than men all the way through university now. in my own graduate office there are easily more women than men. perhaps that is the exception, but taking a look around my building i think not, although i am in the biological sciences and not math or physics. no, women leave STEM AFTER their graduate studies. the reason why is pretty self-evident. the post-graduate years are the end of prime baby-making time. STEM are generally highly competitive fields. employers want people they can trust to be productive virtually all the time. building a research program in academia requires a relatively constant stream of publications, new projects, new students, etc. women consistently state throughout their teenage and college years that they prefer more work-life balance than men do. raising a family rather than being wedded to a career. perhaps there are a handful of women who genuinely get snubbed for funding, professorships, etc. for no reason other than suspicion of future baby-making, when in reality they are as single-minded in their career pursuit as any man, but i find it hard to believe that is any kind of epidemic. and again, even if it were an epidemic, the issues would be well removed from a sexy shirt and would not even come close to justifying the disgusting character assassination on what would otherwise probably have been the proudest moment of that man's life. here's a final thought: maybe those images dont exploit female sexuality, they exploit male sexuality.

Okay, I can sort of see where you're coming from with all this, but, to be honest, I don't agree with most of what you said. To address the first paragraph: just because different people in a movement have different opinions on things and on the best course of action for resolving what they see as a problem does not mean that the whole movement is thus worthless and should not be taken seriously. For example, just because Martin Luther King Jr and Malcolm X had differing stands on what actions should be taken during the civil rights movement does not mean that racism and discrimination were (are) not issues. It just means that they were complicated issues that had no clear solution. The same is true of feminism in the modern era. In response to your second paragraph and the implication that women are less successful in a demanding field because of the fact that they are the gender who can get pregnant, well... I mean, I won't say that's not what causes the lack of women in STEM jobs. I don't really know if it is the case or not. What I will say is, even if women are losing out on STEM jobs just because of their "baby-making" tendencies, it doesn't mean that that's not still a discriminatory practice. Last I checked, it takes two to make a baby. Just because th e woman happens to carry the baby around with her for nine months does not mean that she is the one solely responsible for its care. Men and women can both want children, or they can both want to not have children. It's not a purely female thing to want to be a parent. Just because we've grown up in a culture that socialized us to believe that women should be the primary care-givers to children and men should primarily focus on their careers does not mean that that is an appropriate or non-discriminatory belief. In fact, it's quite reminiscent of the "separate spheres" ideology of the 50s which said that a woman's place was in the home, behind the oven, and I think we've all moved past that kind of thinking. There is no reason to expect that just because a person wants to have children, they should not also be allowed to have a career. There is no reason to believe that a man who wants children should be able to do so without devoting any of the time previously ascribed to working to taking care of his new child, while it is assumed th at a woman will do so. The assumption that beca use a woman wants a family she should not also be able to have a career she enjoys, while refusing to apply the same logic to a man is, in itself, unfair and unequal, and harmful to women. What you're saying is that a woman must choose between having children and having a career, while a man can have both without making the same sacrifice. I don't blame you for thinking this way, as you were socialized to do so, but that doesn't make it okay. That's basically all. Reply if you want to, I would love to hear some other perspectives.
