replies.commentText: It's not just the shirt. The shirt reinforces stereotypes about how STEM fields are "just for boys", and those stereotypes are what's keeping girls from entering the fields they are passionate about.

Hans Peter Rørholt Vigerust 

If some unspoken stereotype, whose only manifestation in reality is a cartoon shirt, keeps you from entering the STEM fields, you didn't really want to be there to begin with.

@Hans Peter Rørholt Vigerust It sounds like it is just the shirt. i don't know how that shirt could perpetuate any stereotypes at all. It's just a bunch of scantily-clad women. How does that say "sorry girls, science isn't for you"?

I agree that if a shirt on the internet turns you off to a career path, perhaps that field is not for you. Historically, though, "feminine" skills have been rewarded less than "masculine" in terms of power and prestige. The result is a ladder of hierarchical segregation with fewer and fewer women near the top. I'm not saying the shirt is responsible for this alone, but it sends a message to girls that can be interpreted to say that females are objects of desire, not of intellect. The reason many girls don't like science may be because they've been discouraged from the start, by being "told" that they won't fit in in such a "masculine" working place.

Hans Peter Rørholt Vigerust I think you make a mistake in speaking of this societal phenomena as if it were consciously guided. Yes, manual labor jobs have traditionally been of greater necessity, and consequentially, conferred more status onto their doers; usually men. However, only in the past thirty years we've seen a switch to what many would call an 'information economy', where intellect is awarded over physicality, and we're seeing women climb the career ladder just fine in this new environment. That is all to say, the hierarchies that naturally form in societies have not been informed by sexism in the substrata of culture. They were born of practical necessity.

I'm still not really seeing it. If I were entering a traditionally female profession and my boss went around wearing a shirt with half-naked guys all over it, I wouldn't think that she sees men as objects for her consumption. I'd just assume that she likes hot men, like most women do.

Believe me, I'm as big an advocate as anybody for encouraging women to enter STEM and other male-dominated fields. But I just don't see this shirt as being part of the problem.

Ash Tree Your emotional appeal is nothing but that. That's not the average experience of a working woman in the United States. And for an y woman who faces instances of discrimination in the workplace we have a system of jurisprudence in place, through which they can seek redress. It's not a perfect system, but only when you compare it to some fictionalized utopia in your head can it be called bad. Our social institutions, and attitudes towards women, are top notch on a global scale.

Ash Tree 

It's interesting that you think someone's ability to understand other people's lives is dependent on which genitalia they were born with. 

You should stop being so sexist.

Ash Tree Yes, different people have different experiences--including different women. I never claimed yourself, or women who share your experience, don't exist. In fact, I preemptively addressed that in my original response to you, when I mentioned our system of jurisprudence. However, your experience as a woman is not representative of every other woman's experience. You do not get to declare yourself the spokesperson for all women just because you have a vagina and a sad story. When dealing with a large group of people, the only way to make accurate statements about their shared experience is through statistical observations. And the statistics tell us that experiences like the one you describe, thankfully, are the exception, not the rule.

+Tom Cotter No, but your ability to understand and rule as an arbiter on experiences (such as street harassment) which are race or gender specific is greatly diminished because no matter your understanding, it's entirely theoretical in comparison to a group who have lived it. Same as abortion. I'm not going to try and proclaim something about an isolated village in a foreign country's culture if I've never been there, or don't speak the language, or let someone take my advice betting their life's savings on a rugby match if I've never watched a game in my life. I'm not going to lecture a physicist or a surgeon about things I'm not informed about. You can have an understanding of what life's like for different people, it's when you make the mistake of demanding your theoretical understanding be prioritised over theirs that you encounter serious issues. Like insisting you should be the one to do a job someone else in the room is better informed and qualified to do because you've read the Wikipedia page and maybe a book on it. And yeah, not all women represent all women, duh. So the conversation should be largely driven by women. You're off the hook, judgement regarding a type of life experience you'll literally never have is unasked for and unnecessary. At it's most basic, men will never have the same experience of culture and societally bred discrimination (if they're straight and caucasian anyway, #buzzword but it's true, no simpler way to phrase it don't get offended) (I'm also both straight, male, and caucasian fyi) that would inform an opinion about that shirt. YEAH FUCKING DUH men aren't offended by shirts of really beefy guys with abs, or feel insecure about it, because there's no cultural structure of sexualisation that dehumanises men, leads to absurdly disproportionat e sexual assault and rape statistics (the most significant factor), and affects their lives and career opportunities. And if you're offended by the implication that you might not know everything there is to know about someone else's lived experience, ask yourself (not me) why you assume you don't have more to learn on the subject, or why it's such a 'sexist' injustice to imply that people have different experiences and there are certain ones you'll never have the authority to speak to. Why does that aggravate you? Once again, I really doubt you'd be offended by someone asking an astrophysicist to work at NASA or someone with a law degree to defend them in court over you, because you'd say "oh sorry, I don't really have the qualifications to provide a contribution compared to the other alternative options you could ask in this context. I might have a vague understanding but there's still vastly better alternatives available".

RainMinded This response is structured to address each section of your comment in chronological order: The thrust of your first point is that firsthand experience, as opposed to an abstract understanding, a priori, makes someone's opinions on a matter more valuable/true--correct? There are several problems with this line of reasoning. First is that there are only a few experiences in this world which are truly limited to a certain group of people, say child birth or getting kicked really hard in the nuts--each experience the exclusive province of people who have vaginas or testicles. Yet even these experiences fall under the broader umbrella of "Pain." If you ask someone: "How did it feel to get kicked in the nuts?" and they respond... "It was painful." You will be able to understand their experiential state of being, based on your own previous experiences with the sensation known as pain. In fact, this is why we wince when we see people get hurt. Our brains have what are called mirror-neurons, which read the emotional state of other creatures based on physical cues and activate similar brain patterns in our own minds. In other words, you literally feel vicariously through other people. Secondly, knowledge can exist without experience. Take your "isolated village" for example. Let's say you happened upon this village and found that they had a religious doctrine which demanded that every brunette female, upon her eighteenth birthday, be raped by the entire village, skinned from her waist down, and then roasted alive over an open flame to become a sacrificial feast to the gods. Tell me, do you need to conduct an in depth ethnographic study to understand the experience of these girls? Let's take another of your examples that's less extreme: You wouldn't lecture a surgeon on something you aren't informed about (his job I assume). Wise choice. But tell me, does a doctor need to have cancer to treat people with cancer? No. They have medical training. But where did that medical training come from? Did they learn how to treat cancer by surviving cancer? No. They learned about cancer from a completely ABSTRACT body of knowledge, which was created by conducting empirical studies on people who do have cancer. So you see, we agree. You say we should listen to experts, but the experts are using the exact same methods to reach their conclusions as I am--statistical data. You can have all the first hand experience in the world, it only makes you an expert on yourself. To determine the veracity of a claim about anymore than one person you necessarily have to use statistics. ------------------------------------------------------ Okay, your second point. It seems to be something along the lines of "issues that affect women should be decided by women because only women can understand them." This is not only sexist as all fuck, but it also defies basic common-sense and contradicts your previous point. One, it implies that there are "things that can only be understood by women." If we accept this premise we would necessarily also have to accept that there are ideas which can only be understood by other groups of people such as men, or asians, or gay >people. If we go down that road, then the door opens for the case to be made that some groups have 'better brains' than each other, or are biologically superior, since they can understand certain ideas that other groups can't. If this were true--as you suggest it is--it would validate every argument ever made by Social Darwinists, who sought to subjugate people of different colors on the basis that their skin color reduced thei r mental capacity and therefore made them sub-human. Next, your contradiction. In your previous point you suggested that we listen to the people who have extensive knowledge about a topic to form our conclusions--I agree. So why would the conversation be "largely driven by women?" The criteria to be a woman is simply that you were born that way by chance. It doesn't make you an expert on all women. Take for instance women's health. You said before that we should rely on surgeons (or doctors) for medical advice, which I agree with, because their title implies that they have actually gone out of their way to educate themselves on a certain subject. So tell me, which group would you say knows more about women's reproductive health: A group of world renowned gynecologists, who happen to all be men, or a group of women who work various retail jobs? If you want to remain consistent with your previous point it is the former. Finally, how, if we can't understand people's experiences without living them, can you make all those claims about women's oppression? Women don't know what it's like to live as men--they've never done it--how do they know it's any easier? It could be far worse for all they know. You're a man, but you've never be en a woman. How can you compare? I know, I know. You've got facts and statistics, but I thought you said we couldn't understand experience through abstract measures such as those? So which one is it? Are statistics a valid method of determining the average experience or not? And if they are in your case, why aren't they in my case? --------------------------------------------------------------------- It doesn't bother me that I'll never experience something EXACTLY the same as someone else does--they won't ever know my exact experiences either. But what does aggravate me is this notion that we should just shut up and believe extraordinary claims people make because they've experienced some hardship, when there is ample evidence to the contrary. It's perfectly fine if someone wants to say... "That movie made me sad." I could point to the fact that they were laughing, and smiling, and looked pretty happy while they watched it. But at the end of the day I don't have a Sad-O-Meter to measure their emotions, so I just have to trust their self-reporting of the experience. However, it's something entirely different when someone says... "I experienced X, therefore, EVERYONE who happens to have the same genitals as me also experiences X," even though there is evidence which clearly demonstrates that that is not true. And it's especially egregious to make claims on behalf of other people like that when there are millions of people who fit the criteria and say..." No, that's not been my experience." Using one persons subjective experience is the exact opposite of what scientists at NASA do. The entire point of Science is to get past our own subjective experiences, because we know they're always biased, and extract some objective-truth about the reality outside of ourselves. The point is, when you make a claim outside of yourself, you need to back it up with evidence outside of your own experiences.

That joke at the bar of how women can't stop nagging, that small sexist joke you toss at a colleague. These things don't seem to have an effect at all on our everyday lives because they've been thoroughly normalized and incorporated into our habits, our passive actions. I really love this man, and I think he provides immense incite into difficult issues, even if I don't always agree with him. I wish to note, though, there was an interesting dichotomy he brought up at 2:00. That is: a central focus of the feminist movement is to condemn the depiction of female sexuality as a commodity. In this, there can be no doubt, they are in the right. The manner in which media and the public at large has been conditioned to view the human body, particularly a woman's body is deplorable, to perpetuates objectification and projects a cultural expectation that can limit a person's development. However, I recently had a discussion with a friend who said she wasn't offended by such images in and of themselves because a person, regardless of gender, should be allowed to express their sexuality as they see fit. That is, if someone wants to flaunt the fact that they are a sexual being, to display that to a wider audience (Kardashian), they have a full right to do so. What I am concerned about is that while I suppose this is true, each person has a right to express themselves however they please, I think that as a culture we should limit it. There's a sociological theory called 'trading power for patronage' which applies in this case. Minorities, in this case women who get paid to be part of ads that objectify women as a group, are trading their and the group's power to overcome discrimination for the chance to personally profit off their own exploitation. Rappers, strippers, there are lots of groups that this happens for. They get paid to perpetuate their groups continued discrimination. Everyone has the freedom of choice to participate in their own disenfranchisement, but that doesn't really make it effective.

Cultivation theory says that such shirts can skew the perception of reality of people that scientists generally like wearing such shirts, even as it is not true. Moreover, cultivation theory says that if feminists repeat enough times that scientists are sexist, and mass media gives them enough exposure, women will really start believing that scientists are sexist, even as it is not true. This most surely can dissuade some women from entering a STEM field. See, cultivation theory makes the most sense when speaking about the tv audience that spends 7 days a week in front of it - in other words, it needs continued and regular exposure to a single source in order to be able to change the perception of reality of the subject. commentThread.commentText: A better question to ask yourself in situations like these is "Would I be okay with the opposite version of this?" ie. "If the gender-roles were reversed, would I accept this?". After all justice is fairness - and through seeing the situation through the eyes of the potentially worst off in the scenario, helps see the balance clearly. So, if we apply this to the shirt situation: Would it be okay if a woman wore a shirt/dress decorated with unrealistically Adonis-like bodies wearing nothing but speedos? I think it would be acceptable. Looking at it this way, the most reasonable objection seems not to be about unfair body-images* but about prudence: It might make someone flustered to be forced to witness what would be considered pornography a 100 years ago. And that hardly seems like a pressing matter. * Dealing with bad self esteem is ultimately a personal endeavor, and it can be affected by a million things differing from person to person. A society with a global media can never fully accommodate every psychological sensitivity, since some such accommodations are mutually exclusive.

If a huge group of people starts using things like these as their "outlet", it is annoying because you know how misguided and silly that is. Terrible example I know, as it's thankfully ridiculous to compare the severity of those "problems" and the percentage of population affected and misguided by them, but at the core I'd say it's the same phenomenon.

I feel a need to point out why your opinion really does not matter in this context. You are not stating scientific facts, not stating facts backed by empirical evidence - instead, you base your opinion on personal experience, which is far from an objective perspective of the world. Your knowledge of why your boss is not very good at her job, or your knowledge and understanding of women overall, is subjective and biased, and is definitaly not an average. People need to stop making claims, which they justify to other, but themselves as well, as opinions that they are entitled to. That is simply not true. Opinion does not belong in a discussion of such an objective manner, like the thought processes of females.

You just relayed an anecdote. Anecdotal evidence can be very powerful to the person observing it, because it presents itself more often and more clearly when it correlates to your preconceived notions, no matter how subtle those notions may be. I could give you 100 anecdotes from my personal life that easily refute yours. It wouldn't prove much. Issues regarding gender and intelligence, emotional inclinations, &/or mental performance are far too complex to be summed up in a single paragraph. Volumes upon volumes would be needed to fully understand such a topic, because it's nearly impossible to find the root (actual) causes of you r gender-based observations. Here's one now!! I was a cheerleader through elementary/junior/high school. No one ever pushed me toward math or science in any way because it was just assumed that I was a blonde, ditzy cheerleader. But, as a freshman, I decided to get a head start on school the summer before, and picked up my geometry book for a self guided lesson. I wanted to give myself a little jump on things since I often had little time for studying with all the cheer practice & games we attended. I finished the geometry book in a few days....on my own. I checked out an algebra book from the library - giddy with the excitement that comes from learning. Finished it in 2 weeks. Moved on to advanced algebra & on and on. My sophomore year, I placed 1st out of my entire school of 3000+ kids in math, across the board, and was placed on our school's academic team. Finished 6th in our state that year. And yet not a single teacher, parent, or counselor EVER SUGGESTED I CONSIDER A CAREER IN MATH. People thought it was cool that a cheerleader literally WAS the math team for our school. But, they treated it like it was "cute". In fact, NO ONE EVER MENTIONED COLLEGE TO ME AT ALL. I ended up being accepted to UCLA 3 years after graduating high school, because a good friend saw me waitressing and said "what in the hell are you doing? Your'e going to college. Apply immediately." My point is, women deal with treatment throughout their lives that you will never grasp - and that they themselves have a hard time coming to terms with. My little story probably didn't clarify the issue for you in the slightest, but I hope that it helped you see the difference between INTRINSIC personality traits, & things that have been learned from a world that undervalues our work, minds, opinions & accomplishments.

The phrase of the day is "Confirmation Bias", and it explains most of why humans are very bad at generalizing. So, OP having a dumb lady for a boss no more shows that women are less rational than Brandin's experience shows there is a society-wide pressure for women to not go into STEM fields. (Although she acknowledges that somewhat) We should only rely on society-wide evidence when making society-wide generalizations.

Feminism had a place, and still does to some small extent, however instead of focusing on what divides us why not focus on what joins us, what we have in common, what our passions are. To some extent the 90's did this, being "co lor blind" was a virtue, treating other people not by what they looked like but by how they acted was encouraged. replies.commentText: HoboNinja: This isn't about the people who are determined to go into STEM. Nobody who really wants to be a scientist will go "oh no, a distasteful shirt! I'm switching careers!". This is about the people who don't know what career they want or are still choosing or are on the fence. They are the people who will see the sexism in the industry and think "nah, not worth it" and choose something else they'd equally like to do. Over millions of people, this turns into a trend which results in fewer women in STEM. As a thought experiment, imagine you have two rooms that people could choose between. The participants have to sit in the room alone for an hour. One of the rooms has a painting of a landscape, the other has a painting of a creepy clown. Although the clown picture can't hurt anyone an d nobody will be 'offended' by it, I guarantee the majority of people will choose the room with the painting of a landscape. My point is, something doesn't have to be overtly or extremely distasteful, it just has to be more distasteful than the alternative for people to avoid it.

@snowsandrivers blackfyrestorm Fair enough. It is indeed hard to wrap your mind around a collectivist definition of sexism or racism when you've grown up with an individualist one. See, if you follow the individualist definition, you expect the judgement of the person himself to be sexist o r racist, and that to show in his actions. For example if a man and a woman apply for a job, are equally qualified for it, and the man gets the job, why did this happen? Pure chance is one possible reason. In such situations half of the time a man would get the job, right? But if you can prove intention, that the employer took the man because they prefer men over women, that's now sexist and punishable by law. On the backdrop of this, the collectivist definition is indeed lost to many. In the collectivist definition the act itself is divorced from the intention of the individual, and is set in the context of the collectives the actors are part of. Going to our example; if the employer is a school trying to hire a teacher, hiring the man is not sexist, because most educators are women. But if the employer is for example an IT company, it is sexist, because most IT employees are male. But if the man i s a bl >ac k> gay muslim, it is not sexist, because hiring the white woman w ould be ra cist and homophobic. You see, the two sides of this debate are actually really close in opinion. Both sides recognize the power of societal conditioning and cultural clues. Why do I say this? Because "our" side argues two things: 1) Our society and our culture have instilled in most of us that being sexist is bad. 2) The cultural authority of what is sexist and what is not is the surprisingly marxist academia in the social sciences. So this authority can exert authoritarian power over the normal person - and, ergo, by virtue of us living in a democracy, it can exert authoritarian power over everybody. There are examples to support this: how Sir Tim Hunt was fired for example. Our society was manipulated, and outrage was fabricated in order to fire a man. Of course, this line of thinking also has its set of examples. Take the War on Drugs: people have decid ed it's not racist*, while it's obvious it mainly targets minorities. But that just goes to show that it's not enough to implement not racist policies, you have to actually implement policies that help the underprivileged classes. What do I mean by that? Identify a pr oblem that many black americans face (segregation into poor neighbourhoods for example), then device a policy to solve this particular problem (targeted programs for improving poor neighbourhoods over the whole country, no matter if t he residents are black, latino, or white).

@erejnion >Does there NEED to be a "white guy shirt"? Because right now feminism is trying its best to create it. Safe spaces, "white male tears" mugs, "basket of deplorables", and so on, and so on. Come on, dude. While I don't think that "white male tears" mugs and the "basket of deplorables" are helping the situations -- you cannot compare slavery, segregation, voter suppression, the eradication of jobs in black inner cities which resulted in the erasure of jobs, which caused the drug trade to replace legitimate economies, resulting in squalor and mass incarceration, of redlining, in women being prevented from voting, from being socialized to be passive dwellers of homes and raisers of children to the detriment of their own agency, etc. etc. This DOES NOT EXIST for straight white men. The comparison is just silly. >Besides, it's not that the white males didn't suffer in the past, it's that the civilization created by them survived, proving to be a better choice of lifestyle than all the rest. It's easy to pinpoint why Western civilization was so successful: it was not because it was mainly brought about by males (after all more than enough females were key to its progress), it was because of its adherence to individualism and liberal values. Tearing down the system that benefits individualism and liberal values is the worst possible outcome. Modifying the system so that it fits like a glove not only white men, but everybody else too, is the reasonable and sustainable goal, which our civilization has worked to achieve the last few centuries. Everything else will just bring ruin. But no one is trying to tear down liberal values. Liberal values have existed in opposition to conservative values for hundreds of years now. Individualism is giving way ever so slightly one step at the time to collectivist values -- but those values have proven to be instrumental to happiness and well-being in regions like Canada, Western Europe and Northern Europe where the quality of life and genera satisfactions of its citizens are considerably higher than that of Americans. The people who are trying to stand in the way of that are conservatives, who actively want to return to a situation in which women are relegated to positions of subservience and black citizen continue to exist in squalor because of a history and a legacy of apartheid in this country. But, let's put this aside. The side that wants to escape from stereotypes, being treated as an object, and so on... isn't that the side that wants to eradicate labels? That wants to treat everybody just as an individual, not as "black" or "white" or "male" or whatever? Because there's an innate irony to want to escape stereotyping, while at the same time supporting identity politics, which is all about labeling yourself with the stereotype that most fits you. ABSOLUTELY NOT. Labels are VERY important. They facilitate communication and understanding about the ways in which human beings are different and experience the world differently. The whole "I don't see color" or "I don't treat you differently because you're a woman" comes from the conservative side. Whereas our side is all about being sensitive to the differences in which we experience the world. I just went to get tacos in my neighborhood. On the way home, in the dark, I walked down the sidewalk an d a woman walking in front of me turned her head to see who was walking behind her. She did that because she's concerned for her safety. She 's a woman. She's physically probably not as strong as most men. She's in a position because of who she is where she has to be concerned about how vulnerable she is. I come from the school of thought where we don't try to pretend that she's exactly the same as me.....she's different...and I should try to accommodate the difference by being sensitive to her experience. So I walk ahead, in front of her so that she knows she's not threatened by me. If we just act like we're all the same then we aren't being deferential to one another's humanity. I'm a black guy. I don't want white people to treat me like a white person. I want people to acknowledge th at I'm black, and that it's possible that my experience is different. Similarly, I confer the same sort of acknowledgement and respect onto people that I know are different from me out of respect. What we want is for all humans, regardless of differences, to be treated with respect and decency and deference to humanity, so that no person by virtue of who they are has to exist at some kind of disadvantage. If you get rid of labels, you're not actually acknowledging the problem.It's like saying "Well, if we just treat different kinds of broken legs the same way we'll have the same results. No. Leg breaks take different forms. We need to acknowledge each kind of break so we can accommodate it accordingly.

Well, if you're prejudging someone because of the label that suits them, that's your problem. I don't do that. What I do is acknowledge the ways in which their experience in the world might be different from mine. That isn't some kind of terrible judgement of character. That's called "empathy."

Socialism is not collectivism. Affirmative Action is collectivism. Universal healthcare is not, because it's... universal. See, as far as you have Rule of Law and human rights, you don't need to bother with collectives, and can just judge everybody on individual basis. Universal healthcare and tuition-free college can be seen as human rights. So, the same way the government is protecting the human right of freedom of movement by managing the road network, universal healthcare is protecting the human right of receiving medical care. The left-right is about the balance between corporations and government, not about the balance of governmental meddling in the lives of the people or about collectivism versus individualism. Socialism versus capitalism is traditionally understood as model of economical involvement of the government. All the rest is just packaging positions inside "democrats" versus "republicans", and the way these positions are packaged differs from country to country.

P.S. If you're "understanding" something about someone based simply on a label, this is some kind of judgement: you're judging that this something is true for that person.

@erejnion >Socialism is not collectivism. 

.....uh....that makes no sense. The point of socialism is that it benefits the most amount of people possible. It prioritizes the entire group of workers or the citizens, rather than the success of the individual. I have no idea how you could possibly consider it otherwise.

Yes. Agreed. 


>Universal healthcare is not, because it's... universal. 

....what? How could something that exists specifically to benefit the most number of people in society not be collectivistic?

lol, but the rule of law and human rights ARE collectivistic. Anything that prioritizes GROUPS of people is collectivistic.

Sure, but judging that something is true for that person doesn't necessarily have to be a value judgement. It also doesn't have to be a iron clad assumption. It could just be a guideline. Rule of Law and the human rights are specifically designed to be individualistic, not collectivist. They don't appeal to somebody as part of any group. The whole point is that you protect these rights, because you want everybody else as an individual to protect yours too. It's about the relationship between two peers, not about the relationship between a person and a group. The point of socialism is to benefit EVERYBODY. Not "the most number of people", but EVERYBODY. Even a billionaire has a vested interest in socialistic policy, because he knows that he may go bankrupt one day.* Socialism is also designed as a way to make individual people succeed. Why? Because the specimens of Homo Sapiens are really risk-averse creatures. The social safety net is designed to eradicate the risk inherent to trying to succeed. Without it, less people would ever try to succeed. Vice versa, capitalism in practice doesn't benefit individuals. It benefits corporations. That's why if you try to implement capitalism without socialistic policies to counter-balance, you quickly devolve into corporatism and oligarchy. And, of course, if you try to implement socialism without capitalism, it quickly devolves into communism, national socialism, feminism, or some other collectivist ideology. Frankly, humanity can't do without collectives just yet. Even though it's proven again and again that the societies that are the most individualistic survive at the end. P.S. Yeah, and some people just have as a "guideline" that blacks are often thieves and murderers. They have black friends, hey! They are not racist! erejnion Okay. The people in question are random mobs on the internet. Actually, I suppose one could say such groups have authority, but if you concede that, you have to concede the same thing about the mobs that have gone after Anita Sarkisian for nothing more than speaking her mind.

The people in question are not random mobs on the internet. It's every major media outlet, as well as "experts" on gender studies, and politicians. The first and the last aside, I'd wager you can see why people with PhD in gender studies are supposed to have more authority on this topic than the random mobs on the internet. Also the random mobs who "have gone after Anita" are people who are trying to prove that she is wrong. Putting the offensive words aside, it's 99% constructive criticism and no actual treats that are verified as not originating from Anita and her clique. Of course, if you have a problem with strong language, well, while you're correct to advice against using such language, I'd like to remind you that it's only normal to react harshly to being belittled and vilified. Sadly, this is part of human nature. I mean, surely you understand why a Mexican may have some rash words to say about Trump? I'd also urge you to note that this is mostly leftist infighting . Nobody cares what the radical Christians and the radical Muslims have to say.

The authority of experts is different than the authority of priests and politicians. Equating them is a fallacy of equivocation. As far as I'm aware, nothing happened to the shirt-gate guy that hasn't happened to Anita. If one is okay, the other is. (Anita has probably received less negative attention from the mainstream media, but those aren't communications directed toward the man, nor would they usually be unjustifiably harsh, so I don't count them.) Saying that "no actual threats have been verified as not being from her or her clique" sets an unreasonable standard. Barring the threat-sender being caught, which hasn't happened and probably never will unless someone goes through with a threat and is arrested, no such verification could possibly occur. There is likewise no threat that has been proven to come from her, nor am I aware of any case of a feminist threatening themselves like that. She has received enough threats that it is unlikely that none of them are authentic. Also, while I suspect the numbers are very, very different than you say, (I'd imagine less than a third of what she receives is criticism, and less than a third of that is constructive), it doesn't matter how much constructive criticism she receives compared to harassment. Imagine someone who received 1,000,000 harassing communications. Consider the level of badness that would have. Now, imagine that they receive 99,000,000 pieces of constructive criticism. Have the 1,000,000 communications lost badness? I don't think so. (The person might see fewer of them, but that doesn't decrease the badness that has been done, just the degree to which it had its intended effect.) I'd like you to show me where Anita has belittled or demonized gamers. Video and time slot, please. If I were unduly charitable, I might say you could accuse her of demonizing the designers of some of the specific games she criticizes, but certainly not all of gamerdom. Don't get me wrong, I understand how you see it that way, but I think if you watch her videos closely and try to interpret them honestly, you'll not be able to come to that conclusion.

Hm. Not that different, though. As long as the country is not ruled by the priest class and there is civilian police and court system, the priests are just authorities on what is good and what is bad, but authorities without legal power. Doesn't make them less authoritative. Same with the experts. This argument may be coming from the fact that I'm not used to the Pope pretty much pulling the strings of everybody throughout history, as my high school education didn't happen in a Catholic country. "There is likewise no threat that has been proven to come from her, nor am I aware of any case of a feminist threatening themselves like that." Some threats were with suspiciously specific language, leaving people to assume they were written by a feminist or an ex-feminist. Same with harassment. Though I'd make a distinction between harassment and the brass chan culture. It's as if a Japanese thinks the American guy who enters his home with his shoes on is harassing him. It's not harassment, it's cultural differences. Sometimes people should just ignore the pointless rude words and try to get the message, the way every anon acts in every chan. In my opinion harassment should also be systematic and devoid of actual meaning, besides containing insults. Oh, but that's not the question, is it? It's not about what the author wanted to say. She said what she wanted to say. It's about what messages the audience sees in the work. If I want to be 100% charitable to Anita... I'd still have plenty of problems with her, but we're speaking about the reaction she receives, which is not connected with 100% charitable reading of her videos. Besides the media did try to declare that "the gamer identity is dead". Which is the very definition of demonizing gamers.

You're correct, the world was non-sexist way before women had the right to vote. People have this misconception that women were treated like shit through out history and that women were oppressed left right and center. But that's not strictly true, there are many cases through out history of women voting and women owning property, even as far back as the ancient Egyptians. In fourth century ancient Greece, over two-fifths of the land in Sparta was owned by women. In the fifteen hundreds, there were many female aristocrats who owned property and were able to vote. Same with eighteen hundreds and also in the nineteen hundreds too. In America many men weren't allowed to vote either, only property owners (that includes women) were allowed to vote. As far as I seen it, only the rich and powerful, no matter what gender, were allowed to vote back in the day and the poor were not, it had nothing to do wit h sexism. no it was a policy, girls here, boys there, not the teacher's choice (maybe you'll find it less hard to believe when I tell you I'm Polish). It's not objectification in and of itself (although I think a lot of people–wrongly, in my opinion–see it that way). It's objectification in the absence of anything else that's a problem. We all objectify people when we exhibit attraction. They literally become the "objects" of our attraction. It's harmful only when your objectified perception of someone becomes the defining factor of your perception of them as a whole. When I see a coworker who I find attractive, part of me is going, "that's a thing I want to have sex with." If I stop there, it's harmful. But if I also consider that my coworker is not defined by my sexual attraction to her in any way, that she has skills and feelings and a moral disposition, then it's not so bad. She does not exist to be attractive to me, I have no claim to her because I am attracted to her and she is vastly more than just something I want to get into bed with, even if that is something I want on some level. Applying that to the bus driver, he's not defined by his role as a bus driver, that's just his job. Models, on the other hand, are almost entirely defined by their roles. They literally make a living out of being looked at as the objects of people' s sexual desires. It transcends a workplace and on a very large scale, they're basically thought of as being important solely for the reason of being attractive. I'm not arguing models should go away, but the objectification of a model is nothing like the feelings most people have toward bus drivers. The reason it's damaging to women in general is because it perpetuates an idea that women in general are only valid as objects of sexual desire. Ultimately the harmful nature of pu rely sexual objectification comes down to where you rank your sexual attraction to someone in the list of reasons that validate their importance as humans. If you see it as a defining characteristic of a person, you're doing them a disservice and shortchanging them. If you know that they bring more to the table than giving you a boner, then it's not really a problem. You're allowed to find people hot, you're allowed to pu rsue a sexual relationship with them (within reason), just make sure you thoroughly understand that people you're attracted to are people too.

replies.commentText:
Nope. But many repeated instances of such occurrences does build up into a normalised stereotype that STEM subjects are a "man's" field, which may subconsciously sway girls away from pursuing the field early on.
This happened to a handful of my friends around me when we were choosing which subjects to pursue in "highschool". I was in a high achieving class and many of my friends like me were high achievers in both the arts and sciences. By the end of the year a majority of my female friends chose to pursue the arts and to drop their science subjects. At first I assumed it was because they were more interested in those subjects, but then when I asked them (all of them) they said they actually had no preference between the two. If this was the case I would expect a 50/50 split, so I probed a little more and asked specifically why they chose the arts over the sciences. The replies were either "I don't know" or something vaguely along the lines of "it fit more" or "parents/teachers expected me to...". I was one of only two girls who actually did carry on with the sciences, and I did so with a very conscious almost giddy excitement that I was "bucking the trend". 
Equally, among the boys there was a similar phenomenon but in reverse. Most went to the sciences, a few remained in the arts (again in my class we were all-round achievers so these boys also were previously high achievers in both). I also chatted to them about this choice, I got similar responses referring vaguely to sentiments of "belonging" and "I don't know" (also one or two replies about better career prospects). I personally theorised that this trend reflected the culture of machismo that sways many young boys which often suggest that being "artsy"or "creative" is abnormal or emasculating. But that is just a theory.
That a guy owns a shirt is none of my business. But I do think he should have picked a more appropriate one to wear at that convention. It would be like an Arab at a prominent "Celebrating diversity; let's all be friends" convention wearing a shirt covered with bombs and explosions. Not exactly encouraging everyone to befriend the Arab is s/he?

There's a pattern for this, and it essentially breaks down to the trend that women look for positions that are more fulfilling to their lifestyle while men look for whatever earns them the most.

+ThePuppyTurtle Feminism nowadays has its baggage of prominent voices, classes taught in universities, and actual actions taken by self-proclaimed feminists. In short, feminism nowadays is largely understood by feminists and non-feminists alike as "egalitarianism + the premise of class warfare between men and women", if you allow me to oversimplify and paraphrase for the sake of brevity. Just don't take this literally, but as a general direction of what people (feminists and non-feminists) understand as feminism. Egalitarianism is far from the prominence of feminism, so the term is still quite free-floating, without any baggage attached to it. Of course, the real question you are asking is why people would use "egalitarian" or "MRA" to describe themselves, when there are (only a few) feminists who share their opinions? Well... first consider that 1) feminism has accrued too many black points lately, so is in dire need of criticism 2) most feminists are collectivists, as I mentioned earlier. This means that for them the "in-group" is "the feminists and the women" (interchangeably), and the "out-group" is everybody else who doesn't share their opinion. So, in order to criticize these people, it's easier to ditch the label "feminist" outright than to suffer constant abuse that you are not a "real" feminist. Because the moment you start criticizing, you're no longer in the "in-group", so you are an enemy that must be defeated. Second consider that public opinion on what feminism is is also created by your own actions if you call yourself a feminist. So if you think there is a systemic problem in the movement, it may be wise to ditch the label, as to not confuse the general public. Further reading on this topic: [LINK]

I don't claim you have crossed that line in your comment, but when discussion strays near implying (through implicative patterns of speech) "having (some opinion) means you are (or are not) educated", many precautions must be taken to make sure we don't become enshrouded by our opinions like earplugs- they're so comfortable, and it's so much less comfortable to take them off, but the world continues around us whether we're listening or not. Though you draw no pedantically provable connection between "Just because a woman says stuff like this is okay, doesn't mean it is..." and "Just because you are female does not mean you are well educated on these kinds of issues", their sequential use in speaking (and other speech-informed media like comments or film) is often assumed to draw a connection between one sentence and the next, and I think you'll agree there is a somewhat reasonable certainty that this was your intent (though again, of course, not pedantically provable).

There are entire shows that air weekly around making fun of geeks/nerds. Long before Big Bang Theory there was Urkel to mock and denigrate vicariously. Arti Waine That's a very naive thing to say. Free the nipple is a noble movement and the female body should be appreciated. But there's a fine line between appreciation and objectification. It's more easily defined as "expression of the female body" when it's a women doing the expressing, when it's on a woman's terms. That's a man, which changes the context. I COULD be wrong, but I'm confident the shirt is an example of objectifying women. Frankly I'd have no problem with the shirt, or occasional objectification, if genders were equally represented in that regard. Women are FAR more often objectified than men, which is where the real issue, for me, lies.

Schwinn D. Sounds like an ad hominem argument against the shirt wearer, doesn't it? Since you seem to be more concerned about who's wearing the shirt, than what's actually in the illustration. Better question would be, that was the illustrator male, female or trans? And that shouldn't even matter, since artists intent cannot be grasped by some prejudice about his/her race or gender etc., and furthermore, artists intent is many times irrelevant in art, and meant to be concealed, so that the piece would truly be open for audiences interpretation. Of course one can interpret the illustration's intent as objectification, but here people seem to lack the humility of seeing it as just their 5 cents. There are not many hard fast truths in interpretation, so it's alarming to me, that people are so quick and righteous in their anger. Having said that, I'm open to hearing your points that make you think or feel like the piece is objectifying. What exactly was naive in your opinion, since I had several thoughts? We might be talking about an actual character of some pop culture fiction, who has a persona and back story, and I find it concerning that people are so quick to anger about one superficial aspect, that "pops" to them from the illustration. In that case the interpretation debate is in vain, and we should just educate ourselves about the whole story, before making conclusions from "a couple of still frames" that we saw. Nevertheless I stand by my view that by ignoring the context of helicopters, guns and explosions, people are oversimplifying art to be about something they project into it. In this case objectification. And to treat that as absolute truth is worrying. As an artist, I find a gun such a strong symbol of self-determination, that for me it's very far fetched to interpret the picture derogatory towards th e woman portrayed, or women in general. Art shouldn't be censored anyhow, where would that lead? Sparking conversation is positive, if the conversation is constructive and productive - and if that has been the case, the piece might very well have served its purpose [optimistic speculation].

And to clarify my original point in interpretation: for an hitwoman, wearing a revealing dress, IS a way to increase personal power, abusing the lust that it might spark in the unsuspecting target. Indeed a powerful piece, and one to cause emotional reactions and controversy.

Interesting twist with the gun symbolism is, that a brainwashed soldier is a perfect example of 100% objectification and submission to hierarchy, be it voluntary or not, but without that context, a gun is an asset to its holder, and thus a symbol of liberty, equality (in terms of self defence) and personal power (also in terms of offence and abuse).

And usually normal people are casually wearing pictures that they find admirable and beautiful, rarely to assert their dominance, even though the latter happens also.

I think I understand what you're saying. I would agree with what you're saying about the image itself as a perfectly valid interpretation. I can easily see that being the artistic intention. But it's not fair to discount the way I looked at it either, even if it was a snap judgment. It matters less that these kinds of conclusions are concerning, though they are, than the fact that these reactions exist. For that alone they cannot be ignored. Whatever people are projecting into the shirt is just another indication that something is going wrong--not that it's the shirt's fault. Really, with the majority of people looking at this image or others like it, most likely in passing, what are they going to think? That's a strong symbol of self-determination or that's another unrealistic depiction of beauty on some guy's shirt? And who is wearing the shirt is entirely relevant. Ignoring the fact that it is a man would be to ignore the patriarchal system we live in. I'll acknowledge that I have no idea about anyone's intentions with the creation or wearing of the shirt, but note that intention is meaningless in passing encounters. People will see what they see. This conversation is evidence that this stuff is just tricky. I'd like to say that intention is an important thing--and in the right context it is. We can always look deeper. I'll concede to just about everything you said as a potentially precise interpretation, but the truth of the matter is that these things are open to interpretation and people just won't tend to look deeper. Also, I find this discussion (about the shirt in general, not exclusive to our part of it) not entirely warranted just because this shirt is just inconsequential compared to the much bigger fish to fry. That's in part because, you're right, we shouldn't be censoring art no matter what, and there's nothing we can do but critique it. Also in part because the thousand other reasons we still have a patriarchy. BUT. You've had some interesting things to say, so it was worth my time.

Let me start by saying that I'm astounded that you (Nerdwriter1) are still taking the time to respond to comments on a video you made that is almost two years old. Good on you. I'm envious of your dedication. Ultimately this video is discussing a specific example of a more general theory. In this case, many people looked at a shirt, decided that the 'message' conveyed by the shirt was sexist and supports the stereotype of a boys club. These people responded by attempting to point this 'message' out, no doubt hoping to help discredit the stereotype of the boys club, hopefully reducing any sexist barriers in place preventing women from entering stem fields. The sentiment rings with me. Fighting oppression is a good and honorable goal to have. The problem I have isn't with the intentions, its with the theory itself. It sounds way to similar to the hypothesis that video games were making kids violent. Its the same fundamental idea. We have a cultural object that is assumed to have an impact on the way people think. In the case of the video a T-Shirt, in the case of the attempting banning of violent video games, it was the videogames themselves. People looked at the video games and saw the wanton violence and believed it was harming kids, making them more violent. People look at the shirt with scantily clad women on it and believe the shirt is making people more sexist, contributing to systems of oppression. In the case of video games, we know that the intuition people had was wrong. There is no good link between violence in video games and violence in real life. The cultural object failed to have the impact that the people assumed it would have. So given we can't trust our intuitions in the case of video games, how am I supposed to trust peoples intuitions when it comes to a shirt. Does the shirt contribute to the notion that science is a boys club? Is women's representation in science problematic and how does the shirt impact this representation? How am I to know? What I do know is that the man is not a shirt. The scientist, along with his team, achieved something incredible. They hit a bullet with another smaller bullet, landed successfully on a comet for the first time in human history. He was invited to speak for public new agencies, no doubt excited to share his passion with the world, to encourage young kids to imagine a future in which they too could be making groundbreaking scientific accomplishments, and rather than discuss the landing, the comet, astrophysics, science in general, he ended up being vilified for wearing a shirt that people didn't like. TLDR : Representation is far more complicated than any shirt, vilification of a fashion choice is insane to me. EDIT: To be clear, I'm not claiming that you or your video vilified the scientist. In fact, my post ignore the thesis of the latter half of your video. The idea that sexism/racism/etc is perpetuated because people like it is interesting if non-actionable. Honestly, I merely lament the fact that a shirt can get more coverage in the press and online than putting a lander on a comet.

Sure it means that men are more likely to take CEO jobs and STEM field jobs, but it also means they are more likely to die. And I would argue that that isn't an assumption. After all it is based on countless scholarly articles and alike. Here's some food for thought though; There seems to be ingrained systematic sexism, as well as other prejudice based -isms. In the case of sexism, they can be explained by two different hypotheses. 1) Different evolutionary trends have developed different brains which make different choices which, for better or worse, create different trends of employment based o n gender. 2) There is an ingrain ed sexism that causes the trends we see. And the biggest difference between these two ideas is the evidence. We can and have identified the evolutionary trends, so we know for a fact that they exist. What we have not done is identified the ingrai ned sexism, because as you say yourself , it is "invisible". So invisible that they are, in fact, undetectable, immeasurable, except for the outcome they predict, a society that seems to have an ingra ined sexism, and that would prove it's existence if not for the other hypothesis. Now there are two explanations, one with evidence to back it up all along the way, and the other with an assumption as it's base. Occam's razor tells us that the hypothesis with the least amount of assumptions is more likely to be correct and therefore should be operated with, and as such, the second hypothesis is eliminated. So although the explanation is not simple, it allows us to really understand that there is no syste matic sexism in the first world. And really think about it for a second; if I told you that an invisible, intangible flying spaghetti monster was having a great influence on all of my ideas and perceptions of other people, then you would tell me that I was a moron, and rightly so. Now obviously this comparison is no more than hyperbole to extenuate the evidence based flaws in your argument. So, if you can prove that what we observe in soci ety is sexism, and you can make that argument with logic and evidence, and not just with logic as you have been doing, then I would happily consider thinking it over in greater detail, and probably put a lot of deep thought into which explanation was more likely to be true, which fit our model of society better, but until anyone can do that, I will remain stoic in my understanding. Christopher Lynn If you haven't already been made aware, it stems from the Nixon Watergate scandal, which is considered by most around at that time to be the worst scandal the presidency faced (Clinton might rank higher now, idk). That scandal has generated a legacy behind it, and is considered by many to be the grandfather of all scandals, thus the '-gate' suffix you see so often. It's also worth pointing out that not all of that is genuine, and some people attach '-gate' as a sarcastic joke
The addition of "-gate" at the end of everything is a scandal known as "Gate-gate" :)
I wanted to write the same thing :')
Did you just start the gategate?
Christopher Lynn It has to do with the watergate hotel, which sparked the controversy that got Nixon impeached

Not any kind of breaking news here, but language changes and evolves. It would seem that the suffix "-gate" will in the future be considered proper English when referring to a scandalous event. Hell, the word gate in itself may eventually change its meaning to be synonymous with scandal. Through out human history, older generations have always complained about how younger generations speak, but eventually that becomes the norm and then the cycle begins a new. My suggestion is stop complaining and just realize it's a part of natural linguistic evolution. The way we speak now would be unrecognizable to English speakers a millenium ago or even 500 years ago and it's the same vice versa. Only time will tell what English will be like centuries from now, but this is how it starts.
Thank you!
Soon enough there's going to be a scandal involving tainted drinking water and the news is going to obliviously call it "Watergate."
It all started in the medieval times when an important official forgot to order the drawbridge closed during battle. They called it #Gategate.
comes from watergate. Don't ask me why we adopted the ending though.

-gate is just a simple suffix that we have made to quickly identify when you are talking about a controversy.

replies.commentText: [citation needed]

people use evolution to justify all sorts of social behaviors, but you do realize that once you go outside anatomy and mechanism and start to assign adaptive significance or any kind of function to these mechanisms, that's interpretation and subject to bias! saying more females are nurses because of evolution is ridiculous. here's a more plausible reason as to why more females are nurses: (1) females are perceived to be better at the caregiver role, so throughout life they are pushed towards environments where they will learn caregiving skills/they are passively trained in small ways to be warm and empathetic, show more emotion, smile more etc. - you can't confound this with evolution! you don't see this across cultures! (2) structurally it is easier for a woman to become a nurse as opposed to a man since cultural biases EXPECT women to enter the field, so resources and opportunities are catered towards them in this sense; however, there are tons of male nurses! and this statistic is only growing (3) I can tell you that nursing is a far stretch from caregiving! I have worked in the ER and I can tell you that both female and male nurses have to acquire a set of skills to be efficient. taking care of children is very very different from drawing blood from your patients or setting up IV, so you can't make that comparison! "care" can be a very detached and specialized set of skills

+poopspeeps

I am good friends with a male nurse and I have never heard him complain about it being more difficult for him to be a nurse.

@Mr.Grunt yep, chicken or the egg describes it perfectly. i think any small differences that may or may not exist get amplified exponentially by social factors. of course it makes you wonder where the social factors from from in the first place. regardless, whenever someone says evolution or biology is what led to these different spheres, i think that confounds too many things.
so the biggest complaints i have heard is how if a young girl says she wants to become a nurse, it's encouraged and acceptable, but you rarely hear a young boy saying he wants to become a nurse. there is that entry-level disparity in how the environment encourages kids who may be considering some sort of profession as a healthcare provider. as a practicing nurse, i've heard that males have to work harder to gain the trust/comfort of their patients, more so than female nurses. for instance when treating female patients, they have to use the back of their hand as opposed to the front when pulling them up from behind, they have to be careful about where they're touching female patients even if it's purely clinical. just things like that make it more difficult i've heard. not to say that this is the case for everyone, as your male nurse friend seems to be doing fine (which is good, i'm happy for him!), and plenty of male nurses in the ER where i've been working are content as well

commentThread.commentText: I feel annoyed.

Your video fails to deliver a solid argument for one reason. You act as though objectification of ONLY women in marketing and otherwise is ubiquitous, as though every person isn't objectified. Undoubtedly, women have this occur more, a neurological study showed even women view other women as objects at a much higher rate than men. I think it's a mistake to view this as a problem, however. If we did not do this, we would pick very poor mates for breeding. Research shows that "attractive" features and "healthy" features are one and the same. If we are to change how sensitive a world we live in, define the terms. How far do we go? Do we silence our comedians? Our politicians are so afraid to offend, they speak often and say very little. It's what makes Trump look refreshing despite being an idiot. We should simply argue bad taste and call it done, anything else is a slippery slope. Sorry if this is a scattered post, I typed it out on my phone. I enjoy the channel very much, keep up the good work!

The most telling point is the comparison made between Kim K's photo shoot and his choice to wear a shirt. It even went ahead and spread to the comments. Whether it's admitted or not, the only way such a comparison can be made is if both didn't actually exist as they were, but instead only as images for us to consume. Kim K's photoshoot has nothing to do with Matt Taylor choosing to wear a shirt, and yet the comparison was made based on "The potential damage it did to girls" Why are we blaming these people for how 'damaged' girls are? I don't obviously mean just these two people, I mean this is a trend where we hold an incredibly small fraction of society to this standard where what they do must benefit what we want. In which case, their actions and what they mean to them individually means nothing to us, and the image of their actions and how we can consume them means everything to us. Matt Taylor does not exist, and neither does Kim Kardashian, at least not in a way that respects who they are as individuals. They only exist as a collection of meanings, feelings, and ideas that we have about ourselves and superimposed over and upon them. Understandably, I'm late the party, but I'd rather be correct than in the right.

I'm going to try to note that I am not condemning here, because this dominance feature is deep in our DNA, and has always been a part of the human condition. It sucks, and we're wrong for being like that, but I'm going to avoid judgment here as to not be hypocritical here. To not judge feminists for judging percieved sexists for judging women.

Pleasure is used to give an enemy a touch of humanity, something to relate to. It's not meant as an insult or an accusation. There are nice things even your enemy can see in you or say about you. Not everything enemies say about you is an insult you can throw back at them. Not everything you say about your enemies has to always be an insult or an accusation all the time either. Some dehumanize their enemies so they can hurt them without feeling guilty right away, others humanize them so they don't end up accidentally hurting them and feeling guilty for the rest of their lives. That's why it often requires a group of people (such as friends, family or otherwise community) behind someone to get them to come forward and say there's a problem. Even without direct harassment, people who moan about things are often not looked on kindly, it's been expected people should just put up with things. But look where that's gotten people. There's going to be a lot less people willing to put up with things from now on. But it's rarely, if ever, from a place of superiority. It's just people sick of shit.

In the first case people will respect you for standing up for your principles, even your enemies might. This is what you say you are describing. Remember Rosa Parks for example?

In the second case you are just a whining and nagging which annoys people and will get you ignored by responsible adults. This is what you are describing. 

The point I was making is that you can tell other people they are wrong. Imagine if you could be like Rosa Parks and calling out racists?  Or calling out sexists? Imagine you teach bigots a lesson? That would mean that you are also a good person™. Doesn't that feel nice.

We have to look at the consolidation on the state level of these reactionary forces. They are near the threshold of being able to call for a constitutional convention because of the number of governorships and state legislatures where they hold both chambers. They can totally reorder the Constitution, if they even continue to abide by it, which they may not. We are facing a serious crisis. I don't think people grasp the depth of this because they are focused on the president and not the broader strategy of these reactionary forces.' I think a lot of Americans are scared of Trump as opposed to Bush or Obama (even though the policy really hasn't fundamentally changed) because Trump has no spin on what he does. Bush catered to a neo-conservative narrative, Obama catered to the neo-liberal narrative. If taking that veneer off what has been happening for decades finally terrifies Americans into doing something real about their authoritarian government, maybe it will not have been a complete loss. I also think it's interesting to see an isolationist hold the executive branch hostage while the CIA is trying to get it's next war (Iran) revved up. And your right (to get sidetracked), publicly scrutinizing one scientist who might have grown up with some questionable views on women doesn't solve a lot. But maybe getting more men to empathize with trauma women face will reconnect victim with perpetrator. I'm sure in the time since this all happened, a lot of discussion between different people has forced a lot of men to confront this issue. An amazing friend of mine, whose trans gender, told me after her surgery she had this huge reality change. She went from being a man in society to a woman in society. The change revealed to her all sorts of every day gendered prejudices that she had never noticed when she was a guy. I guess the point i'm trying to make is; if your a male, your not going to get the whole perspective. That frustration of being called out for something you thought was harmless (and, lets be serious, we ALL face that moment at some point) is an opportunity to express kindness through empathy for someone else's struggles. Ultimately, if we want to survive as a species, this is something we are all going to have to get better at.

I'm more disturbed by the pre-packaged notion that sexual imagery is denigrating because humans cannot perceive iconography without objectification. Why is it presumed that in order to appreciate a purely visual and even titillating image of a human, one has to be dissociative? Is it because this is the way it is or because this is the historical model we're used to? I think it's the latter. Because if the dissociative appraisal of the eroticized image of a human being is symptomatic of a dissociative attitude towards people, then it would be easy to assume that the eroticization is a cause as well as a symptom. But if we're using historical precedent, keep in mind that global cultures traditional place hierarchical provisos on human worth--i.e. humans aren't valuable until you measure their qualities such as status, gender , race, religion, clan membership, etc.--so there's all these dissociating attitudes that tailor the behavior, and then the symptom becomes an expression of it. We're not used to the idea of an eroticized or iconic representation of a human independent of a message or culturally reinforced intention. We can't imagine the idea that someone can wear an eroticized shirt and see women as equal humans because in order to do so, he couldn't be interested in those kinds of displays (I'm not using Matt Taylor as an example because I don't know him...I'm referring to a hypothetical male). The presumption that sexualization is denigrating seems to be as much of a problem as sexualization being used to denigrate is. Sexuality is (for the most part) an integral PART of the human psyche. It would seem that the issue about sexualization is more to do with conceptual integration failure rather th an sexual imagery itself.

"Women earn 60% of all graduate degrees yet comprise less than 25% of STEM jobs." Those facts sound about right but using them as an argument for a "culture of denigration of women" is false equivalence. A more qualitatively equivalent question to address the low woman STEM employment is: What percentage of women with graduate degrees hold a graduate degree in a STEM field? I would guess that it's close to that 25% mark if not even less since companies are encouraged to hire women to "balance out" the sexes. If the latter were true, this would actually say that women are relatively overrepresented in STEM fields in terms of equal opportunity. Different people with different combinations of characteristics, traits, etc. (including gender) tend to make different choices and that's probably a good thing for people in general.

commentThread.commentText: To think about our actions and inactions..... How do we make contributions?

I really couldn't get a sense of whose side you were on in this video. He's not wearing the shirt for the pattern, he's wearing it because it is made out of rayon, one of the lightest most comfortable fabrics to have on in a place like Florida, and also one of the cheapest. I live in Virginia, and every summer I buy a whole new spate of rayon shirts with all manner of prints on them, because it gets fucking hot here in the summer and they only cost 12 bucks for a week's worth of shirts. And I don't examine them that much before I buy them, I go based on the base color behind the pattern. A blue one, a green one, a red >one, and so on. I don't even try them on first. Secondly, he's not exploiting an y woman by wearing it, because the women on his shirt are fucking cartoons. They never were real people, they never will exist as real people. Those cartoons are a fantasy brought about by the imagination of an artist; an artist that might, in fact, be a woman. Women artists draw other women, shocking, I know. Can you fucking believe it? And not all women artists are like Marie Cassatt or Georgia O'Keeffe in their approach to drawing or illustrating women. Hell, Jane from Breaking Bad drew "Apology Girl". Are you telling me that wasn't a sexy drawing in any way? Now, if he had seven copies of the same shirt, and he wore one every day. Then y our sexism argument has a leg to stand on, because clearly he is sending a message with his shirt. But why on that day? You might ask. I chalk it up to him figuring that it would be a success and he was going to leave work early and hit the bars to celebrate, so he dressed in his bar-going outfit, not figuring ahead of time that someone might interview him on his way out of the door. And also, the idea that his shirt reinforces a "boy's only club" mentality is plainly ludicrous. The shirt, by itself does nothing, because, again, the women on his shirt are a fantasy, most women don't look anything like that. You could pick the pattern apart in the same way, but instead complain that the women are all white and call the shirt racist, or you could complain that because there are no dogs on the shirt, he must also hate dogs. He didn't make the fucking shirt, he's just wearing it, and if he is anything like me, he probably didn't examine it too closely before buying it. My wife works in STEM, she has a doctorate in virology. We got married while she was finishing grad school. All of her classmates were women, and all of them washed out, she was the only person who graduated in her class. They didn't wash out of the program beca use of sexism. Some of them quit because grad school wasn't what they expected in terms of workload and pay (writing grant proposals sucks), some quit because of family problems and planned to come back sometime later after they had been resolved, and some quit because they did the math and a masters degree would be a faster route to the job they wanted. Most of my wife's coworkers are women. The statistics you quoted earlier might have been true at some point, but they are not true now. I've been to conferences with her and the male to female ratio is about the same as the general population. Again, I can't tell what side of the "issue", if you can really call it an issue, you are on, but the shirt is harmless. So is the guy wearing it. Your ire, if you hate the shirt, should really be directed at the factory owners that used children to make it in the first place.

An interesting discussion but I don't think I agree, not entirely anyway. Part of the problem is cognitive and evolutionary science are still in an infant state. We don't really know why societies came together the way they did, or why the same moral and value judgments of those societies seem to be in agreement. What we do know is that societies that espouse what we might call 'family values' are more successful at bearing children. Population growth creates economic growth, and those in turn create knowledge, science and the technology we are communicating on. To tamper with that formula has often in the past lead to disaster, such as the social experiments in Soviet Russia, Nazi Germany and Maoist China. The worry I have is we're chopping away at the foundations for a literate, technologically and socially advanced civilization and all we'll have left is the ruined, toxic leftovers of a gender-fluid society that collapsed under its own arrogance and and (oddly) anti-western bias.
If womens are discouraged by a t-shirt, STEM is indeed not there place.
