commentThread.commentText: Your video was insightful and explained what feminists have been saying for a very long time, but because you're a guy people will actually listen to you, so I appreciate you saying something. Unfortunately, reading through your comment section makes me sick. People are so afraid to look inside themselves and see a monster, and see someone who is harming others (whether they mean to or not), and see someone who is afraid of giving up some of their power and realizing that they might only have what they have because they're better and deserve it, but because they were born lucky and into a society that automatically assumes they are more intelligent and hard-working just because they so happen to be male. You hit it on the nose when you said they're afraid to give up their power, so they go on the internet and write angry comments and tell women to die, that they hope they get raped, etc... to assert their power even more. I was accepted into philosophy masters an PhD programs and I'm one of 2 girls who were accepted into the program I am most strongly considering (I'm also thinking of doing an international relations course, which has many many more females and minorities represented). I'm scared, because I was an undergraduate in philosophy classes and it's so hard to be one of the only females in a class full of males, because even though I did really well in all of my classes and even though I know that I am good at philosophy, whenever I spoke up in class, I would be attacked like no male in my classes--- even when I was putting forth ideas that a male would later say and not be attacked for. I even considered not entering philosophy and doing something else instead just because the sexism is so pervasive. Those little things make a big difference as far as being accepted and welcome into a program. So, yes, a shirt does makes a HUGE difference. Not just shirts, but words on the internet (as can be seen in this comment section which is not even as vile as on a lot of feminists videos), attitudes, and everything. I am being sexually harassed at work here in Japan (one of the most sexist developed nations on Earth) and when I told people about it they said "Oh, it's just a joke," but it's not just a joke. It matters.

I'm not really up-to-date on this shirt-gate thing, so I may be taking things out of context, but I'm rather annoyed with outcry against sex as sexism. If a person has images of scantily clad women or men on their shirts, then my first assumption is going to be that this is motivated by one's libido, rather than some declaration of superiority. Obviously, we shouldn't think of anyone a s sex objects, but we can't just ignore that most of us find the opposi te sex (or the s ame sex) to be sexy. I believe sexuality is something to be celebrated, and it feels natural to me for men to enjoy images of naked ladies. That's biology, folks. I'm not concerned with the focus on female sexuality so much as I'm bewildered that it's less common for men to get the same treatment. Here is where I suspect that are patriarchal society is at fault, but I don't think the solution is to demonize make horniness, but to celebrate female horniness.

I think what would have completed your argument in a more satisfying way would be to acknowledge that there is pleasure in prejudice, but possibly even greater pleasure in persecution of those perceived as being prejudice. 

If I accept your argument that prejudice brings pleasure and if you accept my argument that persecution of prejudice also brings pleasure (and we all know it does), then we can only conclude that there is not actually a core ideology or morality to be sought out here; the situation is no more than a competitive discourse between different moral economies, each attempting to make gains through the destruction of the other.

I am a female chemist, and I do believe that in a completely egalitarian society, you would still find that women are more likely to choose careers involving care-giving and interpersonal contact, and men are more drawn to careers involving mechanical systems and math. The reason why I believe this is that in the most egalitarian societies that we currently have, primarily the nordic countries, women are more likely to choose careers in nursing, teaching, etc., and in places like India that are still very sexist, women have a strong economic incentive to choose STEM fields and are more likely to do so than in Nordic countries. Men and women are not completely the same once you look past their genitals. The same hormones that have massive effects on our bodies have effects on our brains as well. I say this as a highly rational, proficient female scientist. I won the award for the best graduate student in the chemistry department at my university. I knew I wanted to be a scientist since I was 4 years old and watching Bill Nye, yet, I'm willing to admit that a lot of the women that I know are highly gratified by working with individuals rather than ideas. Most likely, when comparing men and women on most factors, they are two bell curves that mostly overlap, but they are not completely identical. All of this is fine as long as we accept that the women who are in STEM fields are just as proficient as their male counterparts. Likewise, male nurses are paid less and promoted less than their female counterparts because we expect women to be caregivers. Sticking our fingers in our ears and screaming "MEN AND WOMEN ARE IDENTICAL IN EVERY SINGLE WAY EXCEPT FOR SOCIALIZATION" ignores reality and doesn't fix the problem. We are an animal that is fantastic at heuristics, but we need to retrain ourselves to approach every individual as just that, an individual, rather than as a member of any one group first.

First, understand that I like your videos and have subscribed, but I want to, respectfully, disagree with you about one thing in particular.  If someone wearing a shirt that you think is offensive, drives you away from the thing you might consider as a career than I don't know if you really had the passion for it in the first place.  I work in a field where many people do not subscribe to my political, religious or moral positions on things, and many of them are very vocal about it.  That being said, I love what I do, I am passionate about it, I have a deep commitment to it, and I won't let something trivial like someone's shirt, words, opinions or anything really dissuade me from continuing on working in a profession that I love.

replies.commentText: +David Radford  ooohrah.

Just a quick thought, David - I don't think many people think that that one shirt is driving women away from STEM. It's more like that's one scale on a dragon. No single scale, no hundred scales make up the dragon's armor, but it's a part of thousands and thousands of bits that taken together, are overwhelmingly powerful. In the same way, this shirt is just one (particularly loud and obvious) piece of a pervasive pattern of messages that say to women, "you're not welcome in STEM." Yes, the shirt was made by a woman, yes, he was wearing it to support a friend, no that was not a good choice for that particular event. One whisper is silent. Ten thousand whispers are deafening.

How much of this is someone outwardly saying "You're not welcome in STEM fields" and how much of it is just an excuse? Also this video postulates that this one shirt was the driving force for many women not to embrace STEM fields. If a woman can contribute to science and has demonstrated value, no rational scientist, will ever deny her a place. All this to me seems like some people dancing with a "shadow monster." And again, if you have a talent, ability and passion that leads you to succeed than I doubt much will stand in your way. Science, unlike other fields, extends a warm welcome to who will push it into new and uncharted territory. Its acceptance of diversity is well noted through out its history. But it does not embrace timidity and is reserved for the bold. It demands strength of character and resolve, so this "dragon" you claim exists is easily slayed by those who fight against it.
Yah, if a shirt is enough to throw an ENTIRE gender off the rails of choosing a career choice, then there is a much bigger problem.

David Radford I totally agree with what you said; the shirt isn't what's keeping women of all ages away from science. Instead, it serves as a symbol of what women, even in the science industry, have to face on a daily basis. Even though we've gotten far since the 1960's where women were finally allowed to enter the workforce (both influenced by their service in the war and by the suffragettes who had made this a possibility) the market as we know it today is still male-dominated. As he states in the video above, though many women enter the field of science, few of them actually get a position, and even fewer get cited in news and magazines. And this isn't even taking into consideration how many girls, even today, are sexualized through media.
Imagine if that were a girl, sitting with a shirt with half-naked men on it. The only critique she'd get would be that she's a pervert, and that it (frankly) is immoral to wear that shirt to an interview. This is because men don't face the same thing women do; they aren't used to being objectified, and the mere thought grosses them out, most probably resulting in her not being taken serious as a professional.

As he states, we are too used to sexualizing women, to the point where we even don't notice it anymore.
The shirt is, in my eyes, but a symbol of how unequal the world still is.

It's not that women are not resilient in the presence of weird sexy lady shirts, if that's the argument you're trying to make. It's that women are seeing these sorts of images and this type of messaging (the message being something like stem is for dude bros like me that like wearing sick bikini lady shirts that would probably make a 12 year old girl feel kind a weird) at young ages (elementary, middle, high school ) and internalizing them. What happens to you as an adult man at your job (or maybe even when you were younger and first entering the work force) is pretty different. If you had been bombarded as a young boy by subtle and not-so-subtle messaging that your desired career field was not made for people like you, yes, maybe you would still be doing what you do (just like there are still women in stem) but it probably would have reduced the likelihood of most boys in your situation going into that line of work.

I am trying to understand the kind of bullshit tactics this guy is talking about... the way he uses subjective metaphors and trying to make them sound logical is the ideal bullshit of pseudo talking.

People are offended by this shirt because it depicts women in a moderately sexual manner. Well, what is it about female sexuality that is so offensive, even to the supposedly liberal and open-minded? This isn't about misogyny, it's about our collectively rocky relationship with sexuality. If this shirt was covered in scantily clad men, people would think it was funny and goofy. Why? Because in many ways, we continue to perceive male sexuality as funny and goofy. For us, female sexuality still carries darker connotations, something dirty and even taboo. When we see an image depicting female sexuality in connection with a man (Matthew Taylor and his shirt, Calving Klein's new "I flash in my Calvins" ad) our minds often automatically jump to thoughts of denigration and exploitation even if that isn't what is necessarily occurring. We think that showing women bein g sexual is degrading to them, as if women are incapable of being strong, independent individuals a nd sexual beings at the same time. There is definitely an undercurrent of sexism here, but it isn't Matthew Taylor's. It's ours. At the end of the day, WE need to sort out our issues with female sexuality rather than constantly trying to police it in all it's forms.

The problem, as I see it, is at the level of the subconscious. Images such as the man's shirt automatically light up area's of a person's brain related to sexuality, cultural condition, or any number of areas depending on one's personal history. We can dissect and analyze what effect such images will have at the conscious level, but the damage has already been done, so to speak. We can't unsee images. And, to a large extent, we can't undo the initial effect images have on us. But what we can do is study the totality of imagery within our culture and attempt to come to an understanding of what effect this imagery is having on us. And then, the next time we encounter a certain type of imagery, we can choice how we interact with it instead of just reacting how we have been socially programmed to react. TLDR: images fucking matter because we have monkey brains and think stupid shit before we even know that we have thought anything. but, we can do better by understanding how stupid our brains actually are. sexism is real, wake up people. -Monkey brained "person"

commentThread.commentText: This is complex as hell. I look at the bdsm community, the religious community, the academic. I don't know what's right. I don't think it's right to coddle people. You're not entitled to safety. This is a universe law, beyond people. At the same time, people need to be protected. That's a humane response. But look at the victorian era. It was very uptight and, I feel, misguided. How can we act? Women are oppressed by sexualization and the lack of sexualization. They are oppressed by this shirt. They are oppressed by the blankness of the Middle East. I think that erring on the side of expressive freedom is the better err. It's going to hurt people. The Civil Rights Movement hurt people that would not have been hurt had it not happened, but it was the better way, I feel. So too, I think a person's right to express him or herself is the better side of making a tough decision. Honestly, I think we are all repressed and that society has been dominated by the power holders. And the power holders aren't men. They are at this moment, but if society then puts women in power, there are still people who hold power over others. That is the source of trouble, of pain, of problems. These people causing the real harm are adaptable. That shirt was not offensive. The same way that two men French kissing is not offensive, the same way that anyone's kink is not offensive. People can take offense to it. That is their problem, not he person expressing themselves. The problem comes not from the shirt but from the context of the shirt, which is our world. That guy could be a great guy (he landed something on a comet and he then apologized for wearing this shirt, so, I mean, how bad can he be when he had every right to act like a cocky bastard, but chose not to?). Also, that shirt is cool, it is artistic. It is sexual, and well crafted. The problem is that our world has problems, and this makes people afraid. Women are a power minority. So are non-whites. This is a problem. There are groups of people who hold power over others. This is a problem. But don't solve the problem with exclusion. That's just stupid. You're going to antagonize potential allies. Be inclusive, celebrate everything that has an iota worth of achievement. Do not make the slave the master and the master the slave. That doesn't fix humanity. Do not tell people how to go about their personal decisions. We need to balance our understanding of intent and impact. This shirt is not bad, and it is not a bad thing, and calling this shirt into the spotlight is not worthy of the efforts of people who are trying to fix humanity. What is worthy? A slow progressive, inclusive dialogue that makes gradual but permanent social change that brings about equality and camaraderie and allows for everyone to live and express themselves as they want to. And it's not because "It is just a shirt." Any small thing can have magnificent impact. No, it is because that shirt represents expression. That guy liked it. I like it. I am a man, and if any of you think that devalues my opinion, then you're an idiot. This shirt is ok. The world is not. It is not the shirt's fault. That guy could have worn a plain black shirt and the world would be just as bad off as before. And that shirt does not represent what is wrong with the world. The fact that we are simultaneously trying to tell people to be one with each other, but also to be sterile. That is the problem with the people who claim to be on the side of progress.
The only sin that shirt is committing is how ugly it is.

How about: 
The first of all social justices, is freedom. If you are free, you will inevitably offend people -not because you're inherently evil or something. Simply because people are different, and what is important to one is insignificant to another.

BUT... If you begin chasing offense, in an effort to stamp it out, you diminish and ultimately destroy freedom. From that point, there is no such thing as justice -social or otherwise. 

Following this logic, justice require freedom, and freedom requires offense. Thus, justice REQUIRES that we allow for, expect, and even encourage offensive behavior. 

So, what's to be done about all this offensive behavior if we cannot outlaw it? In my family, we practice the life skill of "getting over it." No, that's not a smart-ass joke. It's a real and ongoing conversation around my dinner table with all members of the family participating. The general concept is simply that what other people think about me or say about me is none of my business. Period. Until actual action is taken against me, any hurt or threat I feel is a product of my own insecurities. Addressing those insecurities is NOT somebody else' job. It is my job.

My hurt feelings are my own responsibility to address.
Now I remember why I don't read Youtube comments.

Let's not forget about the origins of the neologism "shirtgate" which utilizes the "-gate" suffix to imply a deeply intrusive, calculated, and nefarious operation. More likely than not, his shirt choice was not nearly as diabolical as the scandal it references. This is not to free him from any criticism, but just to remind us that we don't have to indict someone who made a bad fashion statement in the same way we do a politician who conspired in such an evil way. In the case of the watergate scandal, we are talking about people who know they did wrong and are covering it up. In the "shirtgate" situation, a gentler approach might gain an informed ally instead of alienate him into defensiveness.

Sexualized femininity is unrelated to misogyny, that said, carry on. P.S. Watching this video again, and I would like to say that I am annoyed, not by his shirt, not by the worry people have over its effects, but at the vulnerability young women supposedly have. I want to live in a world where sexuality of all kinds is not shunned or insulted, and no one is threatened by that. The fact that women are threatened by that shirt I consider unacceptable. That we live in a society where someone of your same sex appearing attractive or fetishistic somewhere makes you less comfortable, is not acceptable. This ant i-sex society is wrong, and needs to be corrected.

On the topic of the statistics given about how women are less prevalent in the STEM fields I'm wondering if age has been taken into account? I certainly do admit that the ratios of women to men in most STEM subjects at undergraduate level are still far from 1:1. However, many of the quantifiers for the success of anyone in science require a pretty great level of seniority. My worry is that because it takes so long to get into any real level of success in STEM (especially science, where at the very earliest you finish your PhD at 25, have three years of post-doctoral research and aren't leading your own research properly until you're about 30) we are mistaking the fact that it takes a long time to see the effects of promoting women in STEM for a direct effect of sexism. Given that a scientist is unlikely to be producing really impressive, citable work until they are at least 35/40 it probably should be taken into account that the demographics of STEM workers at that level of achievement haven't been effected as much by the great programmes that are now under way and perhaps we need to wait a while to see the full fruition of what has been done. Obviously we aren't done yet and I am definitely all for having more women (and non-binary genders... and more diversity in general) but I'm more in favour of the correct use of data!

commentThread.commentText: Treating privileges as rights, and their absence or any threat to them as an attack, and meeting that attack with defensiveness or even a counter-attack (or a preemptive strike), that's one of the big problems we face in the world. My main problem with the racism/sexism/representation debate is when I spot existing inequalities and see people argue that adding some to the missing side isn't fair because you haven't also added some to the bigger side. I've seen this crop up in my personal life when we (my family, including my 12-year-old nephew) go to McDonalds or a store, and we have the idea going in that we're going to get ABC (say, a drink for each of us), and I decide that since I don't want a drink as much as I want something else, I'll switch my drink to something of roughly equal value (say, a cheeseburger). And dang if that kid doesn't walk out of there with a drink AND a cheeseburger. Because I got a cheeseburger, so he should get one too, right? And my dad prefers to get him the burger than to argue the point (if my dad even notices that the point exists). This happens even when we have specifically pointed out earlier that we are operating on a limited budget for the day, and go in with the idea that we are only getting drinks because we're saving our money for later in the day -- and then I feel like if I assert equal privileges (getting two cheeseburgers to match his two items), I'll be draining the budget before we've even left the first stop. This is kind of what the atmosphere is like for the sexism/racism/etc. debate, in that when some people say "Hey, we could use some female characters" or "Hey, we could use some Asians instead of all these musclebound white guys" or the like, people on the other side say it's just not fair to focus on stuff like that, in part because it takes away from the existing setup. Because THEY already have their ice cream, and they don't want to see other people get a scoop of ice cream unless they get a second one. Etc. I'm a white girl with no claim to minority status of any type (not even female: we make up half the planet), and I want to play a wider variety of characters from different races and such. I really don't care about strong, active female characters (I've always gravitated toward Dark Horse male characters even in like Buffy the Vampire Slayer or The Slayers, where they have strong, active females), but I want to play Japanese characters and Korean characters and Kenyan characters and Cajun and Sumi and Argentine and Fijian and Romani and mixed-race. And I want to play males who don't have musclebound bodies, and females who have flat chests (it would be nice to have some fantasy play there: I have a build like the female dwarf in World of Warcraft), and to have more choices on Rock Band (which, coincidentally, I just typed Rack Band) than "thin" and what my friends and I dubbed the "starved in Africa" look. (I'd actually like to play some of the aging country stars, or like Meatloaf, which requires a different body type than all the se skinny sticks.) Compared to the people who look around at all the media and see themselves barely represented at all, it's not like I have a lot to complain about. But it bugs me. Sameness bugs me. Variety interests me. I don't see how there would be enough people in the world for whom the opposite is true, that the entire media has to continue operating from a fear of variety just to stay in business.

THIS video is amazing. I've went from .. how do I put this?... NOT thinking that I was immune to prejudice but at the same time NOT fully understanding the extent to how it applied to me as a white male. What I mean is, as someone who generally tries to stay calm and be a good person. It's just hard to hear "white privilege" and not think it's overblown and get defensive about it even when you concede that the idea is probably true. Like anything in life, you need to be able to objectively look at things and read GOOD sources from BOTH sides (very important) for NOT hours but days, weeks, months to start to truly understand it. Even when you're sure you get it it's not until some period of time in that you'll read, or hear a quote or argument that just blows your mind and opens your mind up to new possibilities or, in my case here, simply clarifies the issue even more so. So what clarified the issue so much more for me? The quote about "cultural norms being SO invisible that they seem like insight is AMAZING". It expresses so much about all of these prejudices in a way that I wish I had heard months if not years ago. There is something AS important to me that is not discussed that often, but I know people feel, that I feel is just one reason why these conversations are so hard to have productively. My main problem with stuff like "white privilege" REALLY wasn't admitting it was probably true, or to even what extent, but the fact that when I tried to have conversations about (all of these, really) topics like this it very often turns into passionate people with good intentions and motivations SHOUTING at me and others, calling us idiots, not 'woke', telling us to kill ourselves, etc. I've NEVER understood how this furthers the conversation and I get that people are going to be passionate (and that's a good thing) but if you ever try to question these methods you'll be told your an asshole, racist, homophobe, whatever, and that you're just trying to "tone shame" them. This is ONE thing that I ABSOLUTELY do not agree with because the premise is that you're wanting them to quiet down in an attempt to silence their passion, message, and (usually) that it's a further attempt to assert your dominance. While I'm sure this happens every once in a while, FOR ME it's not about that. I AGREE with the premise, I AGREE with the passion. You can ONLY master a few things in your entire life. Like one or two. You can only be GOOD or even DECENT at a few more. There is simply not enough time to spend 10 years on every subject and truly immerse yourself in it. Yet we talk about EVERY TOPIC like we are experts ON BOTH sides. Therefore, what I think is super important to concede is that ALL humans are wrong MOST OF THE TIME and so when you run into someone who is TRYING to have a conversation about topics as difficult as this FROM EITHER SIDE, the best thing you can do is remain calm and get out your passionate thoughts in a way that is as absolutely effective as possible. That is, people, like me, are going to have ideas that AGREE with your message but haven't spent as much time as you and are, therefore, still going to say some stupid ignorant things. Sometimes, to understand the situation better, it's even IMPORTANT to question the worst aspects of these topics specifically to get a different perspective on them. When it feels like you're being yelled at I can't help but feel like it pushes people further away from these conversations and stifles progression. FINALLY, it is SUPER IMPORTANT to note that the pleasurable feeling that people with prejudice feel by being above others isn't exclusive to them. A lot of people subconsciously seem to ALSO get off on SHAMING OTHERS for prejudice and I fear that this is where the yelling comes from NOT just because they are passionate. Don't get me wrong, I'm NOT saying that SJWs are wrong. I agree with the core ideas they have. I'm just saying that if the point is to ACTUALLY change people, we need to find the best way to talk to EACH PERSON individually. I'm NOT tone shaming because you can't say that it doesn't even always work, I'm trying to say that the passion needs to be tailored in different ways to be the most effective for each person. If you solely get off on shaming people ON EITHER SIDE, be it prejudice OR SJW, screw you. You're alienating your movement/cause and stifling the progress instead of helping it. Negative reinforcement doesn't work well as rational thought. It was talking to understanding people who put these issues into new ways of thinking that started to make me start to fully see the extent of these issues and how they affected me... Like I mentioned at the top of this comment about the quote in this video. THAT is what we need more of.

The proposition of "do you feel annoyed or threatened" seems mostly like a Kafka trap from feminists and sjw's to make it about the persons prejudice rather then the other way around. Either way the person who is annoyed or 'threatened' is wrong and thus needs to examine and check their privilege. 

It's a bit like donald trump and his double bind rhetoric tactics where he ends up looking like he knows what he's talking about and that he's the one in charge.

+dogsRoxXD Heh, don't be absurd brother. Scientific inquiry carries far too much pragmatic value to realistically conceive of it ever being seriously threatened, let alone by a couple twitter zombies and tumblrites . If the STEM fields are going to continue to hold such massive influence on modern society, then I want some people watching damn closely to make sure that ugly ideas which may have become associated with scientific practice without really coming out of it aren't getting reproduced and massively proliferated along with the good stuff. +dogsRoxXD Why don't you dial it down a bit, huh? We're just having a conversation, there's no call to be hostile or discourteous. I read the article you linked and I fail to see what you find so devastating about it. My major criticism of her would be that she highlight this "major study from December" and criticize it for methodological flaws and faulty assumptions without outlining these flaws and assumptions and producing an argument for why they're wrong. Hell, she doesn't even name the study she's referencing, talk about some shitty journalism. As far as concerns the meat of Virginia Hughes' argument, namely that she wants to criticize the tendency in neuroscience to jump from brain structures to universal proclivities inherent to the sexes, I am actually quite sympathetic. The brain is massively informed by environmental influences and is an incredibly complicated machine; I would be wary of any claim that tries to make a direct causal connection between a brain structure and some universal human proclivity, let alone a study such as this which does have ideological stakes, stakes which very conceivably are coloring the researcher's interpretation of data. All that aside however, I still fail to see why you find this article so threatening. I don't see any laws being passed about what kind of research can be done, I see no thought police donning white coats and entering the labs to enforce conformity with the feminist party line. All I see is a small woman with no power besides that of the pen raising a rag about how maybe there are some sexist stereotypes getting unwittingly reproduced and legitimized under the penumbra of good scientific research. My faith in the durability of the scientific method remains unshaken. I mean just look at global warming and the failed attempt by the goddamn Republicans to deny it: almost everyone takes climate change as a fact by now, and if all the moneyed interests and political power that went into resisting that scientific fact failed to do so, then what chance do some online writers have? Your belief that internet feminism presents a legitimate and pressing threat to scientific inquiry is fantastic. "Yes, Criticizing is good, but within the sciences, this finds facts and weeds out bad research. But, what science doesn't need is people who have no idea about the research, criticizing it because it doesn't fit in with their agenda. You don't see me walking into your gender studies lecture and telling your professor everything he is teaching is a lie without a speck of proof." You kind of are, bro :) The basic tenant of feminist theory is that patriarchical thinking informs our psychology and beliefs to such a profound extent that examples of it can be found surfacing just about everywhere, including in such seemingly removed fields as scientific inquiry. You disagree and are trying to summarily dismiss that theory despite only having a tenuous grasp of the philosophy behind it. I am trying to rebut your position through providing further information and through argument, not just by saying "lol, you're just a STEMlord who can't understand the TRUTH! Go back to your Chemistry 101 class and don't come back until you've read the completed works of Judith Butler and Simone de Beauvoir." The ability of laymen to converse over issues in which they aren't specialists yet which nevertheless concern them as public citizens is a cornerstone of democracy. I don't presume to criticize science in its most esoteric reaches--hell, even working scientists can't really criticize science on that level save for in the areas in which they're specialists--but I am still informed enough to give an opinion on how we should receive some bit of research, and I sure as hell can criticize th e sexual disparity in STEM fields and how it relates to Matt Taylor's poor fashion choice. Drop the bunk arguments to authority, they are distasteful and not very productive. "And who is to stay what constitutes as good, and what constitutes as bad? If it hurts some feelings is it bad? If it agrees with the Social Justice agenda is it good. This is where your argument breaks down, because there is no good or bad facts. There is accurate and inaccurate facts, but bringing morality to facts is just something that is objectively impossible. Facts are factual, they exist whether you believe that they are right or wrong. Facts exist outside of human perception." No, REALITY exists outside of human perception. Facts are linguistic/symbolic constructs made by humans to try to get a grasp on that reality. These constructs, being so intimately tied to the human, are naturally subject to human error. It's only too easy for mistakes in judgement, and yes, even for ideological bias to seep in. The history of science is replete with examples of this: Galileo thought the planets orbited in perfect circles as opposed to ellipses because he was deep into Platonic philosophy which stated that the circle was the most beautiful and perfect of shapes. Newton's calculations of the universe were hamstrung because he refused to confront the fact that the fundamental nature of the heavens might change over time, and he artificially divided the rainbow into seven colors because the occult bullshit he was into stated that seven was a sacred number. Einstein refused to deal with quantum physics because it introduced the concept of real chance to the functioning of physics, and Einstein was too enraptured by his fantasies of a deterministic universe put in motion by some Spinozist watchmaker God to consider that possibility. There's an entire extinct branch of science called phrenology deeply informed by t he racist ideas of the 19th century which sought to scientifically legitimize th ose racist fantasies of white superiority by referencing the shape of the skull. You keep acting like science gives us this undiluted, transparent access to truth and that just isn't the case. Science as a discipline has this almost miraculous power to generate ever more sophisticated models for understanding and manipulating reality, but it never just gives you truth, it never allows you to completely escape the bias of your historical moment. I think it's dishonest and worse, counter-productive, to pretend that it does. The Copernican revolution would never have been possible had the man remained faithful to the simple TRUTH of geocentricism insured by the fine reasoning of Ptolemy and Aristotle and their inclusion in infallible Catholic dogma. On that note and as regards social justice warriors, I don't think it's at all difficult to imagine that the revolution would not have occurred had the 16th century's version of a social justice warrior, Martin Luther, not broken open a political rift in which it was possible to doubt the absolute authority of the church.

commentThread.commentText: The thing missing from this comment section is that, time and again, the existence of stereotype threat and self-prescribed gender limitations has been shown again and again in study after study. You cannot deny scientific data that shows that many women have negative perceptions of their ability to achieve in some fields, and not in others. [LINK] "Findings suggest that men and women do not differ greatly in their online abilities. However, we find that women's self-assessed skill is significantly lower than that of men." [LINK] "When women perform math, unlike men, they risk being judged by the negative stereotype that women have weaker math ability. We call this predicament stereotype threat and hypothesize that the apprehension it causes may disrupt women's math performance. In Study 1 we demonstrated that the pattern observed in the literature that women underperform on difficult (but not easy) math tests was observed among a highly selected sample of men and women. In Study 2 we demonstrated that this difference in performance could be eliminated when we lowered stereotype threat by describing the test as not producing gender differences. However, when the test was described as producin g gender differences and stereotype threat was high, women performed substantially worse than equally qualified men did. A third experiment replicated this finding with a less highly selected population and explored the mediation of the effect. The implication that stereotype threat may underl ie gender differences in advanced math performance, even those that have been attributed to genetically roo ted sex differences, is discussed." And these are just two, easy to google examples that are members of a substantive amount of research showing that women have negative perceptions of their abilities in areas, even when their abilities are the same, and therefore end up underselling, underperforming, and underachieving. There are dozens more, but I don't have my binders full of women handy right now. For any female scientist on here to say 'well, I don't feel that way at all' is incredulous. Not because they don't know how they feel, but they act as if their anecdote supercedes the evidence. The very fact that so many people think that one or two or even twenty women's testimony to the contrary of this scientifically observable trend points to the fact that many people look to the confirmation of their belief that gender discrimination in any capacity is wrong. That CONFIRMATION BIAS has also been shown time and time again. As a teacher, I'm sad because I hear too many accounts of female students who were top of the class, bright, and outgoing in Years 1,2,3, and are now quiet, afraid to answer questions, and no longer achieving greatly in Years 7,8,9. This is not an anecdotal attempt to convince you. I just said I hate the anecdote arguments (or rather, non-arguments). It is an emotional appeal to get people to DO THEIR FRIGGIN RESEARCH AND SEE WHAT THE MAJORITY OF SOCIOLOGICAL, PSYCHOLOGICAL, EDUCATIONAL, AND DEVELOPMENTAL STUDIES SAY! So, yes, that shirt was not okay. And no, one person saying 'We have a Women in Tech event at my company' does not mean that it is better. We are talking about ingrained, widespread, SCIENTIFICALLY DOCUMENTED!!! trends that permeate the very fabric of how people, in their many identities, move through the world. I'm not being poetic. I'm reading the research. It's clear. And if one person in the comments links to one study that shows no stereotype threat, I show you the meta-analysis of stereotype threat that says " For women, subtle threat-activating cues produced the largest effect, followed by blatant and moderately explicit cues: ds = |.24|, |.18|, and |.17|, respectively; explicit threat-removal strategies were more effective in reducing stereotype threat effects than subtle ones: ds = |.14| and |.33|, respectively. " And wearing a shirt that shows women as violent-loving, exceptionally attractive, bodacious babes, while talking about your team's scientific achievements, seems like a pretty good example of a "subtle threat-activating cue". [LINK]

commentThread.commentText: So you brought up an interesting point. Some people operate under that assumption that [[women biologically prefer other fields to stem fields]] because they may be misinterpreting invisible social norms as statements about biology. But honestly, everything starts with biology, even social norms. It's not like they're pulled out of thin air or are an accident. Maybe social norms are a result of biology as well, and this feed back loop has caused a reasonably large segmentation between the sexes as far as participation in different fields are concerned. [LINK] This talks about a study which found that, while the deviation of brains is pretty high in general, there is still a light correlation between certain traits of the brain and the sex of the person with the brain. Surely, because this correlation is light, it cannot describe the large disparity between wo/men is different fields. I think it's much more likely that these differences are the result of biology, not society. But even then, this assumes that the relative lack of female participation in STEM fields is a bad thing, the result of evil misogynistic social norms forcing women out of STEM fields. Rather, this is just how society works; it influences people in ways which hugely affects what they do later in life. You certainly wouldn't be a YouTuber right now if not for certain societal influences, right? And that's not a bad thing. Welcome to humanity.

I'm in danger of losing my freedom of expression, when no discrimination is occurring - neither implied nor in actuality. I don't want the US to become like Sweden. Equality of opportunity is infinitely more important than equality of outcome. This is why statistics mean nothing without knowing and understanding underlying root causes, and therefore it's extremely facile to concoct spurious correlations, even in completely unrelated concepts (which is why pseudoscience remains rather prevalent in the modern age). Maybe this, maybe that - little more than maybe's. I f sex asymmetry in STEM is primarily due to actual discrimination, then action should be swiftly taken when the actual discrimination takes place. Otherwise and regardless, don't raise females to be so complacent to cultural norms, or demand that subjectively offensive material be prohibited, if for whatever reason you must absolutely demand that there must exist a 1-1 male-female ratio in STEM (or really, any other job/career). Everyone has the right to be offended; however, no one has the right not to be offended. This equally applies to males as well. I would be singing the exact same tune if STEM was dominated by females, and wearing shirts with [drawn] scantily-clad, sexualized men was the norm. There is no "pleasure" that I could possibly derive from being associated with a dominant subset of humanity (in a given field, career, area, topic, or any other category) - nor is there any good reason for me to focus on subsets of humanity within the context of STEM, which has aims above and beyond the trivial and petty categorizations concocted by flawed, mortal organisms. I am a libertarian and a classical liberal in this sense - individuality is more sacred than authoritarianism. Provided discrimination was not occurring, there is nothing wrong with wearing such an article of clothing in an absolute sense. Hence regardless of what the root cause is, Matt Taylor did nothing wrong (other than perhaps wear something that's inappropriate for the occasion; a lab coat would have been a better choice to appease the [clearly abundantly] shallow public - but certa inly nothing wrong within the conte xt of sexism in the form of workplace discrimination). In the case of #shirtgate, there was no discrimination occurring - only inference that was immediately connected to a conjecture of sy stemic sexism in STEM, and Taylor immediately became the whipping boy of such an inference. The Rosetta event was twisted into a platform mainly utilized by the vocal minority (hopefully) of SJW fanatics, which not only primarily downplayed the scientific achievement (in which both males and females were directly involved), but regressed the original goals of feminism by inducing further divisions in various scientific and social communities. Do not mistake this as an implication that discussion should be suppressed, but rather that such discussions should not require the exploitation of an incident which did no actual harm.
Where your entire argument breaks down, is the notion that male sexual desire is 'sexist'. Why do you think so? Do you think that women are sexist when they express sexual tastes? If not, why not?

An interesting angle! I haven't really thought about the matter enough to venture an opinion of my own - and it would be kind of late to the party in any case - but it was thought-provoking enough for me to finally subscribe to your channel. Cheers!

+Richard L I am late to the party too.. I don't think he was right on this one though.
There is no proven link between the shirt and the lack of women in STEM. He just linked those 2 things together out of his ass.

+TheDcfan01 Of course there's no real link between that shirt and the lack of women in STEM - the latter existed long before the former. And nobody is arguing that that exact shirt is the cause of the problem. Rather, the shirt is a symptom of the attitudes that are at the root cause of the problem. The belief that STEM is a manly field, and the lack of women, and the laissez-faire attitudes toward certain behaviors (such as choosing such a shirt to represent one's group instead of something more neutral), are all factors that feed into and reinforce each other. Finally, a generalized comment about how to discuss complex, touchy issues: Don't say "this thing that I disagree with must be an ass-pull." That's quick and easy, but also cheap, unconvincing, and kind of annoying. It would be better to try and find out what facts, beliefs, assumptions, and trains of reasoning led to someone making a claim or professing a belief. If it turns out to be convincing and solid, so that they were probably right, then you get major intellectual-honesty points for following the line of reasoning and accepting it. And if it turns out that they were wrong, then finding how they got to an incorrect conclusion can give you the tools to construct a compelling and effective counter-argument.

two years later and I come back to this out of idle curiosity; what have I taken from it all? People are morons sometimes. I know this probably wont get read and I'm potentially casting my thoughts to the void, but I think its worth saying in the idea of acknowledging +nerdwriter1's general bravery for stepping up in the face of what could have been a hellstorm to smite him where he stood. I love the channel, love what you do nerdwriter, youre a good man. In regards to the whole thing-- the swirling murky gross M-word and the sticky people that brings to mind on both sides of that fence, I'll have to say I disagree with the notion that the shirt was ever an issue. not because of the fact that it was or wasnt sexist or freedom of expression or any of that, but just... the environment around this just speaks a lot to be said for what people cared for the man and his life, and the subsequent value they place upon women actually joining STEM careers. My girlfriend is in school to become a web systems architect, has been for years now. She adores the field and enjoys the challenge that it provides her. when I first showed this to her asking 'does this intimidate you from going into these fields?' she simply laughed in my face and went back to her sandwich she was eating. I asked her 'Well, do you think it intimidates any of the other girls in your classes?' to which she rolled her eyes and replied 'I wouldnt know, the ones we had dropped out in the first year cause it was too hard' I want you to bare in mind that my girlfriend is not a straight A student, and that she's failed a few classes and this has been stretching out her degree plan. EVEN with this, she still tries because she feels a certain passion for it. when she speaks to her female friends about this, generally they shake their head and wonder why the hell she would want to ever do something 'so boring' Now, I realize this all comes down as anecdotal, and that maybe theres something to it all... yea, taking away someones pleasure to expose an ugly truth is a rough sell, but lets sorta pause for a moment here; the sacrificing of this man's proudest moment, his magnum opis in life, for the promotion of something that might or might not just boil down to someones subjective opinion, is his blood worth the uncertainty of such an ideal? what does undermining something else to provide as a platform say about your ideals own validity or strength to be stood alone? Food for thought. Like I said, at this point I'm skipping stones across the lake for a bit of kinda sorta public personal reflection. the video if nothing else gave me plenty to think about. its nice. sometimes you just gotta yap out into the aether.

There is a great documentary called 'The Gender Equality Paradox' on youtube (made in Norway) that outlines that men and women really do make different choices based in large part due to genetic drivers. The studies by Simon Baron-Cohen in particular are brought to the fore in proving that young babies (we are talking days old) exhibit this difference clearly in the shape, texture and form the toys that grab their attention the longest take. Boys tend to look at straight edged polygons and three-dimensional mechanical structures such as cars and lego etc - things unrelated to human interaction. While girls tend to remain fixated on dolls, and in particular, faces - things that assimilate human forms. So, in places famed for having made great strides i n gender equality and breaking down the so-called harmf ul gender norms, such as Scandinavia, all the government initiatives to create parity in male-dominated arenas have failed to influence the free choices (let's not get into the illusion of choice rabbit hole for now, please) of women who simply do not want to enter STEM or elsewhere. Consequently, and paradoxically, in countries in other parts of the world with less socio-economic liberty and availability of choice, the gender gap is diminished and mitigated in comparison to, say, Sweden, where those (apparently) pernicious norms persist. So, what this tells us is that given more freedom, women go tow ards gender normative jobs that involve more socialising or human-to-human interaction. Matt Taylors shirt can be viewed many MANY different ways. But, really, this is just another case of Feminism doing more harm than good by over prescribing a social malady that doesn't exist. The shir t did nothing. The response did everything to keep women from STEM.

I have a varied collection of thoughts in response to this video. Some of those thoughts could be categorized as agreements, some as disagreements, some halfway in between, and some do not fit on that one dimensional spectrum.

There is something I feel the need to ask. Please forgive me if this is presumptuous:

Have you ever heard of the concept that "Every Cause Wants To Be A Cult"?

Something I think the social justice community is not aware of is there is little to no correlation or causal connection between the righteousness of a cause and the quality of the community associated with a cause. A good cause is just as likely or nearly as likely to attract a bad community as a bad cause. Therefore, fighting against institutionalized prejudice, exclusion, or oppression may be a good cause, and it may attract good individuals, but it may still attract a bad community.

I learned this concept from this essay:
http://lesswrong.com/lw/lv/every_cause_wants_to_be_a_cult/

Since when has STEM been a guy thing? I decided not to go into that because, at least where I come from, that's perceived as either a girls thing or a lame, uber nerdy thing, and I just didn't want to be perceived that way and be forced into that crowd. If that was really supposed to be a guys thing, I would have been a chemical engineer - accept I'm not, because it's not.

First off, you are attempting to crucify Matt Taylor. And you are creating strawmen of your opposition. The impending arrival of the press was not expected. It is not something that he could reasonably have considered when he chose to wear the shirt. And that shirt was made for him by his significant other. Never to wear it at all would be a sign of ingratitude. The main reason why women are under-represented in the "STEM" fields is because those fields are hard. Our society has done everything it can to make things easy for women. Women learn from childhood that everything is supposed to be easy for them. And when something isn't easy, many of them just give up. But there is no "royal road" to science. There is no "royal road" to technology. These things require effort. When it comes to feminists, SJWs, and other sexist bigots such as yourself, there is a very real danger of losing my freedom and my autonomy. Everyone who isn't an obedient little slave is labelled as " misogynist." Men are expected to work themselves into an early grave for the pleasure of women without even a word of thanks in recompense. So, perhaps you would like to tell us why you enjoy your sexism so much.

Just a disclaimer: I'll be paraphrasing. 0:54 - The shirt will discourage girls from joining STEM research because it perpetuates the idea that is a Boy's Club. How does someone wearing a shirt discourage people from joining a field of research? The shirt had women that were sexualized, sure, I concede that point. What's a bit hard for me to swallow is how wearing a shirt with cartoon women on it will dissuade young, aspiring, potential female scientists. I'd also like to point out that the shirt itself makes no mentions of STEM research, nor does it independently associate itself with that field of work. The only association it has with STEM research appears to be that someone reporting big news as far as our progress in space is affiliated with that occupation. If we're to assume that this shirt will have any impact on young girls, we'd have to conclude that the girls' thought process goes as follows: 1. There is a shirt with scantily clad women on it. 2. That shirt is being worn by a scientist. 3. Those women must be referencing the field of study this scientist is involved with because he is wearing it. 4. Because this shirt is involved with his field of study, that must mean it is a symbol dissuading us from becoming scientists. 5. All things considered, I should not become a scientist because, through looking at this shirt with women on it being worn by a scientist, STEM research must obviously be an all boys club that does not encourage women's participation. Conclusion 3 makes little to no sense because we don't know how, or in what way, the shirt is affiliated with STEM research outside of being a scientist's choice in outfit at the time. Some explanation would be appreciated. 2:33 - We're trying to show how wearing a shirt like that might add to a culture of denigration toward women. This goes hand-in-hand with what I wrote earlier. You don't seem to provide a method by which this shirt is doing this. 2:46 - Women comprise less than 25% of STEM jobs, and they are far less likely to be published in peer review journals. Maybe this is because women don't like Science as much as men. If you think this, however, the only thing I can tell you is maybe your assumptions follow cultural norms so invisible they seem like insights about gender. There is a lot I take issue with here. You propose the explanation that it's possible that the statistics are not just a coincidence and instead are the result of invisible cultural norms, but you don't provide any evidence to back up that assertion. What reason do we have to assume that this tendency among women and STEM jobs as well as their frequency in publishing peer review journals is anything but a coincidence? What are these cultural norms you're talking about? How can you demonstrate that they are, in this case, responsible for the statics we've been given? The only explanation you provide in the video is, "Well, maybe you're wrong." Well, OK, maybe I am wrong. So, what? You didn't give us anything to consider. No proof, nothing. Just a suggestion with a lack of citations proving your point. If you provide some kind of proof tha t gender discrimination/"cultural norms" are responsible for these statistics, please provide some evidence. 3:54 - *In issues like this, you need to keep in mind that we're talking about people's pleasure; about taking it away from them." What? I'm going to assume that the issue you're referring to is the discourse over the shirt. The actual arguments themselves. From what I've seen so far, there really hasn't been a connection between this shirt a nd sexism established so far. Far too often are these sorts of issues brought up with little to no evidence supporting it. This video is a y ear old but it still has issues that keep coming up of little things like this shirt.

I think the issue with this shirt is not that it would discourage women from entering STEM, but that sexist men, of which there are many, would take it as an affirmation of their bigotry. And if they feel supported, then these men will go right on making women's lives that much harder. I don't care what this guy wears on a day-to-day basis, but when in the public eye one must keep in mind the message one's attire could be sending.

"We're not crucifying him..." The hell you aren't. You're picking him out because he is a face to direct your hate at, because you can't target "the culture" because it is in the air you breath, the water you drink, and so fractured into subcultures and interpretations there of that any such criticisms fall on deaf ears, or are attacked by people who misunderstand your words or disagree with them. He was a person who could be singled out and dragged through the mud because he was a person, and this is profoundly unjust. Psychologically people are better equipped to critique people than abstract concepts, which is what you have the issue, not his stupid shirt. You want to talk statistics? Do you have statistics on the effects of fashion choices on women going into Stem? No? Well than what you have is conjecture only. As a student of physics I can assure that it is a fucking hard field, even in undergrad; you need intelligence, talent, and mountains of determination just to get a BSc, never-mind a PHD and a career in any space agency. If you think that a cheap shirt is going put a dent in the mountains of mental force you need to be successful in the sciences, than you are delivering a grave insult to my female peers. Then there's the question as to why you would assume that cartoons of women in poses which are barely suggestive by modern standards would have any deleterious effect on women at all. Unprofessional, surely. Ugly and in poor taste, arguably so. But careful that you aren't simply trying to justify your disgust, but trying to solve an actual problem. Lets look at an illustrative example; a woman who just put on a dance performance hailed by critics as a masterpiece in our time chooses to conduct an interview wearing a dress featuring drawings of shirtless me with rippling physiques. Would YOU be equally offended by that? Would you say that her shirt is pushing men away form careers in art? Would you claim that it is her right to wear whatever she damn well pleases? Would you deride her for having poor fashion sense or forgive her trespasses since she is a eccentric artist? I don't know what any of you would do personally, but I do know that many internet commentators would hold her up as a hero of feminism for flipping the script of men objectifying women in this profoundly idiot ic gender war we're all supposed to be fighting. And I see that as fucked up; that even the most pro-women elements of our culture have absolutely no problem with representing themselves as the perpetual victim, always downtrodden and in need of support when times are tough, and praise when they assert themselves, where as men are inherently so tough and privileged that they need to be torn down a peg or smacked back in line. Am I arguing that women don't on the whole have it worse then men, or that they are underrepresented in STEM? No. I am arguing that you're psychologically tearing apart a science nerd because he has fashion sense, and putting on airs as if this is justified, and good. Ad if humiliating one man will end the patriarchy. As if you don't have your own problem atic gender-based biases. As if your ineffectual attempt at social progress were more important the the scientific progress this mission has achieved. I'm disappointed in you.

+Girl Buu Just so you know, I read all your comments and agree with you. What's mostly getting me reading many of the responses to your original comments is how people seem to have decided that the style of your argument invalidated your claims. As a shout out to people (in general), arguing the use of a word -- even if it is only to be somewhat pedantic -- is a vital part of linguistic evolution, and especially so in cases where a word is transitioning definitions. Look at the TECHNICAL definition of feminism and the NEW definition of it for proof. The word started out only referring to advocacy for women's rights, and has now taken on the popular modern definition of advocating for both gender's rights. While misogyny might undergo the same conversion (to a less severe definition) it is still CHANGING, and language being the purest form of democracy to a certain extent the largest body using a given definition will 'define' it. There's nothing wrong with arguing for th e old definition to remain, as it DOES fill a void in the English lexicon that would be empty otherwise. Sure she argued it somewhat crudely, but again, that's STYLE not CONTENT. It's well within a person's rights to say that her particular mode of argument failed on them, but to use that as your sole ammo for arguing her points is not only silly but ineffectual. All that said I'mma let y'all finish but Girl Buu is the best commenter in this thread. Kanye out.

replies.commentText: +realevilcorgi I'm horribly confused by where you ground your argument. Both of these issues are feminist ones, but they are different. One is about helping girls who literally have no rights. The other is about lingering sexism after achieving social equality. To make an analogy, this is like saying that racism agains t African Americans by white Americans doesn't matter becau se African slavery still exists. We could argue about which issue is more pressing, but neither is a non-issue.

commentThread.commentText: Simply put I think people are fine with the point about lack of gender representation in STEM and how seemingly tiny symbols like Matt's shirt could contribute to this problem - going off on a slight tangent here, I agree that there is socially ingrained attitudes holding women back but as uncomfortable as it is to admit, it is possible that society isn't as big a factor in determining woman's choice to go into STEM subjects as in more egalitarian societies like Sweden less % of women in their pop. go into STEM fields than in patriarchal societies like India so there's clearly something more to the issue of STEM underrepresentation than the nebulous sexism of society - but they are annoyed not because their own pleasure from their privileged positions are being taken away, its because of the fanatical also crazed crusade the SJWs have launched on Matt Taylor, this lynch mob mentality that wants Matt to confess to his crimes and grovel on his knees in forgiveness that really is reminiscent as Boris Johnson said like the show trials under Stalinist Russia. Yea this is a super late response but I just discovered your channel and been binging on all your commentaries - great stuff, social media and the internet in general needs a nuanced balanced and objective voice like yours. Really appreciate your work!

Great video. The only point you left out was that the shirt was designed by a female friend of his who I believe asked if he could wear it to promote her stuff, or he wore it as a favor. Correct me if Im wrong. Otherwise, insightful video, I've seen many on this subject from differing perspectives and yours was the first I watched from the social justice side that felt calm and thought-out.
And here I am were my ideas and opinions didn't mattered in the classroom because of my non femininity, because that equaled freak.

You also mentioned, and proceeded to refute the argument of "what if women just don't like science" by stating that that assumption is based on cultural norms. You argue that the reason women don't seem to like science is because we somehow propagate that notion through stereotypes. But... what if I told you that it's because women and men are different, not just physiologically, but also psychologically? What if I told you that the above assumption is not based on cultural norms, but biology itself? There are plethoras of studies exposing dramatic differences in male and female cognition. Why are we so against this idea that men and women are different? Why can't we simply accept (and perhaps even celebrate) the fact that men and women are different instead of trying to forcefully androgenize society by assuming that a 50/50 gender split in the global population ought to translate to a 50/50 gender split in every single populace (be it STEM or a different one), and subsequently trying to enforce an eve n gender split based on the notion that women are psychologically identical to men?

Looking back, don't you think both sides of the argument were getting high off of self-gratification though? I mean, isn't classifying someone as part of an oppressive group because of the shirt he wears and disparaging him because of it, asserting oneself in a hierarchy? Of historical oppresors, the do-ggoders, and at the top of the pyramid, the historically oppressed? That's what I think some people have against SJW's. Granted, some people who don't like SJW's are just straight up awful people, sexists, racists, homophobes etc, but I think that some people who are annoyed at them occasionally, myself included, are annoyed because we see in their rhetoric the same system of 'self hierarchy assignment' that hate groups use, the only difference is their order is the reverse of the status quo. They patronizingly hold traditionally oppressed peoples up on a pedestal, below them are the righteous warriors of justice, the enlightened, the humble do-gooders, and at the bottom are the traditionally privileged. Now as I say, I don't hate social justice or most people that espouse it, but at the core of the movement, at the core of most movements actually, is the so-called self-hierarchy assignment that you described, and only attributing this behavior to the pro-shit side of this argument shows a deep lacking of self-awareness.
