"Media is filled with images of female sexuality"

Female SEXUALIZATION*

Thought you had some interesting insight till you so easily handwaved every criticism of shirtgate with such odd arguments. Saying women have been so subtly conned out of STEM professions that the cultural push is nearly undetectable is a heck of an assertion to make, and even stranger that the supposed "secret of sexism" is that oppression = pleasure. It makes so little sense when you aim that at the mass amounts of women that are apparently finding pleasure in being oppressed according to such an idea. It's just as silly when you put the ultimatum of, "Does this annoy or threaten you?" only to see most responses hit back with a declaration of "I'm annoyed.". If you're trying to grasp the secret of sexism you need to categorize it, because this video attempts to draw insight into subtle subconsciou s sexism and overt "I love to hat e" sexism and tries to package them together in one incident with little success.

I don't think you needed to suggest that people feel threatened, or at the very least I think you used the wrong choice of vocabulary. I think you could've just stopped at the fact that it's so ingrained in our culture that it is basically invisible, that it's the neutral status quo, and that people react because it's unusual whenever it's departed from. Suggesting that people are feeling threatened is more likely to just return knee-jerk responses because suggesting that someone is feeling threatened is a threat to their position of power and dominance.

Let me make a counter-proposition, women aren't being driven away from stem by subliminal messages, they are being driven toward something else by positive messages. Here's the thing, we should know by now that negative messages don't drive people away from a subject, if you are bombarded by negative or repellant messages you are only driven closer to what cannot be obtained. This was the driving force behind most civil rights actions in the first place. Because humans are driven toward that which they are told they cannot have, it makes no sense to suggest that women are driven out of stem by negative messages, we must assume they are being driven toward something else. If you buy your daughter a barbie, it's not out of the malicious desire to see her conform to femininity, but because it is something you think that she would like. Girls, like boys, figure out what other people think they should like and accept or reject such notions based on their relationship to the suggestive figures. If dad who you love gives you a barbie and is happy and wants to see you happy then you associate barbie with happiness because clearly that's the effect the object is meant to illicit. If parents are guilty of assigning a sex to their daughters through the objects they give them, it's only because generally that's what they are told girls will want. So a person determines part of her identity by observing what other people expect them to want and conforming to that notion or rejecting it. Most parents are shown by commercials that their children want ovens, toy babies, and nurse tools because most adult women go into culinary or nursing professions or else identify themselves as mothers. Likewise when women are given these objects and expected to find joy in them they are taught to associate cooking, nursing, and motherhood with joy. So if the above far more likely premise is valid then some random scientists shirt isn't harmful, you're just using that baseless supposition to criticize an irrelevant detail because you see malice where there is none. After all, we are not slaves to subliminal messages, as Sarte would suggest we are radically free. If fewer women are in STEM it's not because they're given a message that it's a boys club, it's that they don't pay much attention to it at all because it's not related to what they form emotional attachments to typically. If you want more women to go into stem, don't complain about some random scientists harmful shirt, start marketing chemistry sets for girls that are... you know... regular chemistry sets.

Obviously if women cared about science then they would comment on this tremendous scientific development but instead they chose to make an insidious and petty attack on the basis of a tacky shirt. Feel free to wear a shirt with attractive men on it, we won't crucify you.
Oh jeez I had to watch this video twice to get everything you said.
You are vile.

I say this with all recently earned respect (I am up early tomorrow and your fantastic videos have kept me up far too late :-) )but I think you miss the mark on this one. By equating the act of wearing the shirt with an act of pleasurable dominance you are stretching an idea to breaking point. Perhaps the scientist just likes garish shirts with eccentric designs. This one happened to feature scantily clad women. Perhaps it is merely an expression of his outgoing, buffoonish personality, rather than an act of intrinsically satisfying dominance. I can't say - I don't know the man. But neither do you and to argue either way is just speculation and should be noted as such. Also your attempt to somehow equate his behavior with the stats about women not entering stem is at best a reach and at worst somewhat disingenuous. Your dismissal of women who are not bothered by the shirt is also pretty troubling. I can tell you exactly what I thought about the event of 'shirtgate'. Firstly I was mildly irritated that a great scientific achievement was being overshadowed by one man's (admittedly awful) taste in clothing design. Then I was shocked, horrified and dismayed at the disproportionate response by his critics. A response that, need I remind you, drove the man to break down and cry in public. I can do the empathy exercise and imagine being a young woman eager to enter a stem field. I guess I would find his choice of shirt extremely irritating and boorish and when combined with all the other media stories about sexism in x,y,z field it may have a demotivating factor. But I also know that if I was truly passionate about my chosen field I would not let things like this dissuade me from entering it. And if I still possessed any sort of moral grounding I would not be demonizing the man or trying to force an apology from him. Was his dress inappropriate for a Public work event? Yes. Was the fact that there were pretty women on his awful shirt an indicator that this man is sexist? No. Poorly attuned to the needs of others, a bit clueless and certainly not likely to win an award for SJW of the year, but not sexist. The vituperative response of his critics revealed far more about them than it did him.

It's all kind of hilarious. Due to moralistic, Christian societies everyone gets really upset and does armchair women's studies when sexy women appear on a shirt. If people didn't have such a negative view of sex in this culture, this shirt would not have been an issue. Also, this video has some pretty big logical loops you had to jump through to approach your argument. Asked simply: how do divides in descriptive statistics about women and men in STEM have any impact on the argument of whether he should or should not have worn that shirt? To illustrate why this is ridiculous: there is a gender gap for teachers in the US. The majority of US teachers in K-12 schools are female. Does this mean a female teacher shouldn't wear a skirt because by doing so she is implicitly asserting that you need to wear a skirt and be part of the girl's skirt club to be a teacher? It's damn arbitrary to start pulling connections like these out o f thin air based only upon the existence of discrepancies.

Your analysis is even headed, but I don't think you understand why many people are annoyed. As a person that actually works in STEM, there were several things that annoyed me about this situation.

For starters, it's how the public missed the real story. A person, whose team lead us to the next milestone in space exploration, is telling you all about it and all you care about is a shirt. I won't even bother with thought experiments on changing the roles. Just the fact that everyone is talking about the shirt is just so depressing. For me, this highlights in the most obvious way how backwards our priorities are.

But the thing that gets to me the most is how counter-productive this discussion has been. We, who work in STEM, care about the lack of women. It affects us daily on a personal level, not just in the abstract way that SJWs try to "fix" things. Many of us have invested effort in bringing in more women to our field. Every practical reason not to join has been removed and the only remaining obstacle seems to be that women think there would be something wrong if they joined. It is a matter of perception and this whole story reinforced the problem tenfold. Not the shirt, mind you, but the reaction to the shirt. The shirt may or may not have been noticed by some women, who may or may not have cared. But the message that got heard by everyone was when SJWs started screaming about how unwelcoming the STEM fields are. Now, more women think STEM is bad for them than ever before. So much progress was undone in the name of making things better.

replies.commentText: +DarKMaTTeR I hate to say this but many women I've worked with in the past are more interested in selling Avon, gossip and hosting get togethers than any STEM career path. They usually whine about "sexism" but spend most of their time socializing.  It sounds awfully sexist, and I wouldn't have believed it until I saw it with my own eyes.  Of course, there are exceptions, but they are few compared to women as a whole.
+DarKMaTTeR Shut it. You're using reason and logic. We can't allow that here.

+DarKMaTTeR I don't really care to look up the term for it, but aren't people instinctively drawn to sexual stimuli? Regardless of whether the shirt is offensive or not, it definitely evoked female sexuality. Also, why did the guy have to wear a shirt like that to an interview? That's just not a professional choice.

@ Snowflake Productions There's no such thing as a professional way to dress for engineering positions. Most engineering positions don't have a dress code. Even for presentations and fieldwork, engineers wear whatever they would wear in front of friends. You assume he chose to wear this on TV, as if to make a point. In reality, he just came to work like any other day, not expecting to be judged by shallow people.

+Nepthu Can I point out that this can be due to the fact that you're likely seeing a very similar group of people? Or that this could be attributed to gender roles or societal norms people are taught to have from a VERY young age that later presents itself in adulthood? If I'm surrounded by male high school drop outs can I truly say that this is indicative of men being uninterested in school?

+DarKMaTTeR I disagree. People can understandably expect people to show up wearing clothing that is respectful, even if there is no written law for what to wear. If he had been wearing a shirt with a racial slur, or a lewd image he would have been similarly torn apart. Interviews don't require a suit and tie or pant suit and yet people dress accordingly. Choosing what you wear, while more of a routine, is a conscious choice we make everyday.

@Danny Berrios You're just wrong. I think it is safe to assume you're not an engineer, otherwise you'd be very familiar with the kind of person I described. Most engineers simply don't reflect on how they look before doing something.

@DarKMaTTeR I never claimed to be, however I'm certain that another engineer could come here and completely state the opposite. That's just plain common sense. I'm also certain that I could find a female engineer (more than one probably) who is completely outside of this image you have of them and some that do in fact fit that image. You, and certainly everyone including myself have created narratives that fit the biases we have formed for ourselves. However the problem is assuming that those narratives are factually correct outside of our small spheres of experience.

@DarKMaTTeR I apologize, because I thought I was replying to a different comment you'd made (not about the shirt which is where the sphere comment started).

That said. I specifically mentioned that these spheres are things EVERYONE has to check themselves on. I even mentioned myself if you'll recall.

However the problem isn't informal wear. It obviously isn't. He could have been wearing a t-shirt with beer stains and it wouldn't have gotten nearly as much the media/critical backlash it has. He specifically wore a shirt that even by informal standards is questionable. I'd argue that he shouldn't have gotten flayed alive, but I think that's endemic of myself not wanting people beaten down over mistakes when simply calling him out on it could have sufficed.

His shirt however did invite that kind of backlash and him being called on it is entirely within the realm of people being upset. And I believe that if people are upset it is not unreasonable. The shirt is questionable. Whether I, you or he has a problem with it is irrelevant because it might not affect us personally.

You admitted that the engineer field is looking to be more inviting to women. Fantastic. But if "women" are telling professionals in the field that they still don't feel comfortable then that's an issue. That's not something you sweep under the rug because you (and I mean the field) did as much as they thought was necessary. The point isn't to change what the field thinks is the issue, its to change what women think are the issues because it directly effects them. 

But lets agree to disagree. And leave it at that.

@Danny Berrios Perhaps it wasn't clear enough in the original post, so I'll elaborate. We're not talking about sweeping things under the rug. If there is an actual problem, we'd like to address it. The women who are experiencing STEM fields from the inside don't complain about anything in particular. In fact, everyone I've talked to has told me that she found things to be much better than she was led to believe. If women engineers were actually reporting problems, trust me, we'd be all over it. But the complains don't come from people who know what they are talking about. They come from outsiders who have bought into the myth that STEM is unwelcoming and are looking for confirmation. Out of millions of engineers, occasionally someone will do something of poor taste and everyone will jump on the hate wagon, loving it because it reaffirms their stereotypes. Then they teach those stereotypes to young girls, who then conclude that STEM isn't for them. I've worked for an entertainment company for a month, and for a marketing team for 3 months, and in both of those cases I saw mor e sexism that I've seen from every engineer I know combined. B ut nobody is looking at those fields asking why they're not listening to women and putting a leash on all the pervs. It doesn't fit a stereotype, so people are very quick to forgive and forget.

@DarKMaTTeR But again that is from your potentially limited experience. YOU have never met people who have complained however that is not in anyway indicative of the larger trend. And you can't possibly think your experiences perfectly reflect STEM as a whole. It's just not rational to assume that on either side.

You also can't say that no one is looking at marketing teams or entertainment companies.

@Danny Berrios
Your type of reasoning expects people to replace what they experience with what someone else tells them to think. Many times these "sexist" studies are funded by organizations that are trying to buttress their own beliefs from the onset.

@Nepthu All I'm putting forth is to remember that personal experience is exactly that, personal experience. Inductive logic requires multiple pieces of evidence before a theory can be made. I don't deny that what he has put forth is his personal experience nor that there are people who blow occasions like this out of proportion. However to call any level of sexism in ANY field a myth based only on what I have seen or what MY friends believe is unreasonable because as comments in this very thread prove it is not a universally held thought even among members of STEM fields. As to the second point. I'd argue that the people doing those studies are typically directly effected by some form of sexism as much as people who directly oppose those ideas aren't or don't define it the same way. It's up to each reader of said studies to look at the facts and methods used and determine whether or not it was reasonably without bias. Also to determine whether they're reading said studies from the source or opinion articles in newspapers.
@Danny Berrios I don't understand what you are getting at. Can a sample of 200 hundred engineers be skewed? Only in theory.

+DarKMaTTeR Most of what I read were MRA types bashing the SJWs and making aggressive threats and denigrating videos towards women and their cringe at this term but here it goes white knights. Everytime something like this happens, it is always the men who attack the women and female supporters that scare me away from discourse, not the original complainers. The DOXXing and death threats, the hostile attacks, etc. It is really scary to read that kind of stuff online, even if I did not believe that this leads to real life violence. Ugh. It is hard to explain, but one great example would be Anita Sarkeesian. As soon as an issue is brought up, there is this huge backlash of men fighting against the person and their ideas; The terrorizing of the person and those that support them is what keeps me in my place.

+DarKMaTTeR It's hard to explain the nuance between someone who is fighting for women's rights and someone who attacks that person if you do not understand why women fear men in the first place. I would encourage you to take a look at violence stats both within the US and worldwide as a starting point. I am a rational person and as a rational person, I understand that online threats rarely turn into anything serious, but the real violence of men on women is the framework of the world in which these threats happen. That is a form of terror that some cannot fathom, but most women understand. In short: When there is backlash to women pointing out injustices, the backlash does more damage to the side that is trying to fight back feminists than the feminists do towards my views on the world. Meaning, even if the message might have seemed uneven, the attackers bring home the need for more social justice warriors, but actual offline ones who fight against the system which allows the harm to continue. I hope I've explained the situation from my perspective as a woman who is just a regular person, not in any movement, but an observer.

+DarKMaTTeR But Dark Matter, what I'm trying to tell you as a woman who saw this drama unfold is that the pointing out of the shirt being sexist did not deter me from being in a male-dominated field. The men who attacked the SJWs are the deterrent. The SJWs do not scare me and most do not affect me at all; It's mostly complaints and pointing out of various unfair stuff to certain degrees, most of which I ignore anyway or just accept. The  hardcore bashing of women as a reaction to the SJWs, however, is doing the real harm. The violence-talk and aggressive attacks on anyone who brings up feminism or women's issues is downright scary. It makes men look bad and fields dominated by men become terrifying to even consider. I refuse to believe that men are that horrible, but the impression those that attack SJWs in such emotionally triggered manners leads me to believe that male-dominated professions are dangerous to woman, or at least downright unwelcoming. Personally, I wish I went into Biology which was a great interest of mine in school, but I had some bad experiences with male colleague on the university level. I started in the Physics department because I did well in the AP class for it at my high school and the teacher got me into a good university program on scholarship; However, when I got there, I didn't get the support I needed so I switched out to the liberal arts. I regret my decision and wish I attended an all-female school instead. I sincerely hope you are right about the changes you speak of in your earlier comment, because I could not find any mentors, and fellow male students were inappropriate around me (sexually mostly, but also skeptical of my abilities, talked over me a lot and i got excluded from study groups--sigh). It was not easy being alone at a difficult university and feeling isolated. I met lots of great women in Sociology, so that's the path I took. It's not the one I wanted most, but it was a lot friendlier at the time. But thank you for caring enough to help mentor and respect the women in STEM. I hope there are more people like you who will believe in the young women that try to break barriers and give them the much-needed support that I never got.

+DarKMaTTeR Thats funny because as women, the clothes we wear is always a huge topic of discussion. Look at Hilary Clinton and Sarah Palin in 2007... @Phlowerchyld

+DarKMaTTeR As a woman, I would feel unwelcome if a speaker wore a shirt like that to any event I attended. Not because it doesn't match some suit-and-tie dress code, but because it's unnecessarily alienating to people you would in theory want attending your presentation without pause. Are you a STEM worker?@DarKMaTTeR

@DarKMaTTeR
Oh, I thought you were just another anonymous know-it-all.

@Annie Trinity   "I don't see how WHAT the person was talking about is relevant to my perspective on what's appropriate for a conference."  Any random passer-by could cut in and start saying they're offended by this and that. It doesn't give them any authority or power on the community. You don't have to inform your perspective by who's talking. You only have to understand that your opinion will be rightly ignored when it is not relevant. You're not part of the community, therefore you do not get to dictate the rules by which we operate. Believe it or not, there are millions of women working in the field and they're all adults. Our HR departments are open for them to voice their concerns, and most of the time the reaction is to their satisfaction. And HR departments are staffed mostly with women, who do care about appearances. If the women in STEM don't care about the things that you do, then we don't care either. Why on earth would we ever care to be attractive to people, who never seriously considered a career in STEM? "doesn't that mean the women you're citing are essentially "the ones left"?" We're very aware that this can play a part, as we are aware that this cannot be but a small part. We're much more worried about losing women who do fit, but they are lead to believe by people with no personal experience that they will be mistreated. There aren't women leaving at any noticeable rate because they couldn't handle the dresscode. Surely, if your point was good, some would have joined and found things to be worse than they thought. In reality, they all find things to be normal. Not to mention that men can be just as preoccupied with clothes, but men aren't bothered either. It is a far more likely explanation that analytical minds, which tend to make good scientists and engineers, are also not inclined to cater to emotions and appearances. Did you know that engineering positions used to have "normal" dresscodes, but companies are relaxing them in order to attract better engineers? I've heard of employers who now explicitly ban formal clothes, so as not to make coworkers uncomfortable. You may think your dresscode is good and ours is bad, but we think the exact opposite. It turns out that not every personality type is attracted to every field of work. We're not trying to impose our style onto your fields, so why are you pushing yours on us?

@DarKMaTTeR "So why are you pushing yours on us?" I'm... not. I'm SHARING. I'm not demanding you do anything; you're right; it's not my place. That doesn't mean you couldn't possibly gain anything from listening to me. We are BOTH outside of the sweet spot on the Venn Diagram of who this concerns. I could just as easily flip this around and say "Well you're not a woman, so shut up, u dont no" but I'm not. Because how the scientific community operates is something I have no experience with, and therefore I should listen when someone speaks about their experience, even though yours is going to be only one subjective vantage point of many. So if you really have an analytical mind, I assumed you would feel the same and therefore, you know, might be interested in hearing the WHY behind what a woman might object to, the REASONING behind the descenting point of view. Especially because you still actually DON'T seem to understand what the actual issue is. You're still conflating casual attire with non-antagonizing attire. We're not talking about a guy wearing a Hawaiian shirt; no one would GIVE A SHIT if it was just a Hawaiian shirt. It's a more extreme example, but if the shirt had pictures o f black slaves picking cotton, would you still be trying to defend it? And speaking of giving a shit, clearly there was at least one person who is more a less a part of your community who was bothered by it. Because feminists aren't psychic; if it came to the attention of people who were only interested in the shirt, it was because at least one person watching the presentation was upset by it enough to speak up. Just now remembering what the original comment said, I chimed in because either you or someone else was claiming it was the attention being called to the shirt scaring away women from the field, not the shirt itself. And I chimed in because that's horseshit. It's the "talking abo ut racism is racebaiting" argument. If women ARE being driven away, then getting inside the head o f a woman being offput by all of this (which is pretty damn easy for me), no, it's definitely the shirt. So. Are you going to do the very reasonable thing of just hearing the perspective of one woman and filing it away upstairs for next time you make a judgment call about what's appropriate (In case you're wondering, yes, I am doing the same about you saying your female colleges said they weren't upset) or are you going to continue to only take into consideration  the perspectives of people who agree with you and/or exist outside the demographic in question the same way YOU exist outside the demographic in question?

@Annie Trinity
Great comment, Annie. DarkMatter doesn't believe in the listening part of communication.
@Nepthu I know it sounds shallow, but would you mind giving me a like then?

@Annie Trinity

Don't reproduce myths by commenting without knowing.

+Nepthu In the video he mentions the fact that 60% of STEM degrees go to women yet they end up being far less than that (forgot what he said, 30?) in the work force.  So while you may have observed that, perhaps even accurately, that is an anecdotal anomaly.  Actual statistics of what women choose to do with their time would suggest they are more interested in going into STEM than men are.

+DarKMaTTeR Actually Danny is right, and being in STEM yourself I am sure you understand the difference between the personal observation that Nepthu offered and the studies such as those cited by the video's author showing that there is a good turn out of women interested in going into STEM. A sample of 200 (20,000?) engineers would be skewed for the very reason he cited. They are not hired. Women are funnelled out at every level and we can see empirically that it is not because they are less interested or less capable.

+DarKMaTTeR In all honesty you're right. I'm an engineer as well, mechanical to be exact, and when you have people isolated for long periods of time they just don't really care about anything other than getting their work done. Also, I heard he wore the shirt because it was my for him by a friend that kept him motivated, however take that with a grain on salt

@160p2GHz Your reasoning has hidden in it a very sneaky pitfall of statistics, that most untrained people are tricked by. You can't just combine numbers from uneven things and say you're reasoning about the whole. STEM is by definition a combination of uneven things. I don't know how to explain this simply, except with a example. Let call it a hypothetical example, because I'm too tired to pull up the official numbers, but I do remember the numbers approximately. Computer Science has a 15-25% female students (depends on country, university, year etc) and the same exact representation in the work workforce, as far as the new generation goes. Another STEM field, biology, has 60-70% female students and the same representation in the workforce. However, employment prospects for computer science are much better than biology. When carelessly merging the numbers from the two fields, it looks like a woman is less hirable, but it has nothing do with the fact that she is a woman and everything to do with the career she tried to pursue. If you look it up, you'll see that the STEM fields that are popular among women are also among the least profitable. So, no, you don't have evidence that women are being blocked from the workforce. This tricky case of statistics has tricked almost every researcher the first time. It's not you fault if you were tricked (unless you studied a science, in which case shame on you). but it is the same mistake that lead feminists to claim that a woman gets paid 23% less for equal work. So be careful, if you want to be correct. If you want to erase the disparities, not just in STEM, you need to stop beating on employers and the workplace, and start beating on those who bring up women to make poor career choices.

+DarKMaTTeR I agree 100%. I am also in STEM, a salesman of scientific solutions, and I dont see the "professionalism" evident in the dress code; I see it in the intellectual contributions made to the field by both women and men. We have men that wear goofie shirts and let their chest hair hang out, we have women that wear over tight pants and shirts and reveal their cleavage. This is ok. We respect each other for each others intellect, contributions, and passion, not for dress codes. As a salesman, I can not be repelled by a woman who bends over and has a thong hanging out, or a man that looks too casual. I have to find the good and the value in every person I deal with. I feel like this whole situation was critiqued by fashionistas. STEM people tend to be pretty quirky, the world can learn to deal with it.

@160p2GHz There have been numerous articles, statistics that show women often want more flexibility in the workforce. Many people get a degree and then get a job in an unrelated field. To be honest, there's no reason why women should HAVE to go into STEM jobs or any job for that matter. If women aren't staying in those jobs, it's their choice. We don't live in a society that forces people into certain careers. Also, when men are the minority in careers such as nursing or teaching, you hear a lot less complaints about it. Somehow, it's only a problem when women are a minority but not men.

+DarKMaTTeR Okay, this debate has been dead for a month, but I'd like to point out that you, too, seem to be falling into a sneaky pitfall - the survivorship bias. From your sample of women who work in the STEM fields, you argue that the women interested in STEM are not bothered by what outsiders bring up as cultural problems. I believe your observation to be more or less correct, but I'm not certain your explanation is (though it is a valid hypothesis).

Your hypothesis seems to be that an interest in STEM subjects and not having a problem with these issues is in some way or form correlated with each other (and thus, the culture is not really a problem). From your observations of the women that work in the STEM fields, there definitely seems to be one, whether there's a direct causal link or some underlying variable that affect them both.

However, another possible explanation is that the women who do care are somehow selected against. Only the women who do not find the culture problematic "survive" to become your colleagues, while the ones who do experience it as hostile to women drop out, to study other fields instead, meaning that the observed correlation is spurious.

To test which hypothesis best explains the observations, you can't look at the women who work in the field (that would give you a survivorship bias). You have to look at all the women who started out interested in working in the field, figure out how many dropped out, and furthermore why those who dropped out did so.

@Thomas Ueland Torp I understand the point that you are making, but we actually have more data than that. I'll give you a few more pieces. The first part is that women are not dropping out at any significant rate. The reason there are so few of them is that they never begin on this path. The percentage of women employed in STEM is the same as those graduating, which is also the same as those applying for studies. The second part is that "fixing" the workplace changes nothing. Most prominent tech companies and institutions offer incentives and advantages to attract women, on top of an already perfectly balanced workplace. They do big gestures to convince people that they are women-friendly, and nobody has good reason to doubt them. Still, the ratios don't change. It's so hopeless that Google hiring leads know openly say that they will offer advantages to women in the hiring process, in order to skew their ratios towards a 50-50. We know, through years of research, that kids decide at a very earl y age what kind of role they are going to play. They form impression from multiple sources, including media and the general public discussion. The leads in popular movies are the biggest known predictor for what hobbies the next generation will pursue. We don't have the means to create the next Big Bang Theory so that it has better female leads. However, at the very least we can help fix the public discussion, which right now is based on caricatures and no facts. People are just lazily guessing that something bad is going on and then passing it on as a given. The whole discussion is framed in the form of "when are you going to stop hitting your wife?". Girls are watching people have discussion in this context and conclude that they shouldn't be engineers. And then the same people will use the product of their own words as evidence.

+DarKMaTTeR I agree with all of this. My mom and step mom are both engineers and I started down a STEM career path (math is the family tradition) myself before switching to an English major (the only rebellous path left). I'm a woman, and while I can't say that it applies to the whole of STEM fields when I asked other women why they weren't pursuing a STEM job their answers predominantly focused on the fact they didn't think they were 'good enough at x' to pass. A large part of what I personally think the STEMS need isn't more consternation about the dressing and behavioural habbits of mal e engineers (we have enough, we all get the point, reiterations on the subject nowadays feel more clickbait than illuminating) , and more on making the careers seem more 'accessible' as it were. Before I decided to follow my passion (corny I know) one thing I loved to do was show other women how the computer programs I was working on actually functioned. Lots of them thought it was a cool brain teaser of sorts and asked questions, it's just that initial hurdle of 'I'm not nerdy enough for that' that pushed most of them off. Once I showed them it's not nerdy so much as just something they hadn't been exposed to they warmed up to it a bit. One last trend I've noticed in the STEM classes (this is all in Alaska, so while we have an iiittttty bitty sample size the one thing our university is proud of is it's engineering program, go figure) is that, on the large part, most of the people are there for the paycheck once they graduate and get a job. I'm not trying to say that a ll engineers are there for the money (again, family of math nerds, I caught my brother writing theoroms about his reflection) , but I will say that in a profession that's known for earning money and with our current economical situation, most of the people that are willing to pay for the education or go into debt for it do tend to like to think they won't be living under a debt rock their whole life. As a lady in a very lady filled department of my university (seriously, it's a clam bake. me and the other women even go to philosophy department functions just to find men to talk to) we're all dominated by our loves for the subject. Very starving artist follow my dreams stuff. I don't see as many men actually shelling out thousands of dollars of debt to follow their dreams, so it makes sense the more... pragmatic, if you will, jobs are 'manned' more by men than women.
preach it need. PREACH!!!!!!!!!!

+DarKMaTTeR +DarKMaTTeR - I have been reading along, following the varying sides of this discussion, and I find myself agreeing with both of you at different times.

I found one thing you said confusing, would you mind clarifying? So +Annie Trinity suggested that "the women left", or those not currently in STEM fields, are those that might be feeling isolated / whose opinions might be relevant when discussing isolating women from STEM fields (I'm just briefly reiterating what was said so you can frame my question, BTW). You replied saying that that demographic aren't the demographic STEM workers are afraid of isolating; rather, you said that the more important group are those who do fit personally / work in STEM; a large danger is losing those already in the field, who may be mislead into thinking the field is sexist when it's not, in reality.

(CONT IN REPLY... I'm sorry for the long comment by the way, thank you if either of you had enough time to make it this far!) :) ...

+Ms. Jackalope .j. Johnstone (CONT, 2 of 2)... +DarkMaTTeR With that said: if sexism is not inherent in STEM (I don't think it is), and with all acknowledging that it's important for more women to get involved in STEM, why would people be more concerned about losing the women already in the field (as you mentioned: due to their getting the wrong impression about inherent STEM sexism) than they would be about appealing to the untapped pool of girls/women who might pass on STEM all together based on this (supposed) "reputation"? How can fem. STEM workers be mislead by SJW's/media re: their work environments, which they experience firsthand? It doesn't seem that one would have to worry about them being pushed out by misinformation - they can see what is & what isn't true - as much as the future of STEM, thus the pool of women/girls "who are left". So how can the opinions of those STEM is hoping to attract be deemed irrelevant? Why doesn't it matter if some of them found it discouraging?

@Ms. Jackalope .j. Johnstone Your question isn't clear to me, so feel free to rephrase it, if I'm not addressing it. We ARE concerned about the untapped pool of women who are pushed away. That's what I have been arguing about all this time, and if that wasn't clear so far, I have failed. I do not think it is possible to misinform women who are actually working in STEM about their own experience. @Jose RicoTacoNachoQuesadillaMandillaJones﻿ that's true, ideally you wouldn't judge anyone for their clothing choices. i agree with that, it should be that way - fashion does not necessarily reflect character or work ethic. but in the end people do take away some kind of information from what people wear, which is why we have a dress code (and which actually now seems to contradict the whole slut-shaming movement, now that i think about it; don't judge a girl for what she wears, but you can definitely judge a man for wearing a shirt like this. i guess revealing clothes for girls don't really compromise another demographic's agency though, so you could argue this situation is different). anyways, i think in the end it's a tradeoff between your autonomy and the kind of message you send out to the people who work for you/the people who see you on media, so i think some responsibility comes with your clothing choices when you are so renowned and so many people look up to you. like a boss wearing a shirt like this has a much bigger effect on morale than a random person wearing a shirt like that at a grocery store, i suppose

@poopspeeps perhaps you could make a case for that, but here's the thing. there is an absolutely huge push in physics and science in general to get more females into the field and just more people in general. considering how much people want more researchers to join them and become physicists, especially since this is a government funded project, anyone who was causing discomfort would probably have been immediately fired or forced to wear something different. the mere fact that he thought it was acceptable to wear that shows that no one there cared that he wore it. moreover, he didnt deserve any of the shit the media put on him, that was complete bullshit and disgraceful. he cried during his apology for god's sake, why did the issue have to be blown so out of proportion that all that shit happened? even if he did wear that and it was somewhat inappropriate, it did not warrant the entire scandal and coverage provided. it was fucking sickening watching the media talking about him as if he had done some terrible thing and that those accusing him acting like they were the best fucking people in the world

@Jose RicoTacoNachoQuesadillaMandillaJones﻿ yeah, i agree, it was definitely blown out of proportion and kind of was a crucifixion, which i'm not happy with at all. he is by no means a bad person, and he has done so much for science. the push for women in science is only recent, so we see leveling out happening in recent years - i think it's a good push. i suppose for the push to fully be in effect there are cases like this that happen that are over the top, but i think once demographics even out they shouldn't happen anymore. to put this into perspective, there are thousand of sexual assault and sexual abuse cases that are swept under the rug and never get any attention in the scientific field, and once in a while a single case gets a ton of attention - i guess that's just how media works. (even with th e black rights matter movement). also remember that it really was only a couple of years ago when many schools did not accept women into their universities, so discriminatory practices were in place a lot earlier than you think.

@Jose RicoTacoNachoQuesadillaMandillaJones﻿ also i think it's difficult to relate to the push if you haven't experienced it, so even i couldn't relate to it for a while. but when i compare a field where there is a push and where there isn't, i can really feel the difference. i'm a female studying neurobiology and chemistry, and i'm working to be on the md-phd track. this was pretty much a smooth path for me because i never really felt discriminated against at all, it was a very welcoming and natural course where i felt like i could do my best! (there was one time when my lab tech told me that i had joined a "boys club" - my lab - and socially it took me a long time to fit in because of that, but putting in extra effort really isn't enough to deter me from something i love as much as research) in contrast, when i was in 4th grade i had a passive interest in chess and math and joined the chess and math clubs respectively. i was the only girl there, and there isn't that huge of a push in these fields i think - or it's a lot more recent of a push than it is in fields like biology and chemistry, which i think are much more gender neutral (biology moreso than chemistry). of course as a kid i wasn't passionate about math or chess or anything, i was just trying it out, but since i didn't see anyone like me and i picked up on subtle unwelcome language cues and couldn't relate to the people around me that much, my kid self thought the fields weren't my thing and i ended up never pursuing those fields. it's sad that i still don't think math is my thing even though i took diffeq and multivariable calculus in my junior year of high school and did quite well in the classes, but i think once you internalize that something isn't your thing it's hard to get out of it. i think the point of the shirt being such a big deal is that small cues like this can really push someone out of a field, especially when they're in this entry-level stage of trying to find out what they like. he doesn't deserve the brunt of all this force, but i think people are trying to find a way to not let "small things slide" or get pushed under the rug, and this is what ends up happening

no no, you weren't condescending at all! you've actually been very open minded and it's nice hearing your perspective, so don't worry about it! are you in a scientific field by any chance?

universities started opening to women internationally in the very early 20th century, right at the turn of the century. very undergraduate focused with small strides in phd-level education. in the US many of these strides were made by cornell, which is really nice! (go cornell!) of course after the universities have been officially opened it takes many years for the numbers to start leveling out, so maybe this graph will help put it a bit more into perspective? http://beckerexhibits.wustl.edu/mowihsp/images/ChartC .jpg it's really not too long ago that this significantly low percentage of professional stem-related degrees conferred to women started to pick up, at least from my perspective  (since the generation from that time is still alive, and some are still part of the workforce - that's my standard of recent). regardless, while the university-level gap has closed over pretty nicely, there still is a gap in the percentage of men and women who work in stem-related jobs (even though it's much smaller when you look at stem degree holders), so there are just all these levels that we have to address and it's difficult to get them all.

commentThread.commentText: I generally like your way of thinking, but not here.You and others reframe the discussion to thing like domination... after talking about statistical enrollment facts re. STEM and gender. Yet you ignore the same facts about construction, mining, the military, etc. The dangerous career fields. The number facts are not because of a women-intimidating culture. A male-heavy culture exists as a result of the male majority in certain fields, simple, do not get cause and effect mixed up. Research the enrollment in college and university programs -- in general the different genders take different programs for different reasons. In general men want to provide for women and a future family and so enter fields enabling room for growth in that desire -- yes even today after decades of "feminism", it is still expected by society and peers ( though communicated in more subtle ways than in the 1950s etc.) Women do not have an equivalent drive or societal expectation -- so they (most, obviously not all) enter non-STEM programs, for various reasons... without a strong requirement to actually do something career-wise with that education. Because WOMEN always have the option to be "taken care of" by a man -- an option that is very much not available equally to the other gender. THAT is an I convenient truth, but thankfully more and more are willing to point this kind of truth out. Even at the risk of being shamed or ridiculed or shouted down -- irrational emotional methods of silencing an opposing view. (Pause...) Which says a lot about the view held by the shamers.

I'm generally on the progressive side of these things, but I still don't understand how a shirt with images of idealized sexy women conveys a "women don't belong in STEM," message. I've considered that it might be perceived as communicating "it is the norm that women are sexy, therefore women should focus on just being sexy, and not anything else," but if that was the point the opponents of the shirt were making, then they would not only arrive to the conclusion that it dissuades women from getting into STEM, but that it dissuades women from doing any careers outside of things like acting, modeling, porn, and other careers that largely revolve around physical appearance. No one is making such a broad claim though, so what am I missing?
I also dislike the claim that bigotry is pleasurable being made without supporting evidence or argument. Would be an interesting subject for research; it would require some kind of video game, and something that reads brains like an FMRI.

commentThread.commentText: First world problems.

At 2:40 you talk about statistics saying that women earn 60% of all graduate degrees, yet make up only 25% of the STEM fields.

This statistic shows more than one fact.
1. Women are in the lead when it comes to graduate degrees,
2. Women are trailing behind when it comes to positions in STEM fields.

This video felt a lot like it emphasizes more on fact number 2 than it does on fact number 1, which just isn't something I feel is correct.
If we truly want each field to be equal, than surely fact 1 is just as important as fact 2.

I agree 100% with the idea that sexism is pleasurable. From an early age we teach that girls and boys are borderline separate species. We create a group identity, a tribe almost. We cling to ou r sex as part of who we are. It's like a subculture. Take metal and punk. The two musical subcultures LOATHED each other in the 80's. Why? In a lot of ways they're similar genres, so why such hostility? Because both groups thought that their genre was better and fans of the other genre were worse. As someone who as recently as January this year was a huge metal elitist, I can say with 100% confidence that that kind of tribal superiority complex is SUPER rewarding. Not a morally good thing to do, but it sure feels good
Yes, but it is also empowering/ pleasurable (to some) to point out something as petty as a fashion choice in order to denigrate others within their imagined hierarchy.
Way to overcomplicate the issue.

Funny thing that the social justice people want to climb to a position of power and enforce their belief on others. They want to attain the "pleasure" you speak of, and that is somehow fine, because there's some arbitrary consensus that what this people do is "right." It is not right. Or wrong, really. It just is, like most everything else in life.

The social justice crowd are just humans, live everyone else, no matter how much they claim the opposite and to hold some philosophical and moral high ground. As simple humans, like the rest, they are greedy, power thirsty, selfish, and all the other qualities that we may at some point or another consider negative in a human being. Therefore, allowing them to ascend above others is just trading one evil for another.

However, the social justice movement is arguably worse. I see it as a guilded cage. Yes, there may be many, many benefits. But these benefits are enforced. You will have them whether you want them or not. Contrary to what they claim, once again, the social justice movement is quite oppressive and authoritarian. Are some of their ideas good? Yes. Should we allow them to govern us? No. Should we then allow things to stay as they are? Of course not. But, a measure of moderation is required, and that is something I have yet to see from the social justice crowd.

The way forward is to try to eliminate blame from the conversation. When one feels their innocence attacked, there tends to be a tendency towards defensiveness and hostility. Cognitive dissonance disrupts the assimilation of information. What are the elements of the behavior pattern, and how do we change it? If the approach is less personal, if we ask each other for help in understanding and value the opinions of others, communication can be achieved.

replies.commentText: +Briar Blackbourne Wait, what? Didn't you hear about the 25% that came afterwards? The point is that even though women are massively getting degrees, the amount of those women able to get a job are... Really low. And it's not about scarcity in jobs, because the 40% of men are still able to get 75% of the jobs. It's about culture: STEM fields are still male-dominated, and that on itself perpetuates the idea that women aren't as able at those jobs, and are thereby less likely to be hired, even when they are as qualified as the men they're up against. The shirt is one of the many symptoms of the so-called boys club that keeps the gender disparity alive: the objectification of women displayed on his shirt can make women feel uncomfortable, and they'd be seen as 'too sensitive' if they were open about not liking it, and maybe even judged as less competent as a result of it. This way, only the women who either don't care or don't speak up survive in the business. Furthermore, it's a double standard: Matt Taylor has said he didn't get called out on wearing the shirt because people cared about his work, not his clothes. Meanwwhile, female scientists are judged based on their clothes all the time.

+Anouk Fleur Briar's point was that college is dominated by females statistically. Nerdwriter brings up the point that there aren't many females in STEM degrees while completely disregarding the 3:2 ratio of women to men in college. Take a look at other degrees and you'll find that there is imbalance everywhere, male and female.

+Anouk Fleur  Why aren't we more concerned that men aren't graduating college at the same level women are?

What's all this junk about women not being able to get the same jobs men get? Numerous studies have shown that some women choose to gasp raise a family after college than pursue their career.  Others want career flexibility. 

Again, why insist that women are getting the short end of stick? Men aren't attending or graduating college at the same percentage women are. There should be some affirmative action that helps men obtain their degree.  We'd do it for any other minority.

Well said. I agree.

I think he brought it up not to highlight a discrepancy in educational opportunity, but a discrepancy in the effectiveness of acquiring job qualifications. I.e., women statistically are attending college more but are also still economically struggling more upon entering the job market; they're getting out of the system less than they put into it when compared to the male population. On the surface level, one would hypothesize that a demographic that has higher rates of education would also have a higher long-term income, and just based on this little bit of information, that's not what we're seeing in this case. But of course, there are a lot more factors at play than just degrees and jobs, and to really unpack the thing would require a crapload more studies and statistics than just those two. It's a very complicated phenomenon.

"...maybe your assumptions are following from cultural norms so invisible, they seem like insights about gender." All we ever hear about any more in both the popular media and the new media is how sexism an d racism run rampant throughout every facet of society, how our collective guilt of bigotry is evidenced solely by differences in outcomes between groups, and how anyone who disagrees with the narrative is blinded by privilege. These so-called assumptions about differences between groups are the complete opposite of invisible. They also happen to have a far more robust support in the realm of fact than the progressive, feel-good assumptions required of dogmatic egalitarianism. "Women earn only 72 cents on the dollar compared to men!" Actually no, when all relevant variables are properly controlled for, such as career field, education, hours worked per week, breaks in career, etc, women earn between 98% and ~101% depending on the study. "Women face massive discrimination in the STEM fields, as evidenced by the huge gap between numbers of men and women employed in the field!" Actually no, a robust and well-performed study earlier this year by two Cornell professors showed that women enjoy overall 2-to-1 advantage when being considered for jobs in the STEM fields.

The problem with issues like this, is that it sets a precedent of victimization. Instead of encouraging girls to do what they believe in, no matter the opposition or discomfort they might face, we encourage them to blame every minor obstacle they could possibly face. In the real world everyone has problems and challenges they have to confront, but our response should be to ignore these challenges, and not make them the center of our focus. Could his shirt be offensive to some women? Yes, of course. But that doesnt hold anybody back from actually becoming a scientist. If anything, this constant culture of victimization has done more harm to gender equality (on both sides) than any shirt ever has.

This did annoy me, and I can tell you why: this shirt was made by a female friend of this guy. Yeah. She went "hey bro, happy whatever special day this is, have this shirt, I made it myself", then he went "I love it, I gonna wear this on that interview about my life greatest achivement". Like, if I cure cancer, I'll have to worry about the fact that I asked my girlfriend to get me a beer on the fridge once, ten years ago?

The thing is I myself would never wear the kind of shirt that the subject of this controversy wore in the interview, nor would I get a similar tattoo, car decal, bumper sticker, etc. I've also never been one to put swimsuit pin-ups or Playboy centerfolds on my wall, and have always been too caught up in Megan Fox's mediocre screen presence to consider her an element that brought me back to a series like Transformers. What I'm saying is whatever supposed "pleasure" is being taken from decorating my day-to-day life with stylized imagery of idealized women, simply isn't a factor in what I'm about as a person, and in that sense, I have nothing to lose in this conversation at the end of the day. But even with all of that, I react to this story with a disdain that I can only categorize (based on the video anyway) as annoyance. Frankly, I'm perplexed that through bringing attention to the apparent pleasures of what some consider minute sexism, people overlook another source of existential excitement: the pleasure of being on a decidedly higher level of justice and morality, the pleasure of exposing the underlying poison of ["seemingly"] benign facets of everyday life, the pleasure of being the good guy in a fight that may in reality amount to little i f nothing at all. And while it is more than worth noting the statistical injustices of women in the workforce and the field of science, the one missing ingredient is what all of it has to do with this one man's shirt. And this is all without mentioning that, through years of meditation and personal questioning, I've worked myself to the point of accepting people's choices of wardrobe, tattoo s, gender identity and bodily modications; and yet, to align myself with the forces of political correctness, I have to draw the line at a type of wardrobe that a certain niche of people decree distasteful and demeaning to an ent ire sex? Who knows though. My status as a straight American male (not all-the-way-white though, so SUCK IT!) might just be blinding me from seeing the underlying maliciousness implied in countless Youtube videos. I say this partially in jest, but I do have the good sense of admitting it could also be a possibility. Like you sir, I too believe it's possible to hold two lines of thought in these conversations. For instance:  I believe in the tree-hugger-hippie notion that we all deserve decency and respect in this wide, chaotic world of ours, regardles s of race, gender or sexuality, and that the opportunities given to one person should not be taken away from another on any of those grounds.....I also think this man should be able to wear whatever he damn well pleases, just as I think a person should get a tattoo of whatever they want, a teenage girl should display shirtless calendars of whatever processed boy-icon she prefers, and women should have the right to see Magic Mike XXL, read 50 Shades of Grey, or, dare I say it, watch porn (all of that, mind you, so long as they don't judge other people in a manner as superficial as said consumed media). * Long comment. But i don't think TLDR belongs in this kind of forum. In any case, I appreciate NerdWriter's content and look forward to watching many more videos. maybe even tonight.

replies.commentText: as a bit of an asterisk, ignoring how tacky it might be to continue like this: Would it perhaps be more productive for all involved if the focus was not on picking which kinds of art should be displayed at what time, but rather educating people on how to separate the media they consume with a truer, more sociologically supported reality. You could argue that such are intertwined to the point of interdependency (i.e. our perceptions of others are largely determined by our immediate environment, including the media), but I honestly feel a few classes here and there about such topics, as well as some simple, controlled self-questioning, would do wonders for our modern society. In other [deliberately oversimplified] words, spend less time highlighting harmful art and more time trying to make smarter people who can consume things in a healthier manner.

I know Tomato's post and most of this conversation are a year old, but I'd also like to throw in my two cents, as I find it disheartening to see these people who have never experienced or witnessed something firsthand speak out as if that means it doesn't happen, and react to a few overzealous feminists as if that's how they all are. That study from Tomato's article found that "women are no longer at a disadvantage when applying for tenure-track positions in university science departments." For one thing, that's nice to hear. For another, that is an extremely niche area within STEM, and one of the most liberal; I'm not surprised it's the first to see such a change. And what exactly do you think drives them to favor women, if not feminists putting up a fuss when women are given the short end of the stick, together with the current imbalance favoring males? Others have mentioned affirmative action, and I'd like to reiterate that the idea is to give those who have had less privilege and opportunity a fair chance versus those who have it better. You say you're annoyed at "how they think they deserve privleges for being part of a minority group"; yet by implying that you don't want to be treated differently from men, you're implying that you want to be treated with the same privilege they are, and that's exactly the point. I can understand the desire not to be treated like a "delicate little flower", but you speak as one of a lucky few who have not been discriminated against (as far as you know) or discouraged by society to enter the STEM field. I'm not trying to say women aren't strong; quite the contrary: they have to be incredibly strong to do what they do in such a world. Props to your strength and skill, and I'm glad you're speaking your mind here. But I think some of the things you're saying might be dangerous to others who have not been so lucky. I want to specifically address +TheAtomicMango and her reply to +U Go Girl: that was incredibly insensitive and ignorant, to insult someone's country without sympathy after they admitted to abuses they've suffered, and then falsely claim that it doesn't happen in ours while flaunting your entitlement that you did nothing to earn. You realize that's a person you're talking to, right? And the USA is in fact at 14th in this (incomplete) list of rapes per million people: [LINK] and 28% of them are committed by strangers: [LINK] I'm especially worried for naive young women like you going to college, where supposedly one in five are sexually assaulted in the USA: [LINK] I'm not trying to scare you, just warn you to be careful. Just because it hasn't happened to you doesn't mean that it doesn't happen, or that it won't. Finally, I think another point worth defending is what he mentions at 2:57 in the video: that much of the trouble is in the way society discourages women from going into STEM in the first place, but people tend to interpret this as inherent differences in the sexes. Nature vs. nurture is a tough question to crack, and I'm sure there are some biological differences, but I reckon it's more nurture than these people think. The influence of media and advertising and the prejudices of parents and society in general starts at a very youn g age and is extremely deep-seated. Take the field of computer science, for example, and see the "Why aren't more women involved in computer science?" section here: [LINK] or this talk that explains it better than I do: [LINK] Thanks for listening.

+Sean H, here are a few reactions to the points you raise. I hope you're interested enough in the topic to want to discuss it. "I find it disheartening to see these people who have never experienced or witnessed something firsthand speak out as if that means it doesn't happen, and react to a few overzealous feminists as if that's how they all are." I also find this a bit much, but then again, the "overzealous feminists" you mention are among the most obvious ones because they're the ones with Tumblr accounts accusing others of all kinds of bigotted and sexist feelings. The feminists who are, say, fighting to improve women's conditions in the Middle East tend to be a little too busy with real-world issues to become as vehement in internet debates. So I'm not surprised that many people know the "overzealous" variety better than other types. "For one thing, that's nice to hear. For another, that is an extremely niche area within STEM, and one of the most liberal; I'm not surprised it's the first to see such a change." Sure, but note that things depend on where you look. I don't think it's "the first" to see such change. In my field (linguistics, somewhere in an orbit around STEM -- see speech recognition technology), there is currently a (slight) majority of women in tenured-track positions, holding scholarships and even actually among students. This higher level of acceptance has been increasing. Certain subfields of biology also have a majority of female researchers. It's not just "the first one" to see such a change; this change has been ongoing, is cascading down the line, and is supported by pretty much everybody, especially in the younger generation. "And what exactly do you think drives them to favor women, if not feminists putting up a fuss when women are given the short end of the stick, together with the current imbalance favoring males?" Sure, but there is a difference between the more visible ('overzealous') feminists, who complain about things that aren't really "the short end of the stick". Besides, I'd claim that a lot comes not from "revolutionary activism" (feminists putting up a fuss), but from internal reflection based on one's own life (having women in your family, talking to them, having peaceful conversations with feminists, equalitarians, etc. about gender questions) without a "fuss." All in all, you have to win hearts and minds -- and "a fuss" is not really the best way to do that. "Others have mentioned affirmative action, and I'd like to reiterate that the idea is to give those who have had less privilege and opportunity a fair chance versus those who have it better." Sure, but if you soften your quality criteria for accepting students, you demolish the meritocracy, and you slowly sap the efficiency and high quality of the education of the institution in question. I'm all in favor of more minorities in all areas of education, but I would rather do this by improving the quality of their basic education so that they don't have any quality disadvantage when applying for higher education -- that seems to me fairer than quotas. "You say you're annoyed at "how they think they deserve privleges for being part of a minority group"; yet by implying that you don't want to be treated differently from men, you're implying that you want to be treated with the same privilege they are, and that's exactly the point." True -- but that is ismply because, in many cases (e.g., affirmative action), what is being asked is not 'the same privileges they have', but actually more or stronger privileges, presumably to offset a disadvantage. I don't think many people these days would subscribe to a gender-centric (non-meritocratic) vision of education ("only for boys"); what upsets people is that measures that are supposed to redress the differences appear to be (and sometimes really are) not doing that, but simply allowing underqualified people to get into institutions where they shouldn't really be, because they were not adequately prepared for them. "I can understand the desire not to be treated like a "delicate little flower", but you speak as one of a lucky few who have not been discriminated against (as far as you know) or discouraged by society to enter the STEM field." 'Lucky few' begs the question of statistics. As I said, in my field, that is not at all the case. We need some hard data here, if we want to argue for the need for some kind of behavior. "I'm not trying to say women aren't strong; quite the contrary: they have to be incredibly strong to do what they do in such a world." Hmmm... Again, this sounds more like chivalry than like hard data. "But I think some of the things you're saying might be dangerous to others who have not been so lucky." Why? And how? I think Tomato is simply saying that people should strive to do their best, and be judged accordingly. To the extent that htis happens -- and I would claim her case is not simply that of a small minority -- she's actually right. You don't protect or help victims by telling them they shouldn't be fighting to improve themselves and get ahead, that it's the world that should be saying "sorry" to them. BOTH things can be true simultaneously, and should happen simultaneously; but so many minority activists strive for the latter without doing much for the former, not even in the form of lip service!... "Finally, I think another point worth defending is what he mentions at 2:57 in the video: that much of the trouble is in the way society discourages women from going into STEM in the first place, but people tend to interpret this as inherent differences in the sexes." Again, I'd like to see some hard evidence connecting these two -- in my field, this is not true at all. "Nature vs. nurture is a tough question to crack, and I'm sure there are some biological differences, but I reckon it's more nurture than these people think." That's a personal opinion. Maybe I reckon it's more nature than nurture. I suppose we need the research here, right? (Notice also that saying something is an innate biological difference doesn't mean we can't change that: as DNA manipulation techniques improve, we should be able to increase and/or decrease any capacity in women, or in men, that we think we should. So biological doesn't mean "unchangeable"). "The influence of media and advertising and the prejudices of parents and society in general starts at a very youn g age and is extremely deep-seated." Again, I'd like to see the research. Personally, I think there is a very complicated relation between the media, prejudices, etc. and the individual. Activists tend to see it as a simple relation: these things are evil, have no good effects, and we should change them fundamentally or get rid of them. Sin ce nothing in life in simple, I am somewhat sketpic about this. I think people influence advertising, the media, etc. just as much as they are influenced by them -- it's a give-and-take relation, not an imposition from above. The media ain't that powerful, and people ain't that weak and impressionable, I reckon. Thanks for your opinions, and have a nice evening!

+Asehpe Hey, this is awesome. I'm certainly interested enough to discuss it, and I appreciate you taking the time to address my points! I hope it's cool that I numbered your paragraphs for brevity, starting with the second one: 1. ("I find it...") Agreed: as in many areas, it's likely the noisy/offensive/melodramatic ones getting a disproportionate amount of the attention that leads to this perception that (I think) errs on the negative side. (Maybe I'm just another one of those.) 2. ("For one thing...") Quite fair: I should have said "one of the earlier ones" or some such. In general, your response makes me wish I'd thought mine out better, which is a welcome lesson. 3. ("And what exactly...") Agreed, and this partly comes down to semantics and what constitutes a "fuss", which admittedly I didn't specify. Regardless, I love your last point—with a nuanced subject like this, winning hearts and minds requires a calm, respectful, patient approach, and outrage and emotion aren't good ways to convince anyone. I don't mean to say yelling and screaming made this happen, yet when I hear that women are twice as likely to be given positions in a department that has historically favored men, I can't help but imagine there's more than purely conscientious motivation involved and, at this point in time, necessary for significant change. (Or maybe I'm overly cynical; regarding universities, maybe, but surely not regarding everywhere.) So the fuss I speak of is the negative attention I think they're partly trying to avoid, and the more visible feminists, though liable to overdo things, do contribute to this. I shouldn't have spoken like it's the only motivator, though. 4. ("Others have mentioned...") 5. ("You say you're annoyed...") Hmm... I do see the same ideal future. As for how to get there, and the arguments for and against affirmative action, I probably shouldn't speak of things I know so little about, so I'm going to shush about it for now. 6. ("I can understand...") Your field aside (though it's nice to hear of the equality; and I think it's fair to call it STEM, what with it being the scientific study of language; and this isn't really relevant but I think it's SUCH A COOL SUBJECT), doesn't the number of women going into STEM positions today count as hard data? Evan mentioned a few statistics at 2:40 in the video. My field is computer science, and though it is gradually changing, it is still massively one-sided, and projected to be so through 2022 (again I quote this site: [LINK] As for arguing for the need for some kind of behavior, I'll save that for paragraph #8. 7. ("I'm not trying...") Ah... Here I probably wanted to dispel the notion that I was being overly patronizing, or chivalrous (a kind way to put it). I do believe what I said, but if that's why I felt the need to say it, it's probably because I was indeed being that way. Ha! Apologies for that. 8. ("But I think...") I heartily concur with all you're saying here, and I don't think it conflicts with what I meant, but I was unspecific, so I'll try to clarify. Let's look at her last sentence in particular: "if a fucking shirt prevents you from doing what you love, may be you didn't love it that much in the first place???" I think I understand her point with the same interpretation as you, that women—like anyone—should stand up for themselves and not expect to be pitied or babied (or infantilized) by anyone. And I'm not arguing that. But in this case, she's also saying if you REALLY want to work in your chosen field, you shouldn't be frightened off by evidence that your peers in that field may well objectify and mistreat you based on what you are, not your merit. (That's what the shirt suggested to me, anyway, as it's something I've known to happen in my field; for a taste, see this blog post by a woman leaving a relatively prestigious position because of its community dynamic—it's not primarily sexism that pushed her out, but that's a part of it: [LINK] The point I take from such stories is that changing a community as one of the minority is incredibly slow and difficult and painful, and not something that anyone should be expected to undertake if they don't have to.) So my issue is that I find this to be a perfectly valid reason for someone not to enter a field, despite being interested otherwise, and thus I find it a failure on the part of the community, not the individual being discouraged from joining it. In other words, when you say both things should happen simultaneously, I completely agree, but I worry that words like Tomato's are helping one while hurting the other, just as those of the overprotective SJWs do in reverse. I imagine for most people it won't make a difference, but for some, it's more ammunition against feminism. All that being said, I can appreciate just about everything Tomato said, especially after hearing your points, and I'm glad it's being said. I just feel that the other side is being under-represented here. (I see your comment above mentioning your willingness to listen, and I appreciate you turning that toward me!) 9. ("Finally...") I think my response to #6 applies here too. 10. ("Nature vs. nurture...") 11. ("The influence...") I suppose we do need the research. Here's a bunch, referenced through a blog post: [LINK] My opinion here also has a lot to do with the femal e engineers in my life. For example, observing the personalities of my mechanical-engineer friend and her materials-scientist sister and hearing how their parents raised them in a purposely gender-neutral way has called into question much of what I once believed to be inherently female traits. And I don't mean to say the adults targeted by advertising, TV, movies, etc. are so impressionable: more so their children. In the end, I reckon (I suppose I am stealing this meaning from southern U.S. colloquialism) that time will reveal the truth: young people, as you mentioned, are especially amenable to these ideas, and it will affect how they raise their own children, y'all. Thanks again for the thoughtful response, and have a good one!

Two thinkers come straight to mind here: Nietzsche's discussion of the genealogy of morality; and Lacan's notion that the history of philosophy is the history of desire - that is, there is something in our ethics that is not part of our moral framework. Forget this and one will practice one's own sadism in blissful ignorance. What shivers of delight so many SJWs feel when they have another person to 'call out'... and this sadism is all the more sadistic - and invisible and powerful - because it is 'doing good' for its subject. This is why, although I didn't like his shirt either, it is absolutely the case that Taylor was crucified by social media.
if no one pointed out that t-shirt there would be no deal at all... but no, click-bait and making a big drama is profitable... most people use any form of controversy just to gain profits.
