You know just like the first two women to complete navy ranger school, or the ever growing women in STEM, they chose to do these things because they wanted to, just as much as the women who chose to enter early childhood education, or the women who decided to pursue those "useful" gender studies degrees.﻿ Edit, January 12, 2016: the reason why men, on average, choose certain jobs that differ from the jobs women choose, and vice versa, is because men and women have different brains. "Females and males maintain unique brain characteristics throughout life. Male brains, for instance, are about 10% larger than female brains. But bigger doesn't necessarily mean smarter. Disparities in how certain brain substances are distributed may be more revealing. Notably, male brains contain about 6.5 times more gray matter -- sometimes called 'thinking matter" -- than women. Female brains have more than 9.5 times as much white matter, the stuff that connects various parts of the brain, than male brains. That's not all. "The frontal area of the cortex and the temporal area of the cortex are more precisely organized in women, and are bigger in volume," Geary tells WebMD. This difference in form may explain a lasting functional advantage that females seem to have over males: dominant language skills." [LINK]

@antiantipoda did you just conflate nurses and doctors, that doesn't make any sense. Notice how you said "nurses do a job almost as qualified as being a doctor" the key word there is almost, and even at that you're completely wrong: "Apart from that, doctors are limited to their specialized field whereas nurses are able to work across several wards or units depending on their job descriptions . Doctors need to be specialized in order to fully assess the roots of an illness or a problem. For nurses, their specialty is more task-oriented and patient-oriented. Once a doctor is convinced that a patient's condition is out of his specialty range, he will refer the patient to a colleague who has a better understanding of that condition. The nurses, however, are to inform the replacement doctor of the patient's condition and subsequently follow up with the patient's progress until he/she leaves the hospital. In addition, nurses enjoy a closer relationship with their patients as compared to doctors since they have more direct contact with th em. Doctors also have a constant need to detach themselves emotionally from a patient so as to be able to continue with their work. As a result, patients will often times identify better with nurses than with doctors, usually showing their preference by the form of the co-operation they offer. On top of that, doctors need to read a lot and thus take a longer time to acquire new and accurate knowledge whereas nurses rely more on their experience to provide the best treatment possible. This is not to say that nurses do not study and advance in terms of education levels. Nurses in fact are able to study for bachelor's degrees, master's degrees and doctorate degrees in nursing. Therefore, the more education a nurse receives, the better the chances of gaining better income levels. This sometimes brings an overlap of authority that becomes a source of disputes b etween doctors and nurses. Doctors generally have authority over their patient's conditions and treatment and will then require the nurses to implement certain procedures. However, when priorities collide, doctors may need to succumb to the authority figures of Head Nurses or Head Units since the latter group has managerial control over a specific ward, floor or unit. The same authority overlap problem also occurs when new p racticing doctors first join a medical facility. Experienced nurses tend to question analysis given by the young doctors since nurses' knowledge is based on actual past experiences, not from theories. Nevertheless, in general, the two share a mutual respect for each other's responsibilities."

+R. Ringshifter Hey guys, what's going on here? You sound confused about the facts... Well, I'm pretty well-educated in (intersectional) feminism, so I'm here to help you out if you'd like. Ask me anything you want to know, I might be able to help you out. Let's begin with the clear question: Why does it matter that STEM fields are male-dominated? First sub-question: Would the shirt be less sexist if STEM fields weren't male-dominated? Here's the thing: If it wasn't a male-dominated field, the shirt-incident never would have happened. Why not? Well, in a field where women are fairly represented and comfortable enough to voice the issues they have at work, he would've gotten called out way before the interview even happened. It doesn't really matter if it would be one of the women to call him out, or one of the regulations that are in place to make women feel accepted; it just doesn't happen in those kinds of places. Proof is empirical, though I accept counter-evidence. This actually goes on to answer the question: the shirt is a symptom of the field being male-dominated, so it makes sense to take the male-dominated factor into account. Also important: the STEM fields being male-dominated is actually something we as a society are trying to fix, mostly by finding ways to encourage girls to enter those studies. But what if all that effort was for naught, because the women that got a degree then don't get jobs? That's where the 60%/25%-disparity comes in: apparently there are factors that make qualified women unable (or unwilling) to get a job. This is because the STEM fields are a 'boys club': a field where the atmosphere is based on what makes men comfortable, gives men easier access to promotion and assumes men's capability, with the opposite being true for women. The shirt is a symptom of the boys' club: none of his male colleagues found personal offense in his shirt's depiction of women as sex objects, so he never got complaints about it. For example, growing up, I saw all these politically correct campaigns about how girls are just as smart and capable as boys, but then I would return to my everyday life and be reminded that I was to grow up and be a mother, a nurturer, etc. Look in the toy aisle at Wal-Mart if you do not believe that I was influenced to think this way. It is filled with soft, domestic things for girls, and tough, manly things for boys. And that's tragic for BOTH genders! Boys should not have to put up a masculine, unemotional front every day of their lives, just as girls shouldn't have to follow traditionally feminine roles.I'm just an 18-year-old girl; I'm not a follower of feminist blogs, and I am in no way a radical feminist. Likewise, I have no groundbreaking theory on how to fi x sexism, either, but I do know that pointing o ut sexism when I see it is the right thing to do--whether it is sexism against women OR men! I do NOT hate men. Men are good, decent, wonderful people and have done amazing things for me in my life. It's mostly men who fought and died for this country, and for that I have the utmost respect.I also respect your response to my comment, because it was polite and thoughtful, and I hope you will respond to this as well.
@HOLyPumpgun | Gaming Hey, if the worst thing I did was disagree with you politely and logically, I don't feel bad. ;)

@Violet Ornelle I really appreciate the well thought-out reply. You come across very balanced and reasonable. You're right in pointing out sexism when you see it but often this can be a bit misleading. Let's take your example for the toy-collection in a local supermarket. The company that sells those toys isn't trying to be sexist, they try to make as much profit as possible. If they could sell the same toys that they make for boys to girls, they wouldn't hesitate for a second. The truth is, they can't and any attempt to do so results in a loss of profit. This phenomenon has been studied, take for example this study  [LINK] . Granted, the sample size is pretty small (it is psychology after all...) but the same has been repeated for different primates with analogous results. This suggests that there may very well be differences between male and female brains on average. This is the problem with trying to point out sexism and hoping it will change things. When I point out that there are barely an y black people in my country's government and that this is a sign of racism, I may be trying to do good but the truth is that there simply aren't that m any black people in this country. When trying to do good by pointing out inequalities, it's important to find out where they come from instead of simply protesting them. This all isn't to say that there aren't any societal influences at play, there may very well be. It's important to never discriminate based on statistical averages, it's what a movement striving for equality should move towards (also, why feminism and not egalitarianism?). However, I think we're past this point. You say you're 18, if you're going to university or college next year, I hope you consider stem. I think I speak for most of my colleagues in saying that a more diverse group would liven up the place.
@Violet Ornelle Oh don't get me wrong, I think you seem like a very nice person, I just very vehemently disagree with your ideology.

+MrDpsc I do agree that our brains are different--that has been scientifically proven over and over again, and there are definitely sound evolutionary explanations for it. However, I don't agree with the other examples you used. The toy companies can't sell "boyish" toys to girls because of reasons beyond simple biological differences. From birth, we treat girls differently. We handle them as if they are fragile and delicate, whereas we roughhouse boys. (I'm sure you've encountered this concept before. This is a well-known study: [LINK] We also play different games with boys than girls; we are more inclined to teach girls to play domestic games like house, and boys baseball, soccer, etc. Our brains are different, but the social influences in our lives augment these differences. The other example you use is pointing out that black people are a minority in our government. I would agree with what you said if you didn't grossly overlook that even though they are a minority, they are still disproportionately underrepresented in our country! Lastly, if you don't think that pointing out inequality and discussing it makes a difference, you can't understand how we've come as far as we have in the U.S. in regard to inequality. I'm sorry I that sounds rude, but I can't say it effectively in a nice-sounding way. The suffrage and Civil Rights movements have a foundation in peaceful protest, discussion, and pointing out inequality when one sees it.

+MrDpsc Also, when it comes to distinguishing myself as either a feminist or an egalitarian, I say that I'm both, but I prefer the word egalitarian because it encompasses not only women's issues, but those of discrimination based on race, religion, etc. as well. But, as you said, this is a small point in a bigger issue.On a side note, I actually am in college right now, and (I know this doesn't make me look great) I'm an English/Literature major.

@Violet Ornelle  I don't live in the US so a black minority in my governement still makes sense. Furthermore, underrepresentation in the U.S. would still make sense as in general, black people have less money and politics is primarily a rich men's game. Protesting inequality in governement would therefore be the wrong move (stupid at best, harmful at worst), you'd have to find out why there is a difference in earnings. And while there are reasons beyond biological differences, the source you cite even admits that it's difficult to distinguish between nurture and nature. If the differences are mostly nurture then surely the problem will be solved by having less sexist parents, not by forcing target to remove their gender-specific toys? If the main source of this societal pressure are the parents themselves then not only will this problem be solved by our generation, feminists should be informing parents. But that is not what they're doing, is it? They're lobying for extra grants for femal e engineers, they're trying to close the paygap by artificially giving female-employees more mone y (sexism at it's finest). It's gotten so bad that in my field, a female with the same qualifications as me will have a 2 to 1 advantage when applying for a job. I don't think you sounded rude but you did misrepresent my point. I don't think pointing out inequality is harmful in itself. It's just that you need to know the cause before you can properly protest. To demonstrate this point, here's a bit of history. The country I live in is split into two parts (actually three but the third one is negligably small). The northern part speaks flemish, the southern part speaks french. Because of historical reasons, the northern part has more industry and is on average wealthier. More governement grants should go to that part because there is a more pressing need for infrastructure. However, in the past people pointed out this inequality between the two halves. With their mindless lobying they succeeded until relatively recently in creating the "wafelijzerpolitiek". When a big project needed money in the northern part, they'd seek out an equally expensive project in the south and fund them at the same time. This resulted in ineffective spending and a loss of a lot of taxpayer money. Mayoring in english literature? Not all hope is lost, you're still young. You can see the light, change mayors and study physics :^p

+MrDpsc

You'll probably never read this comment, but I gotta thank you for at least trying to open up discussion on this tenuous topic. I mostly don't agree with you, but I appreciate the gesture for open discussion. Your comment section is somewhat of a rarity on youtube.

No, "facts" and "statistics" are not the same thing. And no, you should not replace arguments with statistics, as blind as they are on their own. So fucking touchy! If a shirt discourages you from STEM, then you never had a passion for it anyway. There was a great study on the effects of culture on job choice where several researchers tested kids from age 10, 6, 3 and 6 months old about what kind of things they would like to be in hundreds of different ways and found overwhelmingly the same results. Furthermore they also looked at the trends between education rates an d gender equality and the types of jobs that those genders tend to go towards. As the equality divide lessened, there was a disparity on job wants. To put it simply, in countries like Sweden and UK, girls BY FAR, EMPIRICALLY SHOW that they want to lean towards more 'traditional' styles of jobs. I am so sick of everything being blamed on culture as if men and women have the same brains. Why is it so easy for people to think "men and womens bodys and hormones differ but in the brain they are the same." Equal opportunity does not mean equal results.  I also find it hilariously ironic that they criticise this guy who landed stuff on a fucking comet for wearing a shirt, then go on and protest about letting women wear what they want without being judged and how it is harassment. The list goes on and on.

I think it's good for people to ask themselves why they are annoyed but it's dishonest, and borderline absurd, to frame things as "what are you afraid of" and implying that it's about losing the sadistic pleasure in dehumanising women. Sexism is a lot of things. I think a sober-minded view on the subject, that also illustrates the complexity of the phenomena we're talking about, is Susan Fiskes theory of ambivalent sexism. What she, and others, have noted is that so called "benevolen t sexism" is cross-culturally correlated with so called "hosti le sexism". Ideas about women being beautiful, innocent, precious, good, and kind often co-occur with ideas about women being weak, fragile, deceptive, things to own, things to control etc. (and if I recall correctly, correlated within cultures too). There is no dirty secret ab out sexism bec ause sexism isn't one thing. It's a clusterfuck of different processes. Often it's simply about beliefs and assumptions. It's viewing women as very different creatures than men. Sometimes it's about motivation, like I imagine being heterosexual messes with your head and often prompts you to put all women into the same mental box. Sometimes it's about visibility. Seeing male as the default human being. Sometimes it's about power. Sometimes it's about ideology. Sometimes it's about religion. Why were people upset about shirt gate? here's my two cents: I think it varies from person to person. But I think for the most part that it wasn't about STEM males being afraid that girls would enter their boys club, but maybe sometimes. I think it often was people feeling like they've been equally sexist at other times and that thus the accusation was vicariously also about them. So they got defensive. So they went too far, like people always do when they get defensive. So they found an attraction in a narrative about how all the evil feminists have come to ruin science with their fuzzy bullshit, cause that narrative works well to extinguish their self-doubt about their own moral standing. "They're saying I'm evil? I say they're the evil ones!" Anti-feminists are constantly waiting for feminists to say something overly sensitive so that they can say "look at how overly sensitive this is", "they're professional victims I tell you!"
You look like John Krasinski.

'Objectification' is a non-problem, and is in fact a regular facet of everyday social interactions that every human being has with the world at large. Do you consider the complex facets of what make up the human being who sweeps up the shit at the office you work at? No, you think of him as 'the janitor', and there's nothing wrong with that, because we can't possibly be expected to consider everybody as a complex human being outside of their usefulness to us with the exception of friends and family, because that simply is not possible. No one has the time and energy to devote to it. Yet, somehow, in the context of male sexuality, this has been turned into a pejorative idea, without any evidence of harm, through simple chorus repititon. This is more of the same vapid noise, peddling itself as erudition.

I got to this video a bit late in the game, but you seem to be very actively responding to comments, so I don't feel like my input will be thrown into the wind here. I enjoyed the video, though I don't share your opinion. Ultimately, the main argument being used against this man is that while his shirt isn't inherently and single-handedly oppressing women out of STEM fields, it is a minor contribution to the force that keeps men so heavily in the majority within these fields. My issue with that argument is that I don't really see the other forces at hand. If this shirt is the snowflake to the avalanche of sexism keeping women out of STEM, I don't think it's snowing. I have seen no compelling evidence showing women actively or even passively being pushed out of these fields. Certainly, the statistics you cited about how women aren't getting as much recognition once they are trying to be published are troubling, and undoubtedly an issue, but even that to me doesn't feel like a particularly compelling argument to say why women aren't going into STEM. Further, I don't think it's at all unfair to say that women may just not be as interested in STEM as men are naturally. There's an extreme aversion nowadays about anything one says that even creates a minor amount of basic and genera l gender differences. I don't think that's healthy, and I think it only perpetuates the things it tries to prevent. The sense I get from many of my female friends isn't a longing for a job in these fields while being discouraged by t he sexism, most of them just don't actually have any interest, which is totally fine. Likewise, while there may be forces at play keeping a man from being a Kindergarten teacher, I wouldn't say it's at all unfair to say that men are probably less likely to even want to be Kindergarten teachers in the first place out of the intrin sic gender differences leading females to pursue that job and men not to. Certainly, based on the actual objective information you presented here, there is a definite and preventable problem that could be keeping women out of STEM. Whether or not it is, it needs to be fixed. Regardless, I think that using a guy's shirt as a catalyst for that discussion makes the discussion sound trivial, and will only lead to further the divide between genders. Like you said, the most common reaction was annoyance. When I first heard about the story, I thought, "Ugh, Jesus, seriously?" and it actively made me less engaged to the topic. Like I said, I think picking something like this to jump off with is ridiculous, and the discussion surrounding this whole event is totally toxic.
And if I feel annoyed what do I ask myself?

We are stunting women's growth by consistently lumping individual adversity to collective adversity and putting efforts to remove them both. commentThread.commentText: If I understand correctly, your argument is that men derive some sort of pleasure from the dominance of sexism? Because the example that you are putting into the forefront is Matt Taylor's shirt. Do you think he's trying to exert the male dominance in wearing that shirt or do you think he thought his shirt was sick and he loves it? Do you think that everyone who is annoyed at people criticizing his shirt just feel threatened by the fact that someone is taking away their tool of sexist dominance or do you think that they are angry that someone who they consider a great man is being attacked for wearing a shirt he thought was neat? I believe that the reason there aren't as many women in STEM fields is basically that graduate STEM degrees are pursued by nerds (not in a denigrating sense). STEM fields isn't sexist or culturally acceptable shirts, it is grueling hours examining logic circuits, memorizing Bayenesian statistics and quantum thermodynamics. It is wave probability equations and arrow pushing chemical reactions. It is nerds who pursue these fields and, I believe, there are a lot more male nerds than female nerds (look up any typical 'nerd' activity, be it Magic: The Gathering tournaments, DOTA 2 International attendance, robot hobbyists etc... you will find that the gender ratios are skewed). I'm a graduate student in a science field and I'm a huge nerd and so is everyone else (men and women). Why are there more men nerds than women nerds is a completely different question and definitely deserves examination (who knows, there may b e sexism in the roots of it). STEM fields aren't about machismo, aggressiveness and assertiveness or a male culture (some report investment bankers are this way). STEM fields are about nerds studying nerdy things.

commentThread.commentText: I think the main difference between your side and the anti-SJW side (stripping away all the emotion) is that SJWs treat people unequally based on their race, gender, and sexuality while the anti-SJW side mostly just wants everyone to be treated equally. The point that anti-SJWs try to make in regards to this shirt and many other issues is that if you are allowed to criticize a man for his tasteless shirt, then you should also be allowed to criticize a woman for her, let's say, overly sexy clothing. Or that if you are allowed to criticize someone for being white (I've lost count of how many anti- #gamergate  people I've seen on twitter calling for white men to be genocided) then it should also be okay to criticize someone for bei ng black. Obviously criticizing blacks for the color of their skin is verbotten and rightly so. And obviously criticizing women for wearing stuff that's too sexy is verbotten and rightly so. What the anti-SJW side is protesting is the hypocrisy. It's sort of like "Okay, I agreed to treat everyone equally and I'm doing my best at it and it seems to be working and life seems to be better, but, what the hell, now you are attacking me because of my r ace, gender, and sexuality? WTF?" The whole idea behind the SJW mentality appears to be a mix of intersectiona lity, patriarchy theory, and the hierarchy of oppression. While the anti-SJW side is about treating everyone equally. Feminism seems to have this vocal minority with an SJW mentality, which is why we're seeing a lot of anti-feminists and men's rights advocates pop out of the woodwork. Anti-feminism is a reaction to this SJW stuff. It's basically saying "I don't want special privileges for women due to their gender. I want equality and equal treatment for everyone." #shirtgate  has spawned a lot of parodies and, for me, by far the most poignant one was a picture of naked angry feminists protesting something or other with the title "empowerment" and that same picture on a shirt with the title "oppression". I discussed this image with a feminist. She claimed that the shirt, when worn by a man, would objectify the women on the picture. So I asked her what if Kim Kardashian sold t-shirts with a photo of her butt. She claimed it would be empowering, because it's her decision and she can consent to this. So I asked what if Kim Kardashian drew a picture of her butt and sold that on a t-shirt. Same thing. Empowering. So I pointed out that the person who designed Matt Taylor's shir t was a woman. That was two days ago. No response. In the long term what I personally fear is that if we allow this hypocrisy of some genders and races being okay to mock and criticize, but others not, for the same exact thing, then this same logic will be carried over to other field s. E.g. "black people commit a disproportionate amount of crimes, therefore we must be prejudiced towards them." I don't want that. I want to treat everyone equally. Not based on some hierarchy of oppression.

replies.commentText: Hey Elver. I appreciate your dispassionate and well written analysis. I have to say, though, it seems to me that the "anti-SJW" movement fears something that's largely imaginary, this "some genders and races being okay to mock and criticize, but others not" thing you're talking about. Criticism based on race, gender , sexual orientation is never OK, and I rarely hear it from feminists I know or read or see. If I did hear someone calling for "white men to be genocided," what do you think I'd say? We all want people to be treated equally, but that is a /very complex/ thing to figure. It begins with understanding that we can't just start with today, we have to take into account the history of oppression, how certain groups got here at the expense of others. This is the idea behind, for example, affirmative action. Like it or not, we inherit the responsibilities of our parents and their parents. I think our time is best spent trying to learn what that history is.

If we're looking at the history of oppression, then we have to look at it with way more granularity than just the color of the skin. For example, I'm Estonian. Our people were first mentioned in an Ancient Roman scroll and starting with the earliest crusades, we were ruled by Germans, Danes, Swedes, and finally Russians. Under all these rulers we were slaves, for more than 700 years. If my memory serves me right, Estonians did not gain basic rights under Tsarist rule until a few years after the abolishment of slavery in the USA. It wasn't until the chaos at the end of WW1 that we finally declared independence, until uncle Stalin decided to grab our territory for himself. Our country did not exist again until 1991. Should I be angry at Germans, Danes, Swedes, or Russians? Should I bear some sort of ill will towards Slavic people in general? Should we ask for reparations? Would it make any sense to go up to a visiting Russian tourist and tell him to check his privilege? None of these options make any sense to me. Affirmative action i.e. discriminating against those whose grandparents discriminated against my grandparents does not make sense to me. If an ethnic Russian wants to work at my company, I'm not going to tell him to go away just because his grandfather was in the Re d> Army where he invaded and occupied my people, probably killing a few of my countrymen along the way. I'm not going to treat an Austrian differently just because the legendary baron Roman von Ungern-Sternberg tried to personally murder my great-great-grandfather for the crime of teaching reading and writing to his fellow Estonians. If we continue this contest of who has been oppressed the most, then we're not going to get anywhere. We have far more in common with each other than we think. Focusing on our differences and on whose great grandparents were oppressed the most is simply going to perpetuate the cycle of anger, hatred, and violence. There will always be nutcases on all sides who take things too far and I've already seen way too many nutcases on the SJW side. Because any time you start lumping people into groups and start privileging one group over another, based on whatever criteria, you're going to see nutcases living out th eir racist and sexist fantasies to the extreme. But, hey, if we are going to compete on who has been oppressed the most, then I'm pretty sure I'm gonna win. Because, arguably, in the context of being oppressed by other groups base d on ethnicity, Estonians have had it worse and for far longer than even black slaves in USA. Hard to compete with 700+ years of slavery, including the local lord's right to deflower virgin daughters of his subjects.

@Elver Loho Excellent points here. It always gets to me when people focus on skin color in reaction to racism, and then forget to do the painstaking history of ethnic study. Because there have been white-skinned people who have been enslaved, but they don't matter. The Barbary Pirates never existed in the greater discussion on these issues. The issue to me is not that I have my rights protected, the issue to me is that overlooking real history enables a different animal to take over from th e pigs who took over from the humans. We're just changing clothes, not attacking the moral evils that are the root cause.

commentThread.commentText: I think we should take a step back and realize that in the same way our cultural misogyny provides us pleasure, we also take pleasure in telling other people that their misogyny is wrong.  The shirt may represent a larger anti-female bias in STEM fields, but at the same time, it's just a shirt, an easily rectified problem (as in, stop wearing it).   Why is it that only we only express our outrage when we have a figurehead to direct our outrage at?  There are bigger, institutional fish to fry.  Why don't we pressure labs to hire female scientists somehow, either legally or with a petition?  Why don't we take the time to talk to girls about the fact that women are underrepresented in these fields?  I would say it's because we don't get the same visceral satisfaction as we got when this man admitted he was wrong.

replies.commentText: "We also take pleasure in telling other people that their misogyny is wrong." Now that's properly psychoanalytical, and maybe not 100% incorrect either. Not quite a counter to the argument in the video, but worth thinking about. Institutions, like institutional problems, are made up of people.

Well then take 60 seconds to ask yourself if you agree or disagree with the witch-hunt he went through, reducing him into tears. And if it is the former, ask yourself, "What is it that I'm in danger of losing?" Don't get me wrong, I'm not being facetious here; I am very serious. This gets to be beating heart of the matter. The dirty secret of righteous indignation is that it's pleasurable. It's pleasurable to assert your dominance on a hierarchy you create. It's pleasurable in the sense that wearing your Sunday best is pleasurable, the feeling of being a winner at bettering someone. So when we're thinking about issues like this, we have to keep in mind that were talking about is people's pleasures, about taking it away from them. Rightly so, and it will come as no surprise that they'll be reluctant to let it go here, as in any other instance of gratification. In the active sense righteous indignation is easy to condemn. But in the passive sense, it's far more insidious; to tell otherwise rational and level headed people, that by doing nothing at all that they're perpetuating Puritanism, subjective reasoning, and virtue signalling. To require them to think about their actions and their inactions, may feel incredibly annoying. That's what it feels to take someone's pleasure away, a pleasure that is so normalised, so baked into our lives, it's removal feels a lot like pain. I, for one, think that it's possible to hold two lines of thought in mind at once; to marvel at the unbelievable magic of the suffragettes movements, and to lament the real contribution, however small, of one woman's lamentation at one man's fashion choice at a community of scientists, who began at a loss.

commentThread.commentText: I'm glad you're trying to point out the basis of the backlash against feminism and feminist action, but I'm afraid that in mentioning taking away men's 'pleasure' you may be giving anti-feminists a weapon to use against feminism, in that that 'pleasure' was theirs to own and enjoy and we are 'taking it away from them'. It should be mentioned that that pleasure comes at the cost of everyone else's pleasure - women, POC, gay >people , disabled people. I'm a woman in science - I'm studying to be a medical doctor - and that shirt didn't anger me so much as it depressed me. I was incredibly excited about the rosetta landing, but that shirt made it obvious to me that despite my interest in the sciences, and my having loved astronomy as a hobby since childhood, this man viewed me in the same way as the old men who would feel me up on the subway when I was 14. My interest and passion in the subject m eans nothing to people who only see women as objects to be consumed. It's important to remember that the reaction to the shirt isn't just a reaction to the one instance, but the lifetime of instances of people telling women that they aren't good enough, that they are only worth how attractive men find them. I believe this constitutes a systematic denial of 'pleasure' for women and other marginalised people, who constantly have to work against society in order to achieve their goals and to stay safe. For example, I would love to travel alone, but I cannot due to the high chances of being rap ed. A black person would love to be able to call the police without being afraid for their own lives. This 'pleasure' that white straight men get out of bigotry comes from a denial of the pleasure of so many others, and It's important to recognise that, especially when pointing out why so many people are hesitant to let that go. I just finished a fantastic book on global sexism called 'half the sky'. It's a tough read but hopeful and incredibly pragmatic and largely free from dissertation-level doublespeak, which works in its favour. Check it out:  [LINK]

commentThread.commentText: First off, I'm a big fan of your channel. I always get excited when I see something new get uploaded. You've done a great job at helping me look at things from a different perspective. Hate that this is the first time I'm posting on your channel but I've spent the entire day reading about several cultural occurrences very similar to this one and you uploading this today leads me feeling that I need to say this: I was entirely on board until around 3:05. This line of argument is what I find most annoying about these discussions. To keep in theme with your video- I feel like I'm in danger of not getting to have an opinion. When you bring up privilege or the patriarchy (both things that, I admit, do exist in our culture in one way or another) a card is being played that effectively invalidates anything I have to say. By saying I'm so entrenched in the patriarchy and entitlement that I'm not even aware of my own actions not only belittles my opinion but effectively removes me from the conversation entirely. I must bow out of any discussion or else I am somehow supporting th e patriarchy and/or abusing my privilege. Have I been on the receiving end of some advantages that have not been made available to others? Probably. Should this mean that I don't get to have an opinion or even have the ability to engage in a debate in regards to anything involvi ng gender or race? I certainly hope not. Even if I am in fact speaking from a privileged position.  I personally would not wear that man's shirt nor would I ever want to purchase something like it. That shi t is tacky. But if it's how he chooses to express or identify himself- then I believe he does not deserve to be shamed for this. And effectively that is what's happening- maybe not a crucifixion but it is certainly attempted character assassination. We both know that there is a difference be tween sexi sm and misogyny but the general public doesn't. And labeling someone's attire or attitude as sexist places that person with some pretty unscrupulous company. So I can understand why people would be offended by X and I can understand why people would fight against X. But what I can't understand is why if I disagree with your stance then I must also defend ALL oppression of women and/or non-white people. Any way, thanks for looking at all these comments. As I'm sure you're aware- you've opened a pretty big can of worms. Best of luck getting through it all...and keep up the good work.

The point I'm making is that it takes awhile for the efforts of today to show themselves in percentages of the scale, and using it as a indicator isn't particularly helpful. I'd be more interested to know about 20-30 year olds, and what the percentages are there, and perhaps how it's changed. I think there's a real discussion that's interesting and fulfilling along the lines of women in Stem. I see in companies that are global that even the region can really dictate how these percentages work out. Clearly different biases and social pressures are occurring in each place which is interesting to consider. I think having a dispassionate discussion as opposed to an enflamed passionate one is where we can find value. - When it comes to the shirt, it's in poor taste, but it doesn't speak to a broader issue in my mind, it speaks to one individual's poor decision making. No company would allow them to wear that shirt in the workplace, and that speaks volumes for the fact this isn't even allowed in "Stem" fields. commentThread.commentText: Thank you for always presenting new but logical positions on current issues! You are always so insightful and interesting. I often find myself citing you in many of my arguments!

It all just seems hypocritical coming from feminists to me.  The same people who will say that they want to be able to wear whatever they want without being objectified will then condemn a man for doing the same thing.  Never-mind the fact that the shirt was made by his girlfriend and that she thinks it looks awesome.  So in that regard, I don't think I'm annoyed or threatened, it's just that as a woman I can only see this response to what is effectively a non-issue as diminishing real sexism. I can understand why the outrage exists, but what this boils down to me is that there is a collective mentality within feminism (and to varying degrees, against feminism) that is unable to see men or people accused o f sexism as individuals who possess their own individual rights.  Once they are labelled as sexist they seem to have their individuality removed and all reasonable dialogue goes out the window with it.  It's something that I think that Martin Luther King, Jr. was more than aware of within the civil rights movement.  I know it was a different time with a different context, but I think there is something haunting about how applicable his words are when applied the modern feminist movement.  And in that respect, I think he said it best: "We must not seek to use our emerging freedom and our growing power to do the same thing to the white minority that has been done to us for so many centuries. Our aim must never be to defeat or humiliate the white man. We must not become victimized with a philosophy of black supremacy. God is not interested merely in free ing black men and brown men an d y e>>llow men, but God is interested in freeing the whol e human race. We must work with determination to create a society, n ot where black men are superior and other men are inferior and vice versa, but a society in which all men will live together as brothers and respect the dignity and worth of human personality."

commentThread.commentText: I am having a lot of difficulty with this. We often focus on only one type of objectification when we talk about it - the sexual objectification of women. Unfortunately, this is not the only type of objectification that exists. For example, I would argue that a man wearing a nice suit and watch in an ad could be financially objectified (and this could also be sexual, depending on what a person finds attractive). We also choose to objectify ourselves at times, and this is not necessarily a bad thing, as I'm sure a model's bank account will indicate. But the point of speaking out against it is that objectification treats people as only having one defining characteristic that makes them desirable, and not a fully-developed human, as they truly are. It is bad because it takes away the agency of that person, unwillingly. (There is a interesting side note here about campaigning against judging women by how they dress, but not standing by that campaign for a male). The question then becomes this: is a scantily cla d woman inherent ly sexual? and if there is some kind of image of t hat woman, is it inherently objectification? At this point we start getting into the messy grey area of motivations and intent, and whether or not those matter when someone else is offended. And, to a lesser extent, how people allow themselves to react and behave when offended. This is where I think that it mak es a transition into the subject of women in STEM fields. If we are going to ask, "Is this shirt indicative of an attitude in STEM fields?" then we first must figure out what the shirt indicates. I don't think many people paused to ask that question. I cannot say whether or not women are kept out of STEM research by one method or another, but I do not think that this shirt is an indicator of any particular culture than his tattoos might be. The point is this- we must broaden our definitions of objectification, and realize that it is something we all do, on a regular basis. This will help us identify and tackle the seriously detrimental objectification (and be rightfully offended and reactionary), while leaning to let the lesser, non-detrimental act that we all do just fade away into a bri ghtly colored, obno xious, tacky background.

replies.commentText: Well said, dbrockop. Worth a read for anyone scrolling through these comments.  "We first must figure out what the shirt indicates." An interesting thought experiment might be to ask: How would you feel about the shirt if it was full of totally nude women? Or just one giant nude woman across the front? Would it still just be obnoxious and tacky? Or would you say it's disrespectful to women to wear that on a day when you know you'll be on a webcast watched by thousands of women and girls? Would it be disrespectful to men if you had naked men on a shirt and wore it in the same circumstances? I think it would be disrespectful in both circumstances. But it feels a little funny to ask about the naked men, right? I think that feeling tells us something important. It tells us these things don't exist in a vacuum. Like it or not, women have experienced real, unforgivable, often silent oppression for a very long time. It doesn't just go away, it's systematized in our culture. So I think that, though the women are not nude on Taylor's shirt, the effect of scantily clad women is not much different. It indicates a similar thing, that this is a boy's club. Not by itself, but along with the many other things that act as puzzle pieces to make that larger message. Maybe you disagree, and I wouldn't hold it against you, as I can see you've really thought about this. To quote you: "I am having a lot of difficulty with this." These are subtle things we're talking about.

Nudity and FCC regulations aside, we're still making a fundamental assumption here: visual depiction of certain areas women's skin is, by nature, inherently (a) sexual and (b) objectification (which is assumed to be bad). I'm not saying this shirt wasn't sexual, and I'm unclear on whether or not it objectifies women, as this is a fairly poorly defined concept (are these real women depicted? what if it was wonde r woman?). But that's my point - vast assumptions about a nebulous topic. My point here is that we should probably have the same attitude in social situations as judicial. We usually call it the benefit of the doubt. (It should be worth noting I'm not really defending the shirt here, but rather the idea that we can determine all of these things from one action and somehow use it to shape our view of not only academia but also society) I have a hard time agreeing with the idea that this shirt is an indicator of general sentiment in STEM fields, with relation to both fashion and women. I would be tempted to ask why it is that women are under-represented in STEM fields when women have also done overwhelmingly well in other fields. Certainly the concept of a boy's club (or another kind of restriction) would be an easy, and viable answer. Even though it may have merit, I think it is a lazy answer, and is too quick to pin the problem on an external force. As noted by other commenters, t he age of the sample group it quite telling. Simply looking at the end result (or progress thus far) cannot indicate equality of opportunity, nor lack thereof. If this were the case, we can conclude that nursing is a "girl's club" and excludes men. Is it? It actually doesn't feel funny to ask about men, at least for me. You're right that society rarely does, though. But I'd be willing to bet that if he was wearing a shirt with objectified men on it, there would be more outcry that it harms women than men because of it's aggressive take on male sexuality.

What bothers me about all of this is that it seems to me that his shirt has gotten more attention than the actual achievement. He did such a marvelous thing, for the first time in human history and all attention goes to the shirt he was wearing?! I do agree that it may have been a less optimal choice of clothing for an event such as this, and also that it may avert some girls from going in to STEM lines of work, however, I firmly believe it was not his intention.

Further, if we are going to talk signals. Will it not discourage many more to do any actual work in the STEM field if your choice in fashion vastly outweighs you scientific achievements? Also, as you got in on in the video, if we compare how much attention the act of landing something on an asteroid got to how much attention the "break the internet" thing got. As before, it seems to me like scientific achievements are fairly forgotten in the most popular corners of the internet and in mass media. "Break the internet" will probably not be featured in any serious newspapers but we are still bombarded with the latest gossip and fashion tips there instead of anything with any scientific value whatsoever. Granted, there are magazines devoted to science but those are not the ones that are read by a majority of the population. I believe that is a much larger problem and sends a lot more signals than Dr. Matt Taylors shirt did.

TL;DR; I believe that the fact that mass media and the most popular corners of the internet favor fashion, gossip and "reality"-tv over science, is much more detrimental to science and all related fields of work than any shirt Dr Taylor could possibly have worn.

But I do believe that there is a real effect (effect explained in the video & elsewhere in comments) when someone wears a shirt like that on a global, highly publicized webcast. And that it would probably have been a better idea for him not to wear it, or for someone to say, "You know, Matt, it's probably a bad idea to wear that on this platform."

That is true.  So do we blame him personally or the higher ups for not bringing that up to him before he got on the air?  I mean, there were plenty of opportunities for someone to stop him from wearing that shirt up until he showed up on camera, and honestly the only criticism I would ever bring up is that he doesn't look professional enough to talk about landing on a comet.

Maybe I'm not that affected by it because I myself am a female training to get into the STEM fields and the shirt bothered me only because of the severe clashing of colors.  It could be a personal thing that is making me reach my conclusion.

"You know, Matt, if you wear this shirt on this platform, people may love the shirt I made, and I may be swamped with orders, and live off the money you won for me for the rest of my life!"

By the way, that's actually what's happening. The designer continues being famous even years after the whole controversy. AND here you can see the difference between individualism and collectivism: some people prefer the very real positive effect for a single real living person, even at the cost of a perceived minimal negative effect for a whole collective.

Sexualization isn't always negative. Women can express themselves sexually without being objectified or shamed (see slut-shaming). This sexual expression is seen as empowering by third-wave feminists. I'd argue that that the negative impact of sexual expression on a public platform happens when the way that image is perceived moves beyond imagining a person complexly (as an actual human with feelings and aspirations), and merely as a sexual object. In the case of Taylor's shirt, t he woman was obviously objectified as a grotesque decoration, but maybe a cartoonish depiction of a scantly clad female character, as art, isn't objectifying women and driving them away from STEM? Maybe it's just an innocent decoration with no hierarchical dominance being asserted, which Evan argues. I'm not sure yet. The real question may not be if the situation is sexist (the true morality of the issue) or not, but if the shirt will drive women away from STEM by making STEM "look" sexist. So, a societal reaction of percei ved sexism, someone getting offended.

The obvious difference between Kim and this guy's shirt is the Kim K sexualized herself, making herself the agent of sexualization.  This guy's shirt sexualized women without their active participation.  Which is a huge problem that feeds into rape culture and our perception of women as not being agents of their own sexuality, and where their sexuality is essentially the property of public domain. I should think that would be fairly obvious.

Sexuality =/= Denigration, and that applies to both men and women. However, there is a difference in how male/female sexuality is represented and used in media, and more-often-than-not female sexuality is shown as "something to be gained" while male sexuality is typically shown as "something to aspire to". Both generally cater to the male gaze, but one is for the sake of possession while the other is a model for how a man should be.

Kim Kardashian has gone on record saying she did that photo-shoot for herself, but the images still emphasize and conflate her "attractiveness" as a person to her bodily features, solely; whether or not this is for parody's sake is another question entirely (because her curves are pretty much the center of media attention anyways), but it still reduces her person to body parts for our consumption. Rarely is Ryan Gosling, or other male celebrities, put in the same position (and when they are, it arguably draws attention because of how "out of place" it seems).

And as was said in the video, the shirt that scientist wore merely represents the attitude of a "boys club" within the STEM field. The content of the shirt is problematic, certainly, but it seems like the "time and place" for wearing the shirt is being criticized for the most part.

It need to be a case by case. Not trying to attack you ether.

You can't just treat it case by case because that doesn't solve the root of the problem which is overall sexism in society and how people should be taught to treat women. I know it's unreported because of I've talked about this to over a dozen friends. And they don't report harassment because I don't think you realize how difficult that can be. First off, it's a your word against mine scenario most of the time and nothing can be proved. Second, even if you prove it, a slap on the wrist is usually all the punishment that gets dealt. Third, you have to put yourself in the spotlight as a victim, everyone will know and think about you differently. It's unfortunate and one of the problems that we need to address as society as a whole, but people do treat you differently after you've gone through that process. For most people, unless it is a more serious harassment, it's just not worth it to go through all of that. It's easier to just ignore it, and deal with it as something that "just happens." It's heartbreaking but I've heard those words from so many women that I've talked to about this. "It's OK this is just something that happens." It's easy to just say be strong and don't let people harass you, but this is the problem with that- A, that is a sort of victim blaming. We shouldn't have to teach women how to deal with harassment, we should be teaching men not harass. That's a deep cultural problem that will take generations to fix, but yeah, it exists. B, people tend to view harassment as something that comes from boogeymen on the street or the scummy guy at work that everyone agrees is scummy. Truth is it comes more often from friends or colleagues that are otherwise good people. So when they cross the line it can be difficult to press charges against them. Example- You're in line for a promotion and your boss makes it obvious what he wants you to do to get it. Obviously giving in to that is no solution. If you press charges, everyone will treat you differently and it could make the whole workplace uncomfortable. So most just choose to brush it off. This sounds like a movie scenario but this kind of shit or similar happens all the time. It would be great if reportin g sexism and being strong would work in our current society, but it's really not that simple. I recommend the book Lucky by Alice Sebold if you want to learn more about how skewed against women the justice system really is when it comes to harassment, or in the case of this book, rape. And it will reveal to you better than I can in a comment what the backlash is from society and what that can do to a person. You're right in that we need to encourage women to report it and discourage backlash, but in order to actually do that will involve changing the way society views women from it's core. Not so easy. Anyway, I'm not really arguing about this in the context of just STEM. If anything STEM is a better environment than most. I'm talking more generally. It's a larger issue that affects women everywhere and filters down to include women going into STEM.

@Madison Healey It's not a straw man, I am not saying that you are consciously advocating for tyranny or censorship. Or that your argument is that those things are good. I am not trying to misrepresent your argument, but show how this line of reasoning either leads to those things, or shows an underlying system of thinking that is unintentionally oppressive. For instance, there are currently people who think salary negotiations should be removed because men tend to hold out for more money, which is unfair towards women. Now in no way are they directly arguing that women can't compete with men, but the belief that women can't compete with men is a direct requirement for that argument to make sense. I have noticed that this gender stereotype of women being weak and in need of protection is a fundamental aspect of nearly all the arguments of modern day regressives. One obvious place this underlying belief emerges is when we talk about representations of men and women in media. If men and women are free to make content, and represent themselves and each other in whatever way they want. Then the only reason to regulate in any way how one gender is portrayed is because you believe thi s gender has a natural disadvantage. Why would yo ur gender need a leg up if they are fundamentally equal? You say you don't want to impose certain standards and that's great. But by going out and perpetuating a culture where there is currently a sort of social morality police that cracks down on things they find offensive, those standards are certainly being imposed. You yourself talk about how women are "portrayed", the underlying belief there being that these portrayals impose on women that they should act in a certain way. So if you accept that rules can be imposed that easily, then surely you must accept that this social morality policing also imposed on the freedoms of the individuals who just want to create content. So the big picture I see here, condensed into a few sentences, is this. 1: It is wrong to tell people how to live their lives. 2: Other people living their lives influences me, and thus tells me how I should live my life. 3: Therefore, I should tell them how to live their lives. I agree with the first part. But when we get to the second part, I have problems with it. It is technically true, but it is the attitude of an object, people who do this fail to hold themselves accountable for their own actions. This does not encourage them to better themselves, which encourages mediocrity, which in turn causes them to do less well in life, which they can then in turn blame on others, creating a vicious circle. But mostly I object to it because it leads to point 3, and most people don't see that. You can't stop society from telling people how to act, by telling people how to act. There are two ways in which society can tell you what to do. As an example, take hair length. Society can tell you directly "women should have this hair, period" like in north korea. People can tell you directly, "you shouldn't be allowed to do this because I don't like it". This is direct oppression and should not be tolerated. Then there is the secondary or indirect form. I believe that the key point in this argument that in most first world countries, it is the legacy of patriarchal attitudes that live on, not the attitudes in their entirety. Traditional portrayals of women in stories like Cinderella and Snow White have had immense impacts on today's culture, as seeing or reading the stories even once as a child has the potential to cement in that young mind what their gender makes them "inclined" to do. Stories like these make up a sort of mythos that is supplemented later by news stories and advertisements and eventually real world examples that suggest to us that those stories had an element of truth in them. We grow older, unknowingly carrying on these values, and eventually pass them on to our children, starting with the fairy tales. This is where the distinction between institutionalized sexism and de facto, everyda y sexism becomes clear. Our roots as a society are so deeply grounded in sexist attitudes that nearly everything we do or touch serves to in some way affirm what we were predisposed to believe. It is in this context that I believe that this shirt is insignificant. Attacking a man for what he wears is not going to change the fact that nearly everyone in the United States received their first bit of education abo ut gender from fairy tales, or from their parents directly (see Leave it to Beaver). I honestly have no idea how to fix such a problem as this, where the issue has become so intertwined with the society that it seems to be an integral part of it. As a final aside, I would like to point out that, a s a race, humans have often tended towards distinctions base d on gender. As hunter-gathe rers, sexual dimorphism made it excee dingly common for men to hunt and women to gather. Nearly every society I can think of thought of women as lesser of fundamentally different from men. My question to you is this: why? The fact that this sort of distinction between men and wome n is so common, even in societies that never made outside contact, suggests something, but for the life of me I don't know what to gather from it. Are we simply predis posed to sexism as a species?

Decades of anthropology and scientific research contradict this. None of the gender differences we have studied today existed before agriculture, and many of them didn't exist until very recently. Before Victorian times, men were stereotypically emotional and women were sterotypically logical and rational. Talking about feelings was considered masculine before the Wild West movies of the 50's popularized the strong silent type. The behaviour of animals varies so wildly from species to species that you can't trace any real sex difference trend across them, though some people certainly like to cherrypick events that look similar to moder n gender differences. Mo st gender differences in our culture can be traced back to the division of labour that occurred when agriculture began 10,000 years ago. Before agriculture, men and women traveled together, hunting, trading, raising children, and there was no division of labour. Agriculture required that some people go out to hunt and trade while others stay behind to tend the home and care for the children. Since women get pregnant, they were relegated to the latter. Evolution occurs over millions of years, not a few thousand, so this cannot have made anything hard-wired in our brains. As for STEM, considering all the studies that keep showing that people discriminate enormously against women in stereotypically male fields, and all the companies who have reported that their female and minority hires shot up once they started blacking out names on resumes, it's clear that we aren't free. We are following unwritten rules that were made up thousands of years ago, which are obsolete now and cost us enormous talent. It's not individualism to constantly blindly follow obsolete rules. Think how far we could have come as a society if we were utilizing all of our talent!

We judge people with tattoos by their actions and what they say, not by how they look. Surely we can extend the same to the scientist.
